question_text:
Four days after admission to the hospital for severe dehydration due to profuse, bloody diarrhea, a 10-year-old boy is evaluated for decreased urine output. Physical examination shows generalized abdominal tenderness and numerous punctate, non-blanching macules on the trunk and extremities. Serum creatinine and urea nitrogen are elevated. A peripheral blood smear shows schistocytes. Which of the following sets of laboratory values is most likely in this patient?

Prothrombin time
Partial thromboplastin time
Bleeding time
Platelet count

A
Normal
Normal
Increased
Decreased

B
Increased
Increased
Normal
Normal

C
Increased
Increased
Increased
Decreased

D
Normal
Normal
Increased
Normal

E
Normal
Increased
Normal
Normal
content_preview: Four days after admission to the hospital for severe dehydration due to profuse, bloody diarrhea, a 10-year-old boy is evaluated for decreased urine output. Physical examination shows generalized abdominal tenderness and numerous punctate, non-blanching macules on the trunk and extremities. Serum creatinine and urea nitrogen are elevated. A peripheral blood smear shows schistocytes. Which of the following sets of laboratory values is most likely in this patient? Prothrombin time Partial thromboplastin time Bleeding time Platelet count A Normal Normal Increased Decreased B Increased Increased Normal Normal C Increased Increased Increased Decreased D Normal Normal Increased Normal E Normal Increased Normal Normal
hint: Oliguria, petechial lesions, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and acute kidney injury in the setting of bloody diarrhea is highly suggestive of hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS). HUS is caused by Shiga toxin-producing enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli (STEC).
learning_objective: Recognize hemolytic uremic syndrome, and recall its hematological findings.

answers.explanation_why: In HUS, endothelial dysfunction leads to the formation of microthrombi in the arterioles and capillaries, especially in the kidney, where it can precipitate acute kidney injury (AKI). Erythrocytes and platelets also undergo mechanical damage as they pass through the microcirculation, as seen in the schistocytes on peripheral smear. Platelet dysfunction manifests as increased bleeding time as a result both of the resultant thrombocytopenia and the negative effects of uremia on platelet function from AKI. PT and PTT are typically normal but may be slightly elevated.

images.title: Schistocytes in hemolytic uremic syndrome
images.description: Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (Giemsa stain; high magnification)Fragmented erythrocytes (schistocytes) with a normal convex border on one side and concave or straight border on the other side (examples indicated by blue overlay) are visible. The majority of erythrocytes appear normal.Schistocytes are a typical diagnostic finding in hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS).

answers.explanation_why: Elevated PT and PTT with preservation of platelet count and bleeding time can be seen in hemorrhagic disease of the newborn due to vitamin K deficiency, which occurs due to the inability to synthesize vitamin K. This constellation of findings can also be seen in liver cirrhosis, although typically there is concurrent thrombocytopenia with resultant increased bleeding time in advanced cirrhosis. This patient's age makes this diagnosis unlikely and his presentation is more consistent with an alternative diagnosis.

An increase in PT, PTT, and bleeding time is the hallmark of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). The platelet count in patients with DIC is usually also reduced due to rapid consumption (consumptive coagulopathy). DIC is often a result of trauma, shock, or a very severe underlying illness (e.g., sepsis). However, this patient's hemolytic anemia and oliguria following a dysentery-like illness suggest a different diagnosis.

An isolated increase in bleeding time can be seen with aspirin use, as well as in isolated platelet disorders such as Glanzmann thrombasthenia. Hemolytic anemia, acute kidney injury, and a history of dysentery-like illness are not consistent with aspirin use alone and a different set of findings is more likely.

An isolated increase in PTT can be seen with heparin administration, as it inhibits the action of thrombin and factor Xa by increasing the activity of antithrombin. Platelets are unaffected by heparin, except in the setting of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). This patient has no reported history of heparin use, however, and his presentation and history suggest another diagnosis.

question_text: A 72-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 2-week history of worsening shortness of breath, lower extremity swelling, and a 3-kg (6.6-lb) weight gain. Crackles are heard on auscultation of the chest. Cardiac examination shows a dull, low-pitched early diastolic sound at the 5^th left intercostal space that becomes louder in the left lateral decubitus position at end-expiration. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these auscultation findings?
content_preview: A 72-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 2-week history of worsening shortness of breath, lower extremity swelling, and a 3-kg (6.6-lb) weight gain. Crackles are heard on auscultation of the chest. Cardiac examination shows a dull, low-pitched early diastolic sound at the 5th left intercostal space that becomes louder in the left lateral decubitus position at end-expiration. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these auscultation findings?
hint: The patient presents with clinical features of heart failure (shortness of breath, crackles, lower extremity swelling, weight gain); the early diastolic heart sound is S_3, a strong predictor for heart failure.
learning_objective: Recognize the clinical features of heart failure, and recall the cause of a third heart sound (S3).

answers.explanation_why: Decreased myocardial compliance is the cause of the S_4 gallop, which is an important sign of heart failure with diastolic dysfunction or other conditions with reduced myocardial compliance (e.g., active ischemia, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy). However, in contrast to the auscultation findings in this patient, S_4 gallop is a late diastolic sound.

Heart failure due to systolic dysfunction is due to decreased, not increased, ventricular contractility. Increased ventricular contractility can be seen after myocardial hypertrophy and is a sign of a well-functioning heart.

Increased left ventricular end-systolic volume is the most likely cause of this patient's third heart sound (S_3). In heart failure with systolic dysfunction, the myocardium cannot effectively contract to empty during systole, resulting in ventricular volume overload. During the rapid ventricular filling phase, a sudden deceleration of blood occurs when the ventricle reaches its elastic limit, producing a third heart sound.

images.title: Anatomical locations and auscultatory sites for heart valves
images.description:
I–IV: anatomical locations of heart valves1. Aortic area: 2^nd right parasternal intercostal space (ICS)
- Ideal site for auscultation of aortic valve murmurs (1a). The murmur of aortic stenosis also radiates to the carotid arteries (1b).2. Pulmonary area: 2^nd left parasternal ICS
- Ideal site for auscultation of pulmonary valve murmurs3. Tricuspid area: 4^th left parasternal ICS
- Ideal site for auscultation of tricuspid valve murmurs4. Mitral area: 5^th left ICS in the midclavicular line (over the cardiac apex)
- Ideal site for auscultation of mitral valve murmurs (4a). The murmur of mitral regurgitation also radiates to the left axilla (4b).

answers.explanation_why: The left ventricular filling pressure would be decreased in a patient with hypovolemia. In this patient with features of heart failure, LV filling pressure would be increased.

answers.content: Increased capacity of the pulmonary circulation
answers.explanation_why: An increase in the capacity of the pulmonary circulation occurs during inspiration as a result of a decrease in intrathoracic pressure. This results in a split S_2 due to early closure of the aortic valve (A_2) and delayed closure of the pulmonary valve (P_2). However, it does not result in an S_3_, nor is it related to heart failure.

question_text: Two days after undergoing an emergency laparotomy following a motor vehicle collision, a 37-year-old man has increased thirst. Examination shows dry mucous membranes and decreased skin turgor. A review of his chart shows his urine output to be in excess of his fluid intake. Laboratory studies show a serum sodium concentration of 151 mEq/L and urine osmolality of 110 mOsmol/kg H_2O. One hour after the administration of desmopressin, the serum sodium concentration is 147 mEq/L and urine osmolality is 400 mOsmol/kg H_2O. One week later, his laboratory values are within normal limits. This patient's condition was most likely caused by damage to which of the following structures?
content_preview: Two days after undergoing an emergency laparotomy following a motor vehicle collision, a 37-year-old man has increased thirst. Examination shows dry mucous membranes and decreased skin turgor. A review of his chart shows his urine output to be in excess of his fluid intake. Laboratory studies show a serum sodium concentration of 151 mEq/L and urine osmolality of 110 mOsmol/kg H2O. One hour after the administration of desmopressin, the serum sodium concentration is 147 mEq/L and urine osmolality is 400 mOsmol/kg H2O. One week later, his laboratory values are within normal limits. This patient's condition was most likely caused by damage to which of the following structures?
hint: The features of increased thirst, polyuria, and hypernatremia suggest diabetes insipidus (DI). The change in urine osmolality after desmopressin administration can be used to identify the cause of DI.
learning_objective: Recognize central diabetes insipidus, and recall its association with damage to the posterior pituitary.

answers.explanation_why: Antidiuretic hormone (ADH) is produced in the hypothalamus (supraoptic nucleus and paraventricular nucleus). This hormone is then stored in, and subsequently released by, the posterior pituitary gland. Ischemia or direct damage (e.g., major surgery or head trauma) to the pituitary gland can affect ADH secretion and cause transient central DI. Features of central DI include polyuria, polydipsia, and increased serum osmolality in the presence of low urine osmolality. In the majority of cases, patients recover the ability to maintain serum osmolality, and ADH secretion is restored.

images.title: Pathophysiology of diabetes insipidus
images.description: The binding of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) to V2 receptors (R) promotes the insertion of aquaporin-2 channels into the apical cell membranes of principal cells in the renal collecting duct, thereby facilitating free water reabsorption and concentration of urine.In diabetes insipidus (DI), this mechanism is impaired either due to reduced pituitary ADH secretion (central DI) or defective renal ADH receptors (nephrogenic DI), in both cases reducing the insertion of aquaporin-2 channels. This impairs the ability of the kidneys to concentrate urine and results in the production of large amounts of dilute urine (up to 15 L/day).

answers.explanation_why: The adrenal cortex produces glucocorticoids and mineralocorticoids. Acute adrenal insufficiency can occur in the postoperative period (Addisonian crisis) because of ischemic adrenal damage. Furthermore, acute adrenal insufficiency can be transient, as seen here. However, adrenal insufficiency typically manifests with hypotension and hyponatremia, and this condition would be diagnosed with an ACTH stimulation test, not with desmopressin administration.

Damage to the proximal renal tubule can manifest with polyuria, which is seen in this patient. However, the polyuric phase typically follows an acute anuric phase, which is not described here. Furthermore, damage to the proximal tubule is not associated with a reversal of the changes in serum and urine osmolality after desmopressin administration.

Damage to the collecting duct can cause nephrogenic DI. This condition manifests with thirst, polyuria, and hypernatremia as seen in this patient. However, because nephrogenic DI is not responsive to desmopressin, its administration would not result in a reversal of the changes in serum and urine osmolality.

The supraoptic nucleus produces ADH. Damage to this nucleus leads to central DI, which can manifest with thirst, polyuria, and hypernatremia as seen in this patient. However, because the majority of ADH is produced in the supraoptic nucleus, damage to this structure typically leads to permanent DI, not a quick recovery (transient DI) like the one seen here.

question_text:
A 21-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by the police because of altered mental status. The police found him covering his ears and shouting near a highway rest area. Upon questioning, he was unable to look directly at the police and answer coherently. On the way to the hospital, he reported feeling nauseous and vomited twice. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 110/77 mm Hg. He is admitted to the hospital for evaluation. Three hours after admission, he has a tonic-clonic seizure. Laboratory studies show:

Serum

Na^+

140 mEq/L

Cl^-

102 mEq/L

Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:

On admission
Three hours later

pH
7.47
7.39

PaCO_2
24 mm Hg
31 mm Hg

PO_2

84 mm Hg
82 mm Hg

HCO_3^-
20 mEq/L
18 mEq/L

Which of the following is the most likely explanation of the patient's laboratory findings?
content_preview: A 21-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by the police because of altered mental status. The police found him covering his ears and shouting near a highway rest area. Upon questioning, he was unable to look directly at the police and answer coherently. On the way to the hospital, he reported feeling nauseous and vomited twice. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 110/77 mm Hg. He is admitted to the hospital for evaluation. Three hours after admission, he has a tonic-clonic seizure. Laboratory studies show: Serum Na+ 140 mEq/L Cl- 102 mEq/L Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows: On admission Three hours later pH 7.47 7.39 PaCO2 24 mm Hg 31 mm Hg PO2 84 mm Hg 82 mm Hg HCO3- 20 mEq/L 18 mEq/L Which of the following is the most likely explanation of the patient's laboratory findings?
hint: This patient initially had respiratory alkalosis on admission. The significant decrease in pH in combination with the decrease in HCO_3^- and an elevated anion gap (20 mEq/L) three hours later suggests metabolic acidosis. Since this patient's PaCO_2 (31 mm Hg) is lower than would be expected from normal respiratory compensation of metabolic acidosis (35 mm Hg ± 2 according to Winter's formula), this patient most likely has a mixed acid-base disorder.
learning_objective: Recognize salicylate toxicity.

answers.explanation_why: Opioid overdose may manifest with altered mental status and seizures, as seen here. However, it does not manifest with tachypnea and respiratory alkalosis, but with respiratory acidosis secondary to respiratory depression. Opioid overdose does not cause a mixed acid-base disorder and is associated with additional symptoms such as bilateral miosis, bradycardia, hypotension, and hypothermia, all of which are absent in this patient.

Salicylate toxicity from overdose with aspirin is the most likely explanation for this patient's presentation. In early toxicity, salicylates directly stimulate the medullary respiratory center and cause tachypnea and hyperpnea, both of which manifest with respiratory alkalosis. Later, the accumulation of organic acids (due to salicylates inhibiting citric acid cycle enzymes) causes a high anion gap metabolic acidosis, which leads to a mixed acid-base disorder. Features of salicylate toxicity include tinnitus, nausea, vomiting, mental status changes, hyperthermia (due to uncoupling of mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation), pulmonary edema, seizures, and, ultimately, coma.

Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) may manifest with altered mental status, seizures, nausea, vomiting, tachypnea, and high anion gap metabolic acidosis, as in this patient. However, DKA is not associated with a mixed acid-base disorder; instead, appropriate respiratory compensation for metabolic acidosis would be seen (resulting in Kussmaul breathing). Furthermore, DKA typically presents with additional symptoms such as polyuria, polydipsia, weight loss, signs of volume depletion, abdominal pain, and fruity odor of the breath, none of which are observed in this patient.

Recurrent vomiting can cause a significant loss of HCl, NaCl, and KCl, leading to a hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis, which can be further aggravated by hypovolemia (contraction alkalosis). This patient shows no loss of chloride and vomiting would not explain this patient's initial respiratory alkalosis or high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Acute adrenal insufficiency may manifest with impaired consciousness, fever, and vomiting, as observed in this patient. However, additional symptoms would include hypotension/shock and severe abdominal pain. Typical laboratory findings of acute adrenal insufficiency are hypoglycemia, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and normal anion gap metabolic acidosis, none of which are present here. Finally, acute adrenal insufficiency is not associated with a mixed acid-base disorder; instead, appropriate respiratory compensation for metabolic acidosis would be seen.

question_text:
A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance 30 minutes after being found unconscious on the street. On arrival, he is unresponsive to painful stimuli. His respirations are 5/min and shallow. Physical examination shows pinpoint pupils. Which of the following sets of findings would be expected on arterial blood analysis?

pH
PCO_2 (mm Hg)
HCO_3^- (mEq/L)

A
7.29
71
33

B
7.52
51
40

C
7.21
64
25

D
7.53
31
25

E
7.26
36
16
content_preview: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance 30 minutes after being found unconscious on the street. On arrival, he is unresponsive to painful stimuli. His respirations are 5/min and shallow. Physical examination shows pinpoint pupils. Which of the following sets of findings would be expected on arterial blood analysis? pH PCO2 (mm Hg) HCO3- (mEq/L) A 7.29 71 33 B 7.52 51 40 C 7.21 64 25 D 7.53 31 25 E 7.26 36 16
hint: This patient's presentation of decreased respiratory effort, constricted pupils, and unresponsiveness is consistent with opioid overdose.
learning_objective: Recognize opioid overdose, and recall its arterial blood gas findings.

answers.explanation_why:
Decreased pH and increased pCO_2 suggest a primary respiratory acidosis. The measured HCO_3^- (33 mEq/L) is consistent with a secondary metabolic alkalosis in the setting of primary acute respiratory acidosis because the measured HCO_3^- is more than what would be expected for acute respiratory acidosis (24 + [0.1 x (pCO_2  in mm Hg - 40)] +/- 3 = 24–30 mEq/L). Although this patient's presentation is consistent with acute respiratory acidosis due to an opioid overdose, there is, however, no history to suggest an additional metabolic alkalosis (e.g., diuretic use, severe vomiting).

The measured HCO_3^- is within the range of the expected HCO_3^- for a single chronic respiratory acidosis (24 + [0.4 x (pCO_2  in mm Hg - 40)] +/- 3 = 33–39 mEq/L) but the acute nature of an opioid overdose makes chronic respiratory acidosis unlikely.

This ABG analysis is consistent with primary metabolic alkalosis with respiratory compensation. Increased pH indicates alkalosis, while the increased bicarbonate (HCO_3^-) suggests a metabolic source (e.g., vomiting, nasogastric suction, diuretic use). Appropriate respiratory compensation via hypoventilation results in an elevated pCO_2. Although this patient presents with hypoventilation, there is no history to suggest a primary metabolic derangement.

This ABG analysis suggests acute respiratory acidosis, which is seen in an opioid overdose as a result of hypoventilation. Decreased pH indicates acidosis, increased pCO_2 suggests a respiratory source and, due to the acute nature of an opioid overdose, only minimal metabolic compensation from the rapid action of buffers in blood would be expected. In acute respiratory acidosis, for every 10 mm Hg increase in pCO_2 above 40 mm Hg, the HCO_3^- concentration increases by 1 mEq/L from 24 mEq/L with an expected variability of +/- 3 mEq/L. A slow-onset but more substantial compensation occurs as a result of renal acid-base handling in chronic respiratory acid-base disorders.

Differential diagnoses for acute respiratory acidosis in the emergency department setting include airway obstruction (e.g., foreign body aspiration, acute exacerbations of obstructive lung diseases), neuromuscular etiologies (e.g., Guillain-Barré syndrome, myasthenic crisis, botulism), and overdoses with other drugs that can cause CNS depression (e.g., benzodiazepines).

images.title: Acid-base nomogram
images.description: This nomogram can be used for the interpretation of an arterial blood gas analysis in the context of acid-base disorders.PCO_2 is on the x-axis and the concentration of HCO_3^- (cHCO_3^-) is on the y-axis; both are displayed logarithmically, allowing the pH to be displayed on parallel straight lines. The important areas for acid-base disorders are highlighted and labeled. The oval area in the middle around PCO_2 = 40 mm Hg and cHCO_3^- = 24 mEq/L represents the reference range.

answers.explanation_why: This ABG analysis is consistent with uncompensated respiratory alkalosis. Increased pH indicates alkalosis, while the decreased pCO_2 suggests a respiratory source (e.g., hyperventilation during a panic attack or in early salicylate overdose). Normal bicarbonate (HCO_3^-) indicates an acute scenario with negligent metabolic compensation. Although this patient does present with respiratory abnormality, his shallow respirations at 5/min indicate hypoventilation, as opposed to hyperventilation.

This ABG analysis suggests a combined metabolic acidosis and respiratory acidosis, which can occur in cardiopulmonary arrest. Decreased pH indicates acidosis, while reduced bicarbonate (HCO_3^-) suggests a metabolic source. This pCO_2 is higher than would be expected with respiratory compensation (by Winter formula), and therefore a primary respiratory acidosis is also expected. Although respiratory derangements would be expected as a result of this patient's opioid overdose, metabolic acid-base changes would be unlikely.

question_text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after he was found unconscious at home. He has no history of serious illness. He is suspected to have ingested one of his grandmother's medications as the door of the medicine cabinet was found open at home. His grandmother is receiving home hospice care for end-stage lung cancer. On arrival, the patient is somnolent but responsive when aroused. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 105/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations show no abnormalities. The neck is supple. Neurological examination shows slurred speech, diminished deep tendon reflexes bilaterally, and an ataxic gait. Muscle tone is decreased and muscle strength is 3/5 throughout. Sensation is intact bilaterally and cranial nerves are grossly intact. The pupils are 4 mm and reactive to light; there is horizontal gaze-evoked nystagmus. Which of the following treatments is most likely to reverse this patient’s symptoms?
content_preview: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after he was found unconscious at home. He has no history of serious illness. He is suspected to have ingested one of his grandmother's medications as the door of the medicine cabinet was found open at home. His grandmother is receiving home hospice care for end-stage lung cancer. On arrival, the patient is somnolent but responsive when aroused. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 105/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations show no abnormalities. The neck is supple. Neurological examination shows slurred speech, diminished deep tendon reflexes bilaterally, and an ataxic gait. Muscle tone is decreased and muscle strength is 3/5 throughout. Sensation is intact bilaterally and cranial nerves are grossly intact. The pupils are 4 mm and reactive to light; there is horizontal gaze-evoked nystagmus. Which of the following treatments is most likely to reverse this patient’s symptoms?
hint: Benzodiazepines are used in palliative care for the management of common end-of-life symptoms such as anxiety, insomnia, and dyspnea. The effects of benzodiazepine toxicity are similar to those of severe ethanol intoxication and include CNS depression, hypotonia, hyporeflexia, and signs of cerebellar ataxia (e.g., ataxic gait, nystagmus, slurred speech). The pupils remain unaffected by benzodiazepine toxicity.
learning_objective: Recognize benzodiazepine toxicity, and choose the appropriate antidote.

answers.explanation_why: Physostigmine is used to treat anticholinergic toxicity caused by drugs that are purely muscarinic antagonists (e.g., atropine, scopolamine, glycopyrrolate). These medications are used in end-of-life care (e.g., to reduce airway secretions in patients with noisy breathing, to decrease gastrointestinal secretions in patients with malignant bowel obstruction). Although anticholinergic toxicity can cause an altered mental status and occasionally ataxia, patients with this condition would have other features such as tachycardia, mydriasis, and hyperthermia.

Flumazenil, a competitive GABA receptor antagonist, rapidly reverses the effects of benzodiazepines. However, flumazenil can precipitate seizures in patients who have a seizure disorder, have coingested a proconvulsive substance, or are on chronic benzodiazepine therapy (by inducing benzodiazepine withdrawal). Therefore, flumazenil is only used to treat benzodiazepine toxicity in patients who are benzodiazepine-naive (e.g., accidental ingestion in children, reversal of toxicity from procedural sedation) or have severe respiratory depression. Note that benzodiazepine toxicity very rarely leads to severe respiratory depression unless associated with the coingestion of other CNS depressants such as alcohol, opioids, barbiturates, and first-generation antihistamines (e.g., diphenhydramine).

Cyproheptadine is used to treat serotonin syndrome, which can be caused by certain medications used for palliative care such as tramadol, ondansetron, and antidepressants. While serotonin syndrome can manifest with altered mental status, this condition does not result in ataxia, hypotonia, or hyporeflexia. Instead, features such as tachycardia, hyperthermia, hypertonia, and hyperreflexia would be expected.

Sodium bicarbonate can be used to treat severe metabolic acidosis (e.g., ethylene glycol poisoning), counter the effect of cardiotoxic drugs with sodium channel-blocking properties (e.g., tricyclic antidepressants), and hasten the removal of drugs that are acidic and eliminated via urine (e.g., barbiturates, salicylates). Benzodiazepines are weak bases that neither cause metabolic acidosis nor block sodium channels, and are predominantly eliminated by hepatic metabolism. Sodium bicarbonate does not reverse the effects of benzodiazepines.

Dextrose reverses the effects of hypoglycemia, which is an important differential diagnosis that should be excluded in any patient with somnolence or neurological deficits. This patient, however, lacks the characteristic autonomic features of hypoglycemia such as tachycardia and diaphoresis, and has a presentation consistent with benzodiazepine toxicity, the effects of which cannot be reversed with dextrose. Dextrose is useful to treat toxicity caused by insulin, insulin secretagogues (e.g., sulfonylureas, meglitinides), or beta blockers.

Naloxone, a competitive μ-opioid receptor antagonist, is indicated if opioid intoxication is suspected. Opioids are commonly used in palliative care to manage pain and end-of-life dyspnea. While opioid intoxication can manifest with an altered mental status, ataxia is not expected with this condition. Instead, features such as miosis and respiratory depression would be present.

In a patient with benzodiazepine toxicity, naloxone is administered empirically only if the patient has respiratory depression. This step is not done to reverse the effects of benzodiazepines but to treat a possible coingestion of opiates.

question_text:
An 82-year-old man is brought to the emergency department from a nursing home with altered mental status. According to his caretaker, he was disoriented and was shouting obscenities at his co-residents. Over the past two days, he has had foul-smelling urine. His temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg. He is oriented to person but not to place or time. His extremities are warm and dry. Other than a weak pulse, cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. Placement of a foley catheter yields cloudy urine with a foul odor. This patient is most likely to have which of the following hemodynamic profiles?

Cardiac output (CO)
Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP)
Systemic vascular resistance (SVR)
Central venous pressure (CVP)

A
Decreased
decreased
increased
decreased

B
Decreased
decreased
decreased
decreased

C
Decreased
increased
increased
increased

D
Increased
decreased
decreased
decreased

E
Increased
increased
increased
increased
content_preview: An 82-year-old man is brought to the emergency department from a nursing home with altered mental status. According to his caretaker, he was disoriented and was shouting obscenities at his co-residents. Over the past two days, he has had foul-smelling urine. His temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg. He is oriented to person but not to place or time. His extremities are warm and dry. Other than a weak pulse, cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. Placement of a foley catheter yields cloudy urine with a foul odor. This patient is most likely to have which of the following hemodynamic profiles? Cardiac output (CO) Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) Systemic vascular resistance (SVR) Central venous pressure (CVP) A Decreased decreased increased decreased B Decreased decreased decreased decreased C Decreased increased increased increased D Increased decreased decreased decreased E Increased increased increased increased
hint: This patient's cloudy, foul-smelling urine, tachycardia, and hypotension suggest septic shock. Infection should always be considered as a cause of altered mental status in an older patient.
learning_objective: Recognize septic shock, and recall its hemodynamic findings.

answers.explanation_why: This profile suggests hypovolemic shock. Hemorrhage is the most common cause of hypovolemic shock (often referred to as hemorrhagic shock). To maintain tissue perfusion, there is compensatory tachycardia and an increase in SVR. Despite these responses, there is an overall decrease in CVP, PCWP, and reduced stroke volume and cardiac output. On physical examination, these patients typically have cold and clammy skin. The patient described here has no history that suggests significant blood loss.

This profile suggests the late stage of septic shock. Although this patient has features suggestive of septic shock, the presence of warm skin is not consistent with the decreased cardiac output seen in the late stage of septic shock; in the late stage, cold, pale skin is expected. This profile can also be consistent with neurogenic shock, which is a form of distributive shock that manifests with vasodilation and reduced SVR, as well as relative bradycardia and decreased cardiac output. Without a history or evidence of significant head, neck, or spine trauma, this cause is very unlikely to explain the patient's presentation.

This profile suggests cardiogenic shock, which results from any process that significantly decreases cardiac output. It is generally characterized either as obstructive shock (due to cardiac tamponade, massive pulmonary embolism, tension pneumothorax, etc.) or nonobstructive shock (due to acute myocardial infarction, acute heart failure, arrhythmia, valvular heart disease, etc.). In response to the decrease in cardiac output, there is an increase in SVR. Poor forward flow leads to increases in PCWP and CVP. In cardiogenic shock, patients typically have cold, clammy skin on examination. This patient has no history or examination findings that suggest a cardiogenic cause of his presentation.

This profile suggests distributive shock, which is a collective term for shock that results in pathologic vasodilation, leading to decreased SVR. The most common cause is septic shock (in this case likely due to urinary tract infection), but it can also be caused by neurogenic shock or anaphylactic shock. Circulating cytokines and bacterial toxins cause pathologic vasodilation and lead to decreased SVR (afterload), as well as decreased CVP and PCWP (preload). Consequently, there is an increase in heart rate aimed at increasing cardiac output. Patients with septic shock often have warm, flushed skin as a result of this pathophysiology. In the late stage of septic shock, there may be a decrease in cardiac output; therefore, patients may present with cold, pale skin with a delayed capillary refill (see “Overview of the types of shock” table).

The most important initial steps in the management of septic shock are measurement of serum lactate, early administration of empiric antibiotic therapy after blood cultures have been obtained, aggressive fluid resuscitation with crystalloids, and additional vasopressor therapy in patients who are refractory to intravenous fluid management (hour-1 bundle for sepsis).

This hemodynamic profile is most consistent with an increase in overall sympathetic tone, such as secondary to sympathomimetic drug ingestion or illicit drug use (cocaine, amphetamines, etc.). This patient's presentation and vital signs are not consistent with this hemodynamic profile, as he does not have evidence of hypertension but is hypotensive on examination.

question_text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of progressive shortness of breath, difficulty speaking, and diffuse, colicky abdominal pain for the past 3 hours. Yesterday he underwent a tooth extraction. His father and a paternal uncle have a history of repeated hospitalizations for upper airway and orofacial swelling. The patient takes no medications. His blood pressure is 112/62 mm Hg. Examination shows edematous swelling of the lips, tongue, arms, and legs; there is no rash. Administration of a drug targeting which of the following mechanisms of action is most appropriate for this patient?
content_preview: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of progressive shortness of breath, difficulty speaking, and diffuse, colicky abdominal pain for the past 3 hours. Yesterday he underwent a tooth extraction. His father and a paternal uncle have a history of repeated hospitalizations for upper airway and orofacial swelling. The patient takes no medications. His blood pressure is 112/62 mm Hg. Examination shows edematous swelling of the lips, tongue, arms, and legs; there is no rash. Administration of a drug targeting which of the following mechanisms of action is most appropriate for this patient?
hint: This patient presents with abdominal pain, swelling of the extremities (without hives or pruritus), and dyspnea secondary to edema of the lips and tongue after a triggering incident (dental work). These findings, together with a family history of recurrent orofacial swelling, are indicative of hereditary angioedema (HAE), a disease caused by deficiency or dysfunction of C1 inhibitor.
learning_objective: Recognize hereditary angioedema, and recall its treatment targets.

answers.explanation_why: Antihistamines are used to treat patients presenting with mast cell-mediated angioedema (without anaphylaxis). Although this patient's significant orofacial swelling could be due to mast cell-mediated angioedema, it is more often associated with significant pruritus and hives, which are noticeably absent here. Antihistamines are primarily used for treating pruritus and urticaria and would not benefit this patient.
Attenuated androgens (e.g., danazol) are effective therapies for long-term prophylaxis in patients with HAE. However, they are not useful in treating acute attacks.

The autosomal dominant defect in patients with HAE causes a deficiency or dysfunction of C1 inhibitor, which physiologically suppresses steps in the complement pathways and inactivates kallikrein. Because kallikrein normally converts kininogen to bradykinin, increased levels of kallikrein lead to a buildup of bradykinin, with resultant vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, and eventual angioedema. First-line therapies for HAE focus on antagonizing the bradykinin B2 receptor (icatibant), replacing the defective enzyme with intravenous injection of purified C1-INH, or preventing further generation of bradykinin with a kallikrein inhibitor (ecallantide).

Trauma, dental work, and mental or physical stress are common triggers for these acute attacks.

images.title: Bradykinin-mediated angioedema
images.description: Bradykinin-mediated angioedema is triggered by increased levels of the proinflammatory vasodilator bradykinin, which can build up via several different mechanisms.Top left: The rare hereditary angioedema (HAE) type III (normal levels and function of C1-INH) can be caused by several different gene mutations; illustrated here is a mutation resulting in increased Factor XII activity, which leads to increased bradykinin generation.Center left: In HAE type I (low levels of normal C1-INH), HAE type II (normal or high levels of dysfunctional C1-INHI), and acquired angioedema (acquired low levels of C1-INH), the normal inhibitory function of C1-INH on the kallikrein-kinin system is reduced, resulting in increased bradykinin generation.Bottom left: In ACE inhibitor-induced angioedema, reduced bradykinin breakdown due to inhibition of ACE results in the build-up of bradykinin.C1-INH: C1 inhibitor; ACE: angiotensin-converting enzyme; HMWK: high-molecular-weight kininogen; HAE: hereditary angioedema

answers.explanation_why:
The use of angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors is absolutely contraindicated in a patient with HAE. ACE inhibitors prevent ACE from degrading the already elevated bradykinin and also lead to lower levels of angiotensin II, which normally acts to inhibit bradykinin synthesis.

ACE inhibitors are the most common cause of acquired angioedema.

Glucocorticoids are an appropriate treatment for patients presenting with mast cell-mediated angioedema (without anaphylaxis). While this could explain this patient's significant orofacial swelling, the lack of significant pruritus or hives makes it highly unlikely. Glucocorticoids are ineffective in the context of HAE.

answers.content: Agonist at alpha and beta-adrenergic receptors
answers.explanation_why: Epinephrine, a dual α and β-adrenergic agonist, is the first-line treatment for anaphylaxis associated with allergic or mast cell-mediated angioedema. Abdominal pain can also occur in some cases of anaphylaxis, most commonly with a known food allergen. However, anaphylaxis usually has an acute onset (within minutes to hours of exposure to an antigen), is rapidly progressive, and would present with additional system involvement (hypotension, pruritus, and hives). Epinephrine does not improve airway-associated symptoms in acute angioedema attacks in patients with HAE.

question_text: A 55-year-old woman loses consciousness in the emergency department one hour after being admitted to the hospital for sharp, acute chest pain and diaphoresis. There are no palpable pulses. Chest compressions are started. Medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and breast cancer that was surgically treated 4 years ago. Prior to admission, the patient was on a long bus ride to visit her sister. Her medications include tamoxifen, atorvastatin, metoprolol, metformin, and insulin. The cardiac rhythm is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 55-year-old woman loses consciousness in the emergency department one hour after being admitted to the hospital for sharp, acute chest pain and diaphoresis. There are no palpable pulses. Chest compressions are started. Medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and breast cancer that was surgically treated 4 years ago. Prior to admission, the patient was on a long bus ride to visit her sister. Her medications include tamoxifen, atorvastatin, metoprolol, metformin, and insulin. The cardiac rhythm is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The absence of pulses in this patient indicates cardiac arrest. The presence of a sinus rhythm on the cardiac monitor suggests pulseless electrical activity (PEA).
learning_objective: Recognize pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest, and choose the most appropriate medication in cardiac arrest management.

answers.explanation_why: Intravenous glucagon is recommended for patients with suspected beta blocker toxicity. Although this patient takes metoprolol and has some features of beta blocker toxicity (e.g., hypotension, bradycardia), the absence of PR interval prolongation is inconsistent with beta blocker toxicity. Other features, such as wheezing or seizures, are also not present. Regardless of the underlying etiology, she is currently in PEA arrest and requires a different emergent therapy.

Defibrillation is indicated for patients with cardiac arrest due to ventricular tachycardia (usually appearing as a wide-complex, regular tachycardia) or ventricular fibrillation (usually appearing as a wide-complex, irregular tachycardia). Defibrillation is not recommended for patients in PEA arrest.

Acute myocardial infarction is an important cause of cardiac arrest, and coronary angiography should be considered once the patient is resuscitated. While evaluating the underlying cause of this patient's arrest will eventually be important, she is too unstable to undergo coronary angioplasty.

The next best step for this patient in PEA arrest is administration of epinephrine (given as 1 mg IV, and repeated every 3–5 minutes while continuing CPR). PEA arrest is characterized by continued electrical activity within the cardiac conduction system (as seen in this patient with sinus rhythm on the cardiac monitor) but inadequate cardiac output to support tissue perfusion. For this reason, PEA arrest is considered a nonshockable rhythm. High-quality chest compressions and IV epinephrine are vital aspects of management.

IV amiodarone is a second-line agent used in patients with cardiac arrest due to ventricular tachycardia or ventricular fibrillation who have not responded to first-line strategies (e.g., epinephrine, defibrillation). It is administered as a 300 mg bolus and an additional 150 mg dose can be given 3–5 minutes later. Amiodarone is not recommended for patients in PEA arrest.

Therapeutic hypothermia is recommended when there is impaired mental status (e.g., not following commands, no purposeful movements) after the return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC) has been achieved in a patient with cardiac arrest. It has been shown to improve neurological outcomes in post-cardiac arrest patients and is recommended for at least 24 hours. Hypothermia therapy is not indicated for this patient who has not yet achieved ROSC.

Although hypoglycemia is not a typical cause of PEA arrest, it is common postarrest (along with other metabolic derangements). Therefore, this patient's serum glucose should be closely monitored after resuscitation. However, she currently lacks a perfusing blood pressure (as evidenced by her lack of pulse and mental status), which requires a different emergent intervention at this time.

images.title: Sinus bradycardia
images.description:
ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)– Regular sinus rhythm with a heart rate of 37/min
– PR interval normal (∼ 160 ms), QRS normal (∼ 110 ms), QT interval normal (∼ 480 ms; QTc = 380 ms)
– Morphologies of P wave, QRS complex, and T wave are physiologic. Note the U waves (occurring after the T waves).
– No signs of ischemia

question_text:
A 60-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of recurrent episodes of fatigue, palpitations, nausea, and diaphoresis. The episodes have become more frequent over the past 2 weeks and he has missed work several times because of them. His symptoms usually improve after he drinks some juice and rests. He has had a 2-kg (4.5-lb) weight gain in the past 6 months. He has a history of hypertension and asthma. His sister has type 2 diabetes mellitus. content_preview: A 60-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of recurrent episodes of fatigue, palpitations, nausea, and diaphoresis. The episodes have become more frequent over the past 2 weeks and he has missed work several times because of them. His symptoms usually improve after he drinks some juice and rests. He has had a 2-kg (4.5-lb) weight gain in the past 6 months. He has a history of hypertension and asthma. His sister has type 2 diabetes mellitus. His medications include hydrochlorothiazide, aspirin, and a budesonide inhaler. His temperature is 36.3°C (97.3°F), pulse is 92/min and regular, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 118/65 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show: Na+ 145 mEq/L K+ 3.9 mEq/L Cl- 103 mEq/L Calcium 9.2 mg/dL Glucose 88 mg/dL Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
hint: This patient's episodes of palpitations, nausea, fatigue, and diaphoresis that improve with the consumption of sugar (e.g., by drinking juice) should raise concern for episodic hypoglycemia.
learning_objective: Recognize episodic hypoglycemia, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why: An oral glucose tolerance test is used to diagnose diabetes mellitus and impaired glucose tolerance in patients with insulin resistance. Oral glucose tolerance testing was previously used to evaluate postprandial hypoglycemia. However, it has not been proven effective at evaluating spontaneous fasting hypoglycemia and would not be the appropriate next step for episodic hypoglycemia.

A 24-hour urine catecholamine test is used to diagnose pheochromocytoma, which can cause episodes of palpitations and diaphoresis. However, because this patient's symptoms improve with glucose administration, they are consistent with episodic hypoglycemia, which is not typically seen in patients with pheochromocytoma.

A dexamethasone suppression test is a screening test for Cushing syndrome, which could explain this patient's weight gain and fatigue. However, Cushing syndrome more commonly causes hyperglycemia, as opposed to the features of hypoglycemic episodes seen in this patient. Other clinical features associated with hypercortisolism include central and neck obesity, easy bruising, striae, and proximal muscle weakness, none of which are present in this patient.

Symptoms of spontaneous episodic hypoglycemia and symptom resolution upon administration of glucose are two components of the Whipple triad. If hypoglycemia is not present at the time of evaluation, a 72-hour fasting test can be conducted to reproduce hypoglycemic symptoms and reach a definitive diagnosis. Glucose and hypoglycemic studies, including measurement of insulin, C-peptide, proinsulin, and β-hydroxybutyrate, should be obtained at the beginning of the test and then repeated every 6 hours until the serum glucose falls below 60 mg/dL. C-peptide and proinsulin are measures of the endogenous production of insulin and are decreased in hypoglycemia; hypoglycemia with elevated C-peptide and proinsulin levels should raise concern for insulinoma.

A corticotropin stimulation test is the gold standard for diagnosing primary adrenal insufficiency. While primary adrenal insufficiency can manifest with nausea, fatigue, and hypoglycemia due to decreased levels of cortisol, it would typically also lead to hypotension. Moreover, adrenal insufficiency is more commonly associated with weight loss rather than weight gain.

question_text:
A 59-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of a 3-day history of worsening shortness of breath. He has a history of long-standing hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include enalapril, amlodipine, and metformin. His wife reports that he only takes his medications every second or third day. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. He stopped drinking alcohol 3 years ago. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.9°F), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 167/95 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. Pulmonary examination is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
Video
content_preview: A 59-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of a 3-day history of worsening shortness of breath. He has a history of long-standing hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include enalapril, amlodipine, and metformin. His wife reports that he only takes his medications every second or third day. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. He stopped drinking alcohol 3 years ago. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.9°F), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 167/95 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. Pulmonary examination is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Video
hint: Auscultation reveals bibasilar coarse crackles.
learning_objective: Recognize acute decompensated heart failure presenting with pulmonary edema, and choose the initial management.

answers.explanation_why: Oral metoprolol can be used in the treatment of hypertension, especially in patients with concomitant heart failure. However, metoprolol should be avoided in patients with acute decompensated heart failure, which this patient most likely has, as this drug decreases myocardial contractility, resulting in left ventricular dysfunction and further worsening of pulmonary edema.

Inhaled albuterol and corticosteroids are typically indicated in patients with respiratory distress due to obstructive lung disease (e.g., asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease). This type of condition manifests with wheezing and rhonchi, not the bibasilar lung crackles heard in this patient.

This patient presents with respiratory distress (acute dyspnea, hypoxemia) and bibasilar crackles on pulmonary auscultation. In conjunction with his history of long-standing, poorly controlled hypertension, these findings indicate pulmonary edema due to acute decompensated heart failure (ADHF). As this patient is hemodynamically stable, management includes oxygen supplementation, proper positioning (raising the head of the bed), and intravenous loop diuretics such as furosemide. Diuresis results in a decrease in intravascular volume, thereby reducing the cardiac preload, central venous pressure, and pulmonary capillary wedge pressure, which, in turn, reduces pulmonary edema. Furthermore, in patients with pulmonary edema, furosemide causes transient venodilation, further reducing pulmonary congestion, even before the onset of diuresis. If respiratory distress persists, treatment with vasodilators for ADHF (e.g., nitroglycerin) may be initiated to further reduce preload.

For the appropriate management of ADHF, think LMNOP: Loop diuretics (furosemide), Modify medications, Nitrates, Oxygen if hypoxic, Position (with elevated upper body).

Chest tube placement is indicated in patients with pneumothorax, hemothorax, or pleural effusion. Although this patient presents with symptoms associated with these conditions (dyspnea, hypoxemia), auscultation would typically reveal decreased breath sounds rather than the bibasilar crackles heard in this patient.

Antibiotics may be indicated for patients with respiratory distress due to pneumonia. This condition, however, typically manifests with unilateral crackles, fever, pleuritic chest pain, and productive cough rather than the bibasilar lung crackles that are heard in this patient.

Intravenous corticosteroids are administered in patients with respiratory distress due to acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (AECOPD). Although this patient has a long-standing smoking history, which puts him at increased risk for COPD, auscultation would reveal wheezing or rhonchi, not the bibasilar lung crackles heard here. AECOPD classically manifests with increasing frequency or severity of cough, and/or increasing volume or purulence of sputum.

question_text: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being rescued from a burning house. On arrival, she is obtunded. Her pulse is 132/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 88/52 mm Hg. She is at the 72^nd percentile for height (125 cm) and the 70^th percentile for weight (25 kg). Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Examination shows erythematous burn wounds with fluid-filled vesicles and bullae that cover 30% of the body surface area. The burn wounds blanch on applying pressure. There is mild stridor heard at the lung bases bilaterally. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. There is no pharyngeal edema or soot in the nostrils. Peripheral pulses are palpable bilaterally. She is intubated and mechanical ventilation with 40% oxygen is begun. Urinary catheterization is performed. Laboratory studies are within the reference ranges. Two large-bore intravenous catheters are inserted and fluid resuscitation with lactated Ringer's solution is begun. In addition to fluid resuscitation for replacement of ongoing fluid loss, which of the following is the most appropriate maintenance fluid resuscitation regimen?
content_preview: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being rescued from a burning house. On arrival, she is obtunded. Her pulse is 132/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 88/52 mm Hg. She is at the 72nd percentile for height (125 cm) and the 70th percentile for weight (25 kg). Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Examination shows erythematous burn wounds with fluid-filled vesicles and bullae that cover 30% of the body surface area. The burn wounds blanch on applying pressure. There is mild stridor heard at the lung bases bilaterally. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. There is no pharyngeal edema or soot in the nostrils. Peripheral pulses are palpable bilaterally. She is intubated and mechanical ventilation with 40% oxygen is begun. Urinary catheterization is performed. Laboratory studies are within the reference ranges. Two large-bore intravenous catheters are inserted and fluid resuscitation with lactated Ringer's solution is begun. In addition to fluid resuscitation for replacement of ongoing fluid loss, which of the following is the most appropriate maintenance fluid resuscitation regimen?
hint: This child with second-degree burns that cover 30% of the total body surface area needs urgent fluid resuscitation, preferably with a balanced electrolyte solution. In pediatric burn patients, the amount of fluid that has to be administered over the first 24 hours is calculated as follows: 3 mL × % total body surface area affected by nonsuperficial burns × body weight. In addition, all children < 30 kg should receive maintenance fluids according to the 4-2-1 rule (4 mL/kg/h for the first 10 kg + 2 mL/kg/h for the next 10 kg + 1 mL/kg/h for the remaining weight).
learning_objective: Choose the appropriate maintenance fluid resuscitation regimen for pediatric burn patients.

answers.content: 65 mL/h of 5% dextrose in lactated Ringer's
answers.explanation_why: Lactated Ringer's solution (LR) is the crystalloid of choice for fluid resuscitation and replacement of ongoing losses in burn patients because it closely resembles extracellular fluid. The lactate in LR also reduces the incidence of metabolic acidosis. The formula used to estimate the daily fluid requirement for the replacement of ongoing fluid loss in this 25 kg child < 14 years old with 30% second-degree burns is: 2250 mL (3 mL x 30 x 25 = 2250 mL) during the first 24 hours. Children < 30 kg should receive an additional sugar-containing solution. Using the 4-2-1 formula, the maintenance rate for this solution is: 65 mL/h (4 x 10 = 40 mL/h + 2 x 10 = 20 mL/h + 1 x 5 = 5 mL/h = 65 mL/h). Therefore, this patient should receive maintenance fluid resuscitation with 5% dextrose in LR at a rate of 65 mL/h.

Although albumin solution is a powerful intravascular volume expander, it is not recommended for fluid resuscitation in burn patients because it is expensive and provides no additional benefits when crystalloids are in use. Moreover, albumin solution is not suitable for ongoing fluid loss replacement or maintenance fluid therapy.

answers.content: 25 mL/h of 5% dextrose in lactated Ringer's
answers.explanation_why: A rate of 25 mL/h would not meet this patient's maintenance fluid requirement and may result in hypovolemia. The maintenance fluid requirement for this 25 kg child should be calculated according to the 4-2-1 formula.

answers.content: 140 mL/h of 5% dextrose in lactated Ringer's
answers.explanation_why: According to the formula used to estimate the daily fluid requirement for the replacement of ongoing fluid loss in this 25 kg child with 30% second-degree burns, this patient should be administered 2250 mL of a balanced electrolyte solution during the first 24 hours. One-half of this total fluid requirement is administered during the first 8 hours (at 140 mL/h) and the other half is administered during the next 16 hours. This rate of fluid administration, while sufficient during the first 8 hours to replace ongoing fluid loss, is inappropriate for this child's maintenance fluid requirements.

Although albumin solution is a powerful intravascular volume expander, it is not recommended for fluid resuscitation in burn patients because it is expensive and provides no additional benefit when crystalloids are in use. Moreover, albumin solution is not suitable for ongoing fluid loss replacement or maintenance fluid therapy.

Although normal saline is extremely effective in increasing extracellular fluid, it is not a balanced crystalloid solution, which would be more suitable for ongoing fluid loss replacement in patients with burns. Also, administering large amounts of normal saline can result in hyperchloremic acidosis, which may worsen acidemia in burn patients.

Although normal saline is extremely effective in increasing extracellular fluid, it is not a balanced crystalloid solution, which would be more suitable for ongoing fluid loss replacement in patients with burns. Also, administering large amounts of normal saline can result in hyperchloremic acidosis, which may worsen acidemia in burn patients.

Although albumin solution is a powerful plasma expander, albumin is not recommended for fluid resuscitation in burn patients because it is expensive and provides no additional benefit when crystalloids are in use. Moreover, albumin solution is not suitable for ongoing fluid loss replacement or maintenance fluid therapy.

Although normal saline is extremely effective in increasing extracellular fluid, it is not a balanced crystalloid solution, which would be more suitable for ongoing fluid loss replacement in patients with burns. Also, administering large amounts of normal saline can result in hyperchloremic acidosis, which may worsen acidemia in burn patients.

question_text: A 28-year-old research assistant is brought to the emergency department for severe chemical burns 30 minutes after accidentally spilling hydrochloric acid on himself. The burns cover both hands and forearms. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 108/82 mm Hg. Initial stabilization and resuscitation is begun, including respiratory support, fluid resuscitation, and cardiovascular stabilization. The burned skin is irrigated with saline water to remove the chemical agent. Which of the following is the most appropriate method to verify adequate fluid infusion in this patient?
content_preview: A 28-year-old research assistant is brought to the emergency department for severe chemical burns 30 minutes after accidentally spilling hydrochloric acid on himself. The burns cover both hands and forearms. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 108/82 mm Hg. Initial stabilization and resuscitation is begun, including respiratory support, fluid resuscitation, and cardiovascular stabilization. The burned skin is irrigated with saline water to remove the chemical agent. Which of the following is the most appropriate method to verify adequate fluid infusion in this patient?
hint: The most important goal of IV fluid resuscitation is to maintain end-organ perfusion while avoiding fluid overload.
learning_objective: Recognize the goal of IV fluid resuscitation in burn patients, and recall the method to verify adequate fluid infusion.

answers.explanation_why: Tachycardia is a common early sign of hypovolemia. However, the heart rate is of minimal utility in assessing fluid resuscitation because even adequately resuscitated burn patients may be mildly tachycardic, likely due to stress hormone (e.g., catecholamine) release.

The Parkland formula is a tool commonly used to estimate fluid requirements during the first 24 hours of care in burn patients. While this is a good tool for estimating this patient's initial fluid requirements, it is merely an estimate. Another method can more accurately verify if fluid resuscitation is adequate. In addition, because of studies demonstrating serious complications from over-resuscitation (e.g., pleural effusions, compartment syndrome), the ATLS and American Burn Association now recommend only giving half of the fluid resuscitation volume that is calculated by the Parkland formula in adults.

The Holliday-Segar formula may be used to estimate maintenance fluid requirements. However, the fluid requirement of patients with burns during the first 24 hours far exceeds the estimate provided by the Holliday-Segar formula. A different method is therefore required to assess adequate fluid requirement during the first 24 hours.

Sphygmomanometric blood pressure monitoring in a burned limb is unreliable, as edema of the area does not allow for the accurate auscultation of Korotkoff sounds. Blood pressure is therefore underestimated. If more fluid were administered to the patient based on a misinterpretation of blood pressure, edema in the limb would worsen, and the risk of pulmonary edema would increase. Also, blood pressure may be normal despite decreased intravascular fluid volume and end-organ perfusion in a patient with an intact vasomotor response and would only begin to decrease once shock sets in. Even intraarterial manometry may be unreliable because of peripheral vasoconstriction by stress hormones (e.g., catecholamines).

Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) may be increased in patients with burns during the initial 12–18 hours as a result of cardiac dysfunction. However, PCWP should not be used to verify if the infused fluid volume is adequate because PCWP is also not a reliable indicator of end-organ perfusion.

Central venous pressure (CVP) should not be used to verify the adequacy of fluid volume infusion, since a decrease in CVP is a relatively late sign of intravascular volume depletion in patients with intact vasomotor reflexes. CVP is thus not a reliable measure of end-organ perfusion.

Urine output is a good indicator of kidney perfusion, which is an indicator of overall organ perfusion. Maintaining organ perfusion is the primary goal of IV fluid therapy in burn patients. Initially, the approximate volume of fluid required may be estimated (e.g., based on the total body surface area involved), however, this is merely a starting point, and IV fluid volume should be titrated to maintain a urine output of 0.5 mL/kg/h in adults (1 mL/kg/h in children). Although heart rate and blood pressure should be monitored in patients with burns, these parameters are not good indicators of overall organ perfusion. If urine output falls below 0.5 mL/kg/h, a 500–1000 mL bolus of crystalloid fluid should be given, and the maintenance infusion rate should be increased by 20–30%.

question_text:
A 31-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of weakness and abdominal pain for the past day. Since this morning, he has also had nausea and two episodes of vomiting. He has type 1 diabetes mellitus and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include insulin and atorvastatin, although he admits that he has not taken his medication for the past few days. He appears drowsy. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.4°F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 29/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes and decreased skin turgor. He has a fruity odor to his breath. Abdominal examination shows epigastric tenderness with no guarding or rebound. Since this morning, he has also had nausea and two episodes of vomiting. He has type 1 diabetes mellitus and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include insulin and atorvastatin, although he admits that he has not taken his medication for the past few days. He appears drowsy. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.4°F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 29/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes and decreased skin turgor. He has a fruity odor to his breath. Abdominal examination shows epigastric tenderness with no guarding or rebound. Bowel sounds are normal. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 14.3 g/dL Leukocyte count 11,300/mm3 Platelet count 230,000/mm3 Serum Na+ 135 mEq/L K+ 5.1 mEq/L Urea nitrogen 15 mg/dL Glucose 435 mg/dL Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL Which of the following sets of arterial blood gas findings would most likely be found in this patient? pH pCO2 (mm Hg) Cl- (mEq/L) HCO3- (mEq/L) A 7.10 50 108 15 B 7.50 29 98 22 C 7.30 32 114 15 D 7.41 39 102 26 E 7.24 22 98 9 F 7.61 48 97 47
hint: A urine dipstick test in this patient would be positive for ketones. The anion gap = [Na^+] - ([Cl^-] + [HCO_3^-]).
learning_objective: Recognize diabetic ketoacidosis, and recall its arterial blood gas findings.

answers.explanation_why: Acidemia with decreased bicarbonate indicates metabolic acidosis, which would be expected in this patient's condition. However, a measured pCO_2 greater than the expected value of pCO_2 based on Winter formula is consistent with an added respiratory acidosis. Increased pCO_2 would not be expected in this hyperventilating patient.
Alkalemia with low pCO_2  indicates respiratory alkalosis, which can occur secondary to hyperventilation, e.g., during a panic attack. Alkalemia would not be expected in this patient's condition.

Acidemia with decreased bicarbonate is consistent with metabolic acidosis. However, for this set of values, the patient's anion gap is 135 - (114 + 15) = 6 mEq/L, which is normal. Normal anion gap metabolic acidosis would be seen in patients with renal tubular acidosis or gastrointestinal loss of HCO_3^- (e.g., secondary to diarrhea). The accumulation of ketones in this patient's condition would result in an increased anion gap.

Normal arterial blood gas results and a normal anion gap can be seen in a hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state (HHS), which can cause an altered mental status, features of dehydration, and possibly vomiting. However, the onset of symptoms is more insidious in HHS, and abdominal pain and a fruity breath odor are not features of this condition. Moreover, HHS usually occurs in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus and manifests with a serum glucose concentration ≥ 600 mg/dL. A different hyperglycemic crisis is more likely in this patient.

This set of arterial blood gas findings is expected in diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), the most likely cause of abdominal pain, vomiting, dehydration (dry mucous membranes, decreased skin turgor), and altered mental status in a patient with type 1 diabetes mellitus and nonadherence to insulin therapy. Insulin deficiency triggers lipolysis, which generates free fatty acids that become ketones, resulting in a high anion gap 135 mEq/L- (98 mEq/L + 9 mEq/L) = 28 mEq/L). The primary acid-base disturbance in DKA is metabolic acidosis and patients, therefore, develop acidemia with decreased bicarbonate. Winter formula, i.e., expected pCO_2 (mm Hg) = (1.5 × HCO_3^‑) + 8 ± 2, is used to identify the presence of a secondary acid-base disorder. In this patient expected 19.5–23.5, which means there is respiratory compensation (from hyperventilation) and no added respiratory acid-base disorder.

In patients with a hyperglycemic crisis, the measured sodium concentration should be used to calculate the anion gap. The corrected serum sodium concentration is only used to calculate water deficits and guide fluid management.

Alkalemia with high bicarbonate is consistent with a primary metabolic alkalosis. While metabolic alkalosis can occur as a result of repeated vomiting, this patient's condition is associated with a different primary acid-base disorder.

question_text:
A 57-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 2 hours after the onset of severe nausea and vomiting. He also has cramping abdominal pain and feels fatigued. Two months ago, he injured his lumbar spine in a car accident and lost complete motor and sensory function below the level of injury. He has been bedridden ever since and is cared for at home. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and renal insufficiency. Examination shows dry mucosal membranes and sensory impairment with flaccid paralysis in both lower limbs that is consistent with prior examinations. Laboratory studies show:

Serum

Calcium
12.8 mg/dL

Parathyroid hormone
7 pg/mL

Thyroid-stimulating hormone
2.5 μU/mL

Thyroxine
8 μg/dL

25-Hydroxycholecalciferol

5 ng/mL (N = 20–50)

Creatinine
2.1 mg/dL

Urine

Calcium
550 mg/24 h

Creatinine clearance
46 mL/min

In addition to administration of intravenous 0.9% saline and calcitonin, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 57-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 2 hours after the onset of severe nausea and vomiting. He also has cramping abdominal pain and feels fatigued. Two months ago, he injured his lumbar spine in a car accident and lost complete motor and sensory function below the level of injury. He has been bedridden ever since and is cared for at home. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and renal insufficiency. Examination shows dry mucosal membranes and sensory impairment with flaccid paralysis in both lower limbs that is consistent with prior examinations. Laboratory studies show: Serum Calcium 12.8 mg/dL Parathyroid hormone 7 pg/mL Thyroid-stimulating hormone 2.5 μU/mL Thyroxine 8 μg/dL 25-Hydroxycholecalciferol 5 ng/mL (N = 20–50) Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL Urine Calcium 550 mg/24 h Creatinine clearance 46 mL/min In addition to administration of intravenous 0.9% saline and calcitonin, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient has symptomatic hypercalcemia, as evidenced by his nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, fatigue, and elevated serum calcium. His history of prolonged immobilization from his recent accident, decreased parathyroid hormone (PTH), and increased urinary calcium excretion suggest his hypercalcemia is due to increased bone resorption.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for symptomatic hypercalcemia due to excessive bone resorption.

answers.explanation_why: Reduced calcium intake (< 1000 mg/day) is recommended for patients with mild (< 12 mg/dL) to moderate (12–14 mg/dL) hypercalcemia that is asymptomatic or mildly symptomatic. Although this patient has moderate hypercalcemia, he has a number of symptoms requiring treatment that goes beyond dietary calcium restriction.

Parathyroidectomy may be required for patients with hypercalcemia due to primary hyperparathyroidism. While patients with hyperparathyroidism have elevated PTH levels, however, this patient's PTH levels are decreased due to negative feedback from hypercalcemia, suggesting another etiology.

Thiazide diuretics should be avoided in patients with hypercalcemia. This class of drugs inhibits the Na^+-Cl^- cotransporter in the distal convoluted tubule, resulting in decreased intracellular Na^+. This, in turn, enhances the activity of the Na^+-Ca^2+ exchanger, and increases the driving force for Ca^2+ resorption, which worsens hypercalcemia. Loop diuretics, not thiazide diuretics, may be considered in patients with hypercalcemia and renal insufficiency (as is the case here) to increase Ca^2+  secretion and prevent volume overload while receiving IV fluids.

Hemodialysis can be considered for patients with serum calcium that is 18–20 mg/dL, neurologic symptoms (e.g., confusion), and/or severe hypercalcemia that has been complicated by renal failure. Although this patient has renal insufficiency, he only has moderate hypercalcemia, some renal function, and no neurologic symptoms. With this in mind, less invasive therapies should be tried before hemodialysis.

Intravenous bisphosphonates (e.g., zoledronic acid, pamidronate) are the first-line treatment for symptomatic hypercalcemia due to excessive bone resorption from any cause (e.g., prolonged immobilization). This class of drugs inhibits osteoclast activity, which decreases bone breakdown and calcium release. Dosage adjustment and close monitoring of renal function are recommended during bisphosphonate therapy in patients with renal impairment, as bisphosphonates are potentially nephrotoxic. In addition, calcitonin should be administered in patients with moderate or severe symptomatic hypercalcemia to increase urinary calcium excretion. Patients with symptomatic hypercalcemia are usually also dehydrated and require intravenous normal saline to lower blood calcium levels and achieve adequate urine output and blood pressure.

Most patients with intact renal function and no other preexisting condition for high bone turnover (e.g., Paget disease of bone, malignancy) are able to compensate for increased bone resorption through increased urinary calcium excretion (i.e., hypercalciuria without hypercalcemia). However, this patient's renal insufficiency limits his ability to excrete calcium in the urine, resulting in hypercalcemia.

Glucocorticoids can be used to treat hypercalcemia caused by granulomatous disease (e.g., sarcoidosis) in which there is increased activation of vitamin D and thus increased intestinal calcium resorption. This patient's 25-hydroxycholecalciferol is decreased, indicating low vitamin D levels, which makes granulomatous disease an unlikely cause of his hypercalcemia. Glucocorticoids are not recommended for hypercalcemia due to bone resorption.
