content_preview: A 46-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with nausea and abdominal pain for 1 day. Her last bowel movement was 6 days ago. She has not passed flatus for 12 hours. She has a history of multiple surgeries for endometriosis. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a distended and diffusely tender abdomen with no rebound or guarding. Rectal examination shows an empty rectum. An x-ray of the abdomen shows a dilated cecum and right colon and preservation of the haustra. The patient is kept NPO (nothing by mouth). A nasogastric tube is inserted for continuous decompression and 900 mL (30 oz) of gastric fluid is drained. This intervention is most likely to lead to which of the following sets of serum findings? pH HCO3- K+ Cl- A ↓ ↓ unchanged unchanged B ↑ ↑ unchanged unchanged C Unchanged unchanged ↓ unchanged D ↑ ↑ ↓ ↓ E ↓ ↓ ↓ ↑ F ↑ ↓ ↓ unchanged
hint: Loss of gastric acid due to continuous nasogastric tube decompression leads to metabolic alkalosis.
learning_objective: Recall the acid-base disorder and laboratory findings caused by excessive nasogastric suctioning.

answers.explanation_why: This set of findings is consistent with metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap, e.g., due to diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). In DKA, the accumulation of acidic ketone bodies leads to a marked decrease in pH. Serum bicarbonate (HCO_3^-) is low because it is consumed as a buffer. Despite actual total body potassium deficits, most patients with DKA present with normal potassium levels due to the shift of potassium from the intracellular to the extracellular space. Evacuation of gastric contents, however, removes acid from the body, which in turn leads to metabolic alkalosis.

This set of findings is consistent with metabolic alkalosis due to bicarbonate (HCO_3^-) excess. Etiologies include excessive administration of bicarbonate in a patient with renal impairment, and milk-alkali syndrome, a condition in which ingestion of large amounts of calcium in combination with antacid therapy interferes with renal bicarbonate excretion. Although evacuation of gastric contents typically leads to metabolic alkalosis, further serum electrolyte changes would be expected here.

This set of findings is consistent with hypokalemia, which can be caused by decreased potassium intake, increased potassium shift into cells (e.g., mediated by excessive insulin or beta-adrenergic activity), and increased gastrointestinal or urinary losses (e.g., vomiting, diuretics). Although extensive gastric fluid drainage will likely cause hypokalemia, further serum changes are expected.

This set of findings is consistent with metabolic alkalosis caused by a loss of gastric acid (e.g., due to nasogastric suction or vomiting). Since gastric acid mainly consists of hydrogen chloride (HCl), hypochloremia is expected. Although small quantities of potassium chloride (KCl) are also lost with the gastric fluid, volume depletion, which leads to secondary hyperaldosteronism and, consequently, stimulation of renal potassium excretion is the main cause of hypokalemia associated with continuous nasogastric decompression. Moreover, renal loss of hydrogen ions leads to an increased formation of bicarbonate (HCO_3^-). See “Acid-base disturbances associated with GI disorders” table.

This set of findings is consistent with metabolic acidosis with a normal anion gap, e.g., due to diarrhea. Diarrhea typically leads to the loss of large amounts of bicarbonate (HCO_3^-) and potassium. Primary loss of bicarbonate is compensated with an elevation of chloride, resulting in hyperchloremic acidosis. Evacuation of gastric contents, however, removes acid from the body, leading to subsequent metabolic alkalosis.

This set of findings is consistent with partially compensated respiratory alkalosis, as may be seen in hyperventilation. Hyperventilation leads to an increase in pH due to a CO_2 washout (i.e., hypocapnia). As a compensatory response, renal bicarbonate (HCO_3^-) reabsorption is reduced, leading to decreased serum levels. Respiratory alkalosis is usually associated with hypokalemia due to a potassium shift from the extracellular space into cells. Although continuous nasogastric decompression also leads to an increase in pH, the loss of gastric acid leads to metabolic alkalosis and, thus, an increase in bicarbonate.

question_text: A 54-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after the sudden onset of shortness of breath, epigastric pain, and sweating. He has no history of similar symptoms. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include amlodipine and metformin. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. He appears weak and pale. His pulse is 59/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 85/56 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows normal heart sounds. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The skin is cold to the touch. An ECG is shown. Bedside transthoracic echocardiography shows normal left ventricular function. High-dose aspirin is administered. Administration of which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 54-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after the sudden onset of shortness of breath, epigastric pain, and sweating. He has no history of similar symptoms. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include amlodipine and metformin. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. He appears weak and pale. His pulse is 59/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 85/56 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows normal heart sounds. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The skin is cold to the touch. An ECG is shown. Bedside transthoracic echocardiography shows normal left ventricular function. High-dose aspirin is administered. Administration of which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: ST-segment elevations in leads II, III, and aVF should raise concern for an inferior wall infarction. Epigastric pain, bradycardia, and hypotension are often seen in patients with right ventricular myocardial involvement. The presence of hypotension and hypoperfusion (cold skin) is concerning for low cardiac output and impending cardiogenic shock.
learning_objective: Recognize right ventricular infarction, and choose the initial management for hemodynamic instability.

answers.explanation_why: Intravenous atropine can be used to treat bradyarrhythmias, which frequently occur within 24 hours of inferior myocardial infarction. However, another intervention should be considered before administering atropine, and atropine may be ineffective without first performing this intervention.

Beta blockers such as metoprolol are used in the treatment of acute myocardial infarction to reduce myocardial oxygen demand and limit the size of the infarct. However, they are contraindicated in patients with bradycardia, hypotension, acute decompensated heart failure, and cardiogenic shock. Treating this patient's right ventricular infarction with oral metoprolol would cause a dangerous reduction in his blood pressure and heart rate.

Intravenous morphine is used to treat severe chest pain and anxiety in acute myocardial infarction. However, it reduces preload by inducing venous dilation; therefore, it is contraindicated in right ventricular infarction, which is preload-dependent.

Nitroglycerin is indicated for the symptomatic treatment of acute coronary syndrome (ACS), except when any of the following are present: suspected or confirmed right ventricular involvement, hypotension, bradycardia, or recent use of phosphodiesterase inhibitors. Patients with right ventricular dysfunction, which is seen in this patient, are dependent on preload to maintain adequate blood pressure. Therefore, nitroglycerin is contraindicated in this patient.

Alpha-adrenergic agonists like phenylephrine increase blood pressure by inducing peripheral vascular vasoconstriction. However, they also cause pulmonary vasoconstriction, which increases right ventricular afterload and impedes right ventricular outflow. Phenylephrine would therefore exacerbate the hemodynamic instability that occurs as a result of right ventricular infarction.

Intravenous fluids (usually normal saline) should be administered in hemodynamically unstable patients with right ventricular infarction to optimize preload. Maintaining preload is critical because right ventricular ischemia impairs left ventricular filling in two ways: (1) it impairs right ventricular contraction, which decreases the volume delivered to the left ventricle, and (2) it reduces right ventricular relaxation, which increases the right ventricular diastolic pressure and decreases the volume of the left ventricle by pushing the septum into the left ventricle. Increasing the preload optimizes left ventricular filling and reduces hemodynamic instability.

If blood pressure cannot be maintained with a fluid bolus, vasopressors and/or an intra-aortic balloon pump can be used.

images.title: Acute inferior ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI)
images.description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

- Sinus rhythm with a heart rate of ∼ 83/min
- Normal cardiac axis: R > S in leads I and aVF
- Normal QRS complex
- ST elevation in the inferior leads (II, III, aVF; blue overlay) with reciprocal ST depression in aVL (red overlay) and pathological Q waves in III (example indicated by green circle overlay)

question_text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a 2-hour history of word-finding difficulty, speech slurring, and weakness and sensory loss of his right arm and leg. He has not had fever, nausea, headache, or diarrhea. His mother reports an episode of severe pain and swelling of his hands and feet when he was 12 months old, which self-resolved after 2 weeks. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. He follows commands but has nonfluent aphasia. Examination shows marked weakness and decreased sensation of the right upper and lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Babinski sign is present on the right. An MRI scan of the brain shows signs of an evolving cerebral infarction on the patient's left side. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
content_preview: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a 2-hour history of word-finding difficulty, speech slurring, and weakness and sensory loss of his right arm and leg. He has not had fever, nausea, headache, or diarrhea. His mother reports an episode of severe pain and swelling of his hands and feet when he was 12 months old, which self-resolved after 2 weeks. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. He follows commands but has nonfluent aphasia. Examination shows marked weakness and decreased sensation of the right upper and lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Babinski sign is present on the right. An MRI scan of the brain shows signs of an evolving cerebral infarction on the patient's left side. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
hint: In a young patient, ischemic stroke, a history of dactylitis (pain/swelling of the hands and feet), and low O_2 saturation suggest sickle cell disease (SCD). Sickled red blood cells are rigid and tend to clump along the walls of arteries, which can lead to thrombosis, infarction, and end-organ ischemia (cerebral infarction in this case).
learning_objective: Recognize sickle cell disease-related acute ischemic stroke, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why:
Immediate exchange transfusion is the first-line therapy in SCD patients with an acute ischemic stroke. During exchange transfusion, erythrocytes with HbS are removed and exchanged with HbS-free erythrocytes, reducing both the concentration of HbS and the rate of vasoocclusion, as well as increasing oxygen delivery. Although exchange transfusion improves outcomes, it does not reverse pre-existing vasoocclusion. In this patient, supplemental oxygen should also be administered to maintain a saturation above 95%.

Prevention of stroke in children with SCD includes screening with transcranial Doppler ultrasound. Identified high-risk patients, as well as children who have already had an ischemic stroke, should receive chronic blood transfusions to lower the proportion of HbS.

Intravenous thrombolytic therapy with tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) is indicated for acute ischemic stroke and is typically administered within 4.5 hours of symptom onset (but can be used later under specialist guidance). Most ischemic strokes are caused by thrombi, but this patient's symptoms are most likely due to the clumping of sickled red blood cells, for which tPA therapy is not effective. In addition, this patient is only 5 years of age, and tPA is not FDA-approved for the treatment of stroke in individuals < 18 years. A different therapy that has a rapid effect and allows for the control of HbS levels is more appropriate.

Mechanical thrombectomy is usually reserved for patients with a large artery occlusion. It is typically carried out in conjunction with intravenous thrombolytic therapy. This technique would not be appropriate in a young patient with SCD.

Hydroxyurea therapy is considered a first-line treatment for primary prevention of vasoocclusive crises and is used in the management of anemia in SCD. As it functions primarily by raising fetal hemoglobin levels, which can take several months to increase significantly, hydroxyurea would not be helpful in the management of an acute ischemic stroke. However, this patient should be started on hydroxyurea before leaving the hospital, as it has been proven to improve survival outcomes and reduce complications.

Although patients with SCD are considered hypercoagulable at baseline, anticoagulation is not recommended for patients with SCD with an acute ischemic stroke. In fact, the use of anticoagulants is strongly cautioned in all patients with SCD, as these patients are at greater risk for intracranial hemorrhage. Heparin is only indicated as thromboprophylactic therapy in patients with SCD ≥ 18 years of age that are hospitalized with an acute medical illness.

Aspirin therapy, which has an antiplatelet effect, is a common adjunctive therapy in the management of an acute ischemic stroke, including in patients with SCD. Administration within 24–48 hours of symptom onset reduces the risk of recurrent stroke and improves mortality. However, another option is more appropriate for the acute management of this patient.

question_text:
A 60-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of a 2-day history of worsening shortness of breath. During the past week, she had a runny nose, mild sore throat, and a low-grade fever. She also has had a cough occasionally productive of sputum for the past 2 years. She has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Current medications include metformin and lisinopril. On examination, she occasionally has to catch her breath between sentences. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 140/70 mm Hg. Expiratory wheezes with a prolonged expiratory phase are heard over both lung fields. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:

pH
7.33

PCO_2
53 mm Hg

PO_2

68 mm Hg

An x-ray of the chest shows hyperinflation of bilateral lung fields and flattening of the diaphragm. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?
content_preview: A 60-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of a 2-day history of worsening shortness of breath. During the past week, she had a runny nose, mild sore throat, and a low-grade fever. She also has had a cough occasionally productive of sputum for the past 2 years. She has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Current medications include metformin and lisinopril. On examination, she occasionally has to catch her breath between sentences. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 140/70 mm Hg. Expiratory wheezes with a prolonged expiratory phase are heard over both lung fields. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows: pH 7.33 PCO2 53 mm Hg PO2 68 mm Hg An x-ray of the chest shows hyperinflation of bilateral lung fields and flattening of the diaphragm. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?
hint: In this chronic smoker, worsening shortness of breath following an upper respiratory infection suggests an acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Arterial blood gas analysis showing decreased pH and increased PCO_2 is consistent with respiratory acidosis.
learning_objective: Recognize an acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and recall the compensatory renal response to chronic respiratory acidosis.

answers.explanation_why: A decrease in urinary HCO_3^- excretion is a compensatory measure in response to hypercapnia and chronic respiratory acidosis, which often occur in patients with COPD as a result of expiratory airway collapse and respiratory muscle fatigue. The proximal convoluted tubules reabsorb HCO_3^-, improving the buffer capacity of the serum against lower pH. The distal convoluted tubules and collecting ducts in the kidneys also increase excretion of H^+ (in the form of H_2PO_4^‑ and NH_4^+), raising the blood pH to compensate for respiratory acidosis.

images.title: Arterial blood gas analysis
images.description:
This algorithm does not account for mixed acid-base disorders.

Cl^-: chloride
HCO_3^-: bicarbonate
Na^+: sodium
PCO_2: partial pressure of carbon dioxide

answers.explanation_why: Increased urinary pH caused by the increased renal tubular excretion of HCO_3^- occurs as a compensatory mechanism in individuals with respiratory alkalosis. This patient's decreased arterial pH and increased PCO_2, however, indicate respiratory acidosis, in which the compensatory mechanism is a decrease (not an increase) in urinary pH.

An increased serum anion gap occurs in high anion gap metabolic acidosis because of an accumulation of unmeasured ions (e.g., ammonium, butyrate, citrate, lactate). In respiratory acidosis, the serum anion gap typically remains unchanged.

Hypokalemia occurs in alkalemia through a shift of K^+ ions from plasma into cellular compartments. Extracellular K^+ exchanges with intracellular H^+ as a compensatory mechanism to lower pH levels. In this patient with acidemia, hyperkalemia would be expected.

Decreased urinary chloride concentration occurs in conditions that cause chloride-depletion metabolic alkalosis such as excessive vomiting or diuretic overuse. Respiratory acidosis is not associated with significant changes in urinary chloride concentration.

question_text:
A 70-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her daughter because of a 2-day history of nonbloody diarrhea. The patient has had 8–10 bowel movements daily and has not vomited. She has a history of hypertension, coronary artery disease, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include furosemide, hydrochlorothiazide, lisinopril, atorvastatin, metoprolol, metformin, and dapagliflozin. She appears ill and sleepy. She is 157 cm (5 ft 2 in) tall and weighs 109 kg (240 lb); BMI is 44 kg/m^2. Her temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 97% on room air. Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes. A fingerstick glucose test shows no abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:

pH
7.24

PO_2

85 mm Hg

PCO_2
39 mm Hg

HCO_3^-
16 mEq/L

Which of the following is the most likely acid-base abnormality in this patient?
content_preview: A 70-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her daughter because of a 2-day history of nonbloody diarrhea. The patient has had 8–10 bowel movements daily and has not vomited. She has a history of hypertension, coronary artery disease, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include furosemide, hydrochlorothiazide, lisinopril, atorvastatin, metoprolol, metformin, and dapagliflozin. She appears ill and sleepy. She is 157 cm (5 ft 2 in) tall and weighs 109 kg (240 lb); BMI is 44 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 97% on room air. Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes. A fingerstick glucose test shows no abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows: pH 7.24 PO2 85 mm Hg PCO2 39 mm Hg HCO3- 16 mEq/L Which of the following is the most likely acid-base abnormality in this patient?
hint: Using the Winter formula, i.e., expected PaCO2 (in mm Hg) = (1.5 x HCO3-) + 8 (+/- 2), the expected pCO_2 for an HCO_3^- concentration of 16 mEq/L is between 30–34 mm Hg.
learning_objective: Recognize metabolic acidosis with respiratory acidosis.

answers.explanation_why: This patient's low pH, low bicarbonate levels, and normal pCO_2 levels suggest metabolic rather than respiratory acidosis as the primary acid-base disorder. In respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation, both pCO_2 and HCO_3^-  levels are expected to be increased, which is not seen here.

This patient's low pH, low bicarbonate levels, and normal pCO_2 levels suggest metabolic acidosis as the primary acid-base disorder. However, in patients with concomitant respiratory alkalosis, pCO_2 levels are expected to be lower rather than higher than expected.

In patients with respiratory acidosis with metabolic alkalosis, pH is usually within the normal range, and both pCO_2 and HCO_3^-  levels are expected to be increased, which is not seen here. This patient's low pH, low bicarbonate levels, and normal pCO_2 levels indicate metabolic rather than respiratory acidosis as the primary acid-base disorder.

This patient's low pH, low bicarbonate levels, and normal pCO_2 levels suggest metabolic acidosis as the primary acid-base disorder. However, in patients with accompanying respiratory compensation, pH levels are expected to be within rather than below the normal range, and the pCO_2 level would not be higher than expected.

This patient's low pH and low bicarbonate levels suggest metabolic acidosis as the primary acid-base disorder. This patient's metabolic acidosis is most likely caused by diarrhea, which commonly leads to loss of bicarbonate, although metformin and dapagliflozin can also cause lactic acidosis and ketoacidosis, respectively. In patients with metabolic acidosis, the expected pCO_2 concentration is calculated according to the Winter formula to check if the patient has developed the expected respiratory compensation. Patients with a pCO_2 higher than expected, as seen here, have concomitant respiratory acidosis. The failed respiratory compensation and consequent mixed acid-base disorder in this patient with morbid obesity are most likely due to obesity hypoventilation syndrome.

images.title: Acid-base nomogram
images.description: This nomogram can be used for the interpretation of an arterial blood gas analysis in the context of acid-base disorders.PCO_2 is on the x-axis and the concentration of HCO_3^- (cHCO_3^-) is on the y-axis; both are displayed logarithmically, allowing the pH to be displayed on parallel straight lines. The important areas for acid-base disorders are highlighted and labeled. The oval area in the middle around PCO_2 = 40 mm Hg and cHCO_3^- = 24 mEq/L represents the reference range.

question_text: A 64-year-old woman comes to the physician because of worsening intermittent nausea and burning pain in her upper abdomen for 4 hours. She has not had retrosternal chest pain, shortness of breathing, or vomiting. She has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. Her only medications are lisinopril and insulin. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 155/75 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The abdomen is soft, with mild tenderness to palpation of the epigastrium but no guarding or rebound. Bowel sounds are normal. ECG is shown. Cardiac examination is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 64-year-old woman comes to the physician because of worsening intermittent nausea and burning pain in her upper abdomen for 4 hours. She has not had retrosternal chest pain, shortness of breathing, or vomiting. She has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. Her only medications are lisinopril and insulin. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 155/75 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The abdomen is soft, with mild tenderness to palpation of the epigastrium but no guarding or rebound. Bowel sounds are normal. ECG is shown. Cardiac examination is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: ST-segment elevations in leads I, aVL, and V1–V4 are consistent with anterior wall myocardial infarction (MI). Nonspecific signs and symptoms (e.g., nausea, abdominal pain in the absence of chest pain) are more common in older people, individuals with diabetes, and women.
learning_objective: Recognize anterior wall myocardial infarction, and recall the associated cardiac examination findings.

answers.explanation_why: A decrescendo diastolic murmur is associated with aortic regurgitation (AR), which is most commonly idiopathic but may also result from syphilis aortitis, infective endocarditis, and connective tissue diseases. It is not a common finding in acute anterior MI. A more common auscultatory finding in a patient with acute MI would be the holosystolic (not diastolic) murmur associated with mitral regurgitation. This valvular dysfunction is due to papillary muscle rupture and is more commonly seen in a right coronary artery occlusion causing infarction of the posteromedial papillary muscle.

An atrial gallop (S_4) results from atrial contraction against a stiff ventricle. It is frequently heard in the acute phase of an MI because of impaired relaxation of the ischemic left ventricle. An S_4  may also be heard in conditions that cause ventricular hypertrophy, such as hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, aortic stenosis, or hypertension. Older patients can have an S_4 as a normal finding because ventricular compliance decreases with age.

A ventricular gallop (S_3), on the other hand, is caused by a sudden deceleration of blood flow from the left atrium into the left ventricle during early diastole. This finding can be normal in young adults (< 40 years) or pregnant women, but it is abnormal in older adults. An S_3 may be heard in dilated cardiomyopathy, heart failure, or valvular diseases such as chronic mitral or aortic regurgitation. It is not a common finding in acute MI.

A mid-systolic click is associated with mitral valve prolapse (MVP). MVP is most commonly diagnosed on physical examination of an asymptomatic patient. It may also occur in patients with a history of rheumatic fever, connective tissue disease, or infective endocarditis.

A fixed-split S_2 sound is associated with atrial septal defects. Blood shifts from the left atrium to the right atrium, which increases right ventricular preload across all phases of the respiratory cycle. As a result, the pulmonic valve consistently closes after the aortic valve. A fixed-split S_2 is not a finding seen in acute MI.

Muffled or distant heart sounds are features of pericardial effusion and cardiac tamponade. Fluid around the heart decreases the conduction of sound. Muffled heart sounds may be heard in patients with cardiac wall rupture as a complication of MI, but they are not typically heard in acute MI.

Elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP) results from increased pressure in the right atrium and is indicative of increased right ventricular pressure. It commonly occurs in right heart failure, tension pneumothorax, pulmonary artery hypertension, and constrictive pericarditis. It is not a common finding in acute MI. Anterior MI affects the left ventricle, not the right, and therefore may cause acute pulmonary edema due to left ventricular dysfunction, but it is unlikely to manifest with elevated JVP.

images.title: Extensive anterolateral STEMI with septal involvement and reciprocal inferior changes
images.description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)– Heart rate: ∼ 110/min
– Normal sinus rhythm
– Normal axis (R > S in I and II)
– Narrow QRS complexes
– Normal PR interval
– Prolonged QT interval (QTc ∼ 650 ms), likely secondary to ischemia
– ST elevation in leads I, aVL, and V1–V4
– Reciprocal ST depression in leads II, III, avF, and V6These findings are consistent with an extensive anterior ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) with septal and lateral extension, likely due to proximal left anterior descending artery (LAD) occlusion.

question_text:
A 68-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 1-week history of worsening bouts of shortness of breath at night. He has had a cough for 1 month occasionally productive of frothy sputum. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and long-standing hypertension. Two years ago, he was diagnosed with Paget disease of bone during a routine health maintenance examination. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 145/98 mm Hg. Current medications include metformin, alendronate, hydrochlorothiazide, and enalapril. Physical examination shows bibasilar crackles. Cardiac examination shows a dull, low-pitched sound during late diastole that is best heard at the apex. There is no jugular venous distention or peripheral edema. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:

pH
7.46

PCO_2

29 mm Hg

PO_2

83 mm Hg

HCO_3^-

20 mEq/L

Echocardiography shows a left ventricular ejection fraction of 55%. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s current condition?
content_preview: A 68-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 1-week history of worsening bouts of shortness of breath at night. He has had a cough for 1 month occasionally productive of frothy sputum. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and long-standing hypertension. Two years ago, he was diagnosed with Paget disease of bone during a routine health maintenance examination. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 145/98 mm Hg. Current medications include metformin, alendronate, hydrochlorothiazide, and enalapril. Physical examination shows bibasilar crackles. Cardiac examination shows a dull, low-pitched sound during late diastole that is best heard at the apex. There is no jugular venous distention or peripheral edema. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows: pH 7.46 PCO2 29 mm Hg PO2 83 mm Hg HCO3- 20 mEq/L Echocardiography shows a left ventricular ejection fraction of 55%. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s current condition?
hint: This patient has features of acute left heart failure, including paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, a cough productive of frothy sputum, an S_4 heart sound (low frequency, late diastolic sound) and bibasilar crackles (suggesting pulmonary edema), and a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 55%, all of which are consistent with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF). The ABG shows compensated primary respiratory alkalosis, likely due to hyperventilation.
learning_objective: Recognize heart failure with preserved ejection fraction, and recall its underlying pathophysiology.

answers.explanation_why: Destruction of alveolar walls is the pathophysiologic hallmark of emphysema, a subtype of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), which would match the history of long-term smoking, shortness of breath, and productive cough. But for COPD, reduced lung sounds would be expected on auscultation. In addition, COPD would not explain this patient's S4 heart sound. Lastly, the CO_2 retention that is associated with COPD leads to respiratory acidosis, not alkalosis.

Decreased myocardial contractility is the pathophysiologic mechanism of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF), which commonly occurs after myocardial infarction (MI) or due to dilated cardiomyopathy. However, this patient's cardiac output is preserved, as is evident in his LVEF of 55%. In addition, despite this patient having risk factors for coronary artery disease (diabetes mellitus, hypertension, older age), he has no clinical features or history to suggest an MI.

images.title: Pathophysiology of heart failure
images.description: Reduced cardiac output results in the activation of compensatory mechanisms (i.e., ADH and BNP production, activation of the renin-angiotensin system and sympathetic nervous system) in an attempt to restore cardiac output.Cardiac remodeling and increases in afterload both have a negative effect on cardiac output. Increases in heart rate and preload have a positive effect on cardiac output. The net effect of these compensatory mechanisms may be sufficient to restore cardiac output. If not, the cycle repeats.

answers.explanation_why: Diuretic overdose manifests as a contraction alkalosis characterized by volume depletion, which in turn activates the RAAS system. The renal changes caused by the aldosterone effect in the renal tubule (sodium reabsorption, potassium and hydrogen excretion) result in metabolic alkalosis, not respiratory alkalosis. Additionally, this patient does not have notable signs of volume depletion like thirst, decreased skin turgor, or dry mucous membranes.

Myxomatous degeneration is the most common pathophysiologic cause of mitral valve prolapse (MVP). Although severe MVP could eventually lead to heart failure and pulmonary venous congestion due to increased left atrial pressure, this patient does not have typical features of MVP like chest pain, palpitations, and a high-frequency, midsystolic click that is best heard in the mitral region.

Because this patient was recently diagnosed with Paget disease of the bone, he is at increased risk of developing systemic arteriovenous fistulas, which can result in high output cardiac failure. This rare complication is caused by the increased vascularity within the abnormal bone that is undergoing high rates of remodeling. High-output cardiac failure manifests with features of hyperdynamic circulation such as high pulse pressure, bounding pulses with a quick upstroke, subungual capillary pulsations, and venous hums, none of which is present in this patient.

Chronic uncontrolled hypertension is the most common cause of HFpEF. Chronic hypertension increases the afterload against which the left ventricle (LV) contracts. As a compensatory mechanism, the myocardium undergoes concentric hypertrophy to maintain cardiac output. Over time, the compensatory response of LV thickening is associated with the maladaptive change of interstitial myocardial fibrosis, which leads to an increase in LV stiffness and impaired myocardial relaxation. As a result, patients develop an increase in left ventricular filling pressures and reduced ventricular filling with normal ventricular contraction (i.e., diastolic dysfunction). Severe myocardial fibrosis can ultimately impair myocardial contractility and result in systolic dysfunction but in such a scenario, the patient will have a low ejection fraction.

Note that impaired myocardial relaxation could have also been correct for restrictive cardiomyopathy, in which the ventricular walls harden without myocardial hypertrophy.

question_text: The serum brain natriuretic peptide and N-terminal pro-BNP are elevated. A diagnosis of heart failure with preserved ejection fraction is made. In addition to supplemental oxygen therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
content_preview: The serum brain natriuretic peptide and N-terminal pro-BNP are elevated. A diagnosis of heart failure with preserved ejection fraction is made. In addition to supplemental oxygen therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
hint: In the absence of other life-threatening conditions (e.g., acute coronary syndrome, shock) that require immediate attention, symptomatic treatment of this patient's pulmonary edema should come first in management.
learning_objective: Choose the initial management step for heart failure with preserved ejection fraction.

answers.explanation_why: Oral statins such as atorvastatin are indicated in patients with congestive heart failure in which ischemic heart disease is the cause of myocardial dysfunction. While this patient has risk factors for atherosclerotic disease such as type 2 diabetes mellitus and long-standing hypertension, he lacks evidence of coronary artery disease (e.g., retrosternal chest pain/pressure, dyspnea, dizziness). Moreover, statins are only indicated in the long-term management of congestive heart failure, not in an acute setting.

Oral beta blockers (e.g., metoprolol) are typically reserved for long-term management of congestive heart failure, not in an acute setting, since their negative inotropic effect can worsen cardiac output. Beta-blocker therapy should be considered once the volume status of the patient has improved.

Hemodialysis is indicated in patients with congestive heart failure with volume overload that is refractory to aggressive diuresis with multiple agents, especially if they have increasing oxygen requirements. It is also indicated in patients who develop kidney failure due to cardiogenic shock. This patient has only been treated with hydrochlorothiazide thus far. Moreover, he does not have signs of kidney failure (e.g., oliguria, metabolic acidosis, uremia).

Opiates such as morphine can reduce patient anxiety and the work of breathing by decreasing central sympathetic output. They also cause peripheral vasodilation and venodilation, decreasing ventricular filling pressure. However, there is not enough available evidence regarding the benefits or potential risks associated with morphine administration (e.g., hypopnea, nausea) in patients with congestive heart failure. Therefore, morphine is not considered standard treatment in the management of acute exacerbation of congestive heart failure and would not be the most appropriate initial step in this patient who does not report significant anxiety.

Thoracentesis is indicated for both diagnostic and therapeutic purposes in patients with pleural effusion. This patient's lung examination findings of bibasilar crackles are inconsistent with a pleural effusion, which typically manifests with decreased breath sounds, dullness to percussion, and decreased tactile fremitus in the affected area due to fluid in the pleural space. Thoracentesis is not indicated in patients with pulmonary edema.

Inotropes such as dobutamine are mainly used as a short-term measure in patients with congestive heart failure (CHF) and a reduced ejection fraction with evidence of cardiogenic shock, systemic hypoperfusion, and end-organ damage. Inotropes are not recommended for patients with CHF with preserved ejection fraction, as seen in this man.

In addition to supplemental oxygen therapy and ventilatory support as needed, this patient requires IV furosemide therapy to improve his volume overload status. Loop diuretics are a first-line treatment for symptomatic relief in acute exacerbation of congestive heart failure in patients with normal or elevated blood pressure. To assess the response to therapy and prevent excessive diuresis and preload reduction, it is important to monitor for adverse effects such as hypokalemia and hyponatremia as well as weight changes and volume status. Intravenous vasodilators (e.g., nitroglycerine, nitroprusside) can be considered as an adjunct treatment. These agents cause peripheral vasodilation, resulting in pooling of blood in the venous system, which rapidly reduces ventricular filling pressures and improves cardiac function.

question_text: A 76-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after being found unconscious in his bathroom. His temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F), pulse is 142/min and regular, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 75/40 mm Hg. He does not open his eyes but does withdraw from painful stimuli. The extremities are cold to touch and capillary refill time is 4 seconds. He is intubated, and mechanical ventilation is initiated. Pulmonary artery catheterization shows increased central venous pressure (CVP), increased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP), and increased systemic vascular resistance (SVR). Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?
content_preview: A 76-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after being found unconscious in his bathroom. His temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F), pulse is 142/min and regular, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 75/40 mm Hg. He does not open his eyes but does withdraw from painful stimuli. The extremities are cold to touch and capillary refill time is 4 seconds. He is intubated, and mechanical ventilation is initiated. Pulmonary artery catheterization shows increased central venous pressure (CVP), increased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP), and increased systemic vascular resistance (SVR). Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?
hint: This patient presents with features of shock: tachycardia, hypotension, cold extremities, and prolonged capillary refill time (normally < 2 seconds). Pulmonary artery catheterization showing increased PCWP helps to identify the most likely type of shock.
learning_objective: Recognize cardiogenic shock due to acute myocardial infarction.

answers.explanation_why: Traumatic hemorrhage leading to hypovolemia can manifest with hypovolemic shock. While the SVR is high in hypovolemic shock, PCWP and CVP would be low.

Spinal cord injury can cause neurogenic shock. However, neurogenic shock usually manifests with bradycardia due to autonomic dysfunction rather than tachycardia, which is seen in this patient. In addition, PCWP, CVP, and SVR are typically decreased because of a loss of vasomotor tone and widespread vasodilation.

Patients with systemic allergic reactions can present with anaphylactic shock, which is a form of distributive shock. Because anaphylaxis is associated with widespread vasodilation, low PCWP, CVP, and SVR are expected rather than the increase seen here. In addition, patients with anaphylactic shock typically have warm extremities due to vasodilation and usually display other features of anaphylaxis (e.g., urticaria, angioedema, bronchoconstriction).

Massive pulmonary embolism (PE) can manifest with obstructive shock, in which blood flow from the right heart to the left heart is blocked. This blockage results in blood “backing up” into the right atrium, resulting in increased CVP. Low cardiac output results in hypotension, which induces peripheral vascular constriction and thus increases SVR. However, PCWP is decreased in obstructive shock caused by PE because insufficient blood is delivered to the left atrium (LA), causing a decrease in LA pressure.

In certain cases of obstructive shock (e.g., due to cardiac tamponade), PCWP can also be increased.

Acute myocardial infarction is the most likely diagnosis in this older patient who presents with features of cardiogenic shock. Myocardial infarction causes an acute reduction in cardiac function that usually affects the left ventricle (95% of patients). Loss of left ventricular function leads to an increase in left atrial pressure, which is measured as an increase in PCWP. Progressive loss of cardiac function further impedes venous return to the heart, leading to a high CVP. In addition, there is a decrease in cardiac output and cardiac index, which is countered by systemic vasoconstriction in an attempt to maintain central perfusion. This vasoconstriction leads to an increased SVR and cool extremities with delayed capillary refill.

See “Hemodynamic parameters in shock” table.

Widespread infection leading to sepsis can manifest with septic shock, which is a form of distributive shock. Septic shock typically manifests with widespread vasodilation in response to the acute inflammation, resulting in a decreased SVR rather than an increase, which is seen here. In addition, the resulting intravascular volume depletion would lead to a low CVP and PCWP.

question_text: Four days after being admitted to the intensive care unit for acute substernal chest pain and dyspnea, an 80-year-old man is evaluated for hypotension. Coronary angiography on admission showed an occlusion in the left anterior descending artery, and a drug-eluting stent was placed successfully. The patient has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include aspirin, clopidogrel, metoprolol, lisinopril, and atorvastatin. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 72/50 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows a normal S_1 and S_2 and a new harsh, holosystolic murmur heard best at the left sternal border. There is jugular venous distention and a right parasternal heave. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Pitting edema extends up to the knees bilaterally. An ECG shows Q waves in the anterior leads. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s hypotension?
content_preview: Four days after being admitted to the intensive care unit for acute substernal chest pain and dyspnea, an 80-year-old man is evaluated for hypotension. Coronary angiography on admission showed an occlusion in the left anterior descending artery, and a drug-eluting stent was placed successfully. The patient has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include aspirin, clopidogrel, metoprolol, lisinopril, and atorvastatin. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 72/50 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows a normal S1 and S2 and a new harsh, holosystolic murmur heard best at the left sternal border. There is jugular venous distention and a right parasternal heave. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Pitting edema extends up to the knees bilaterally. An ECG shows Q waves in the anterior leads. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s hypotension?
hint: This patient's hypotension, tachycardia, bulging neck veins, pedal edema, and new holosystolic murmur are suggestive of acute heart failure.
learning_objective: Recognize interventricular septum rupture.

answers.explanation_why: Ascending aortic dissection rupture can cause hemorrhage into the pericardium or the mediastinum, which would manifest with acute onset chest pain and evidence of cardiogenic shock. While anterior aortic dissection can also result in a murmur due to associated aortic regurgitation, the murmur would be diastolic rather than systolic. Aortic dissection would also not explain the presence of jugular venous distention or pedal edema. Moreover, although aortic dissection can lead to myocardial infarction (due to extension of the dissection to the coronary arteries), aortic dissection is not a described complication of myocardial infarction.

Post-infarction fibrinous pericarditis typically occurs 1–3 days after myocardial infarction and can manifest with tachycardia and new-onset dyspnea. However, other features, such as pleuritic chest pain, dry cough, and a pericardial friction rub, would be expected as well. Pericarditis would also not explain the presence of jugular venous distention or pedal edema. Moreover, the ECG in a patient with early post-infarction fibrinous pericarditis would typically show diffuse ST elevations, which this patient does not have.

Left ventricular free wall rupture is a complication of myocardial infarction that most often occurs within 5–14 days of the initial myocardial infarction. In most patients, this event results in sudden onset pericardial tamponade and features of cardiogenic shock (hypotension, tachycardia, tachypnea). However, a new-onset murmur is not a typical manifestation of free wall rupture. Muffled heart sounds on auscultation and pulsus paradoxus would be expected instead. ECG would typically show low voltage ventricular complexes, electrical alternans, and new ST-segment changes, none of which are seen here.

Left ventricular aneurysms develop weeks to months following myocardial infarction. The scar tissue that results from the initial infarction cannot remodel to accommodate the tension across the left ventricle and develops an outpouching (aneurysm) that is susceptible to rupture. A rupture typically manifests with symptoms of heart failure (hypotension, dyspnea), ventricular arrhythmias, or emboli from a mural thrombus. This patient is experiencing a complication 4 days after myocardial infarction, virtually excluding a left ventricular aneurysm as the cause.

Papillary muscle rupture typically occurs within 2–7 days of myocardial infarction and most commonly manifests with symptoms of severe acute mitral regurgitation. Acute mitral valve regurgitation would result in a new systolic murmur that would be heard best over the apex, not the left sternal border. Patients with severe acute mitral regurgitation would also have findings consistent with left heart failure (pulmonary edema, cool extremities, and altered mental status), none of which this patient has. Rupture of a papillary muscle is most often a complication in patients with involvement of the posterior descending artery, which is usually supplied by the right coronary artery, whereas this patient had an occlusion of the left anterior descending artery.

Interventricular septum rupture typically occurs 3–5 days after myocardial infarction. It manifests with sudden onset hemodynamic instability (hypotension, tachycardia, tachypnea) and signs of right ventricular failure (jugular venous distention, parasternal heave, pedal edema, and characteristically clear lungs) due to the development of a left-to-right shunt. This patient's new-onset holosystolic murmur is the result of blood flow across the newly formed ventricular septal defect (analogous to the classic murmur of a ventricular septal defect).

question_text: Two days after coronary artery stent placement for a posterior myocardial infarction, a 70-year-old woman complains of difficulty breathing and retrosternal chest pain. She has a history of atrial fibrillation, for which she takes verapamil. Following stent placement, the patient was started on aspirin and clopidogrel. She appears to be in acute distress and is disoriented. Respirations are 22/min. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 80%. Diffuse crackles are heard on auscultation of the chest. The patient is intubated and mechanical ventilation is started. Shortly afterwards, she becomes unresponsive. Heart sounds are inaudible and her carotid pulses are not palpable. The cardiac monitor shows normal sinus rhythm with T-wave inversion. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: Two days after coronary artery stent placement for a posterior myocardial infarction, a 70-year-old woman complains of difficulty breathing and retrosternal chest pain. She has a history of atrial fibrillation, for which she takes verapamil. Following stent placement, the patient was started on aspirin and clopidogrel. She appears to be in acute distress and is disoriented. Respirations are 22/min. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 80%. Diffuse crackles are heard on auscultation of the chest. The patient is intubated and mechanical ventilation is started. Shortly afterwards, she becomes unresponsive. Heart sounds are inaudible and her carotid pulses are not palpable. The cardiac monitor shows normal sinus rhythm with T-wave inversion. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient has no pulse despite there being a detectable rhythm on monitoring, which is consistent with a diagnosis of pulseless electrical activity (PEA).
learning_objective: Recognize pulseless electrical activity (PEA), and choose the most appropriate initial resuscitative measure.

answers.explanation_why: Unsynchronized cardioversion, also known as defibrillation, is advised when a patient in cardiac arrest has an underlying cardiac rhythm consistent with ventricular tachycardia or ventricular fibrillation (“shockable” rhythms). Defibrillation is not recommended for PEA arrest.

IV epinephrine is a critical part of the therapy algorithm for patients with cardiac arrest. While epinephrine may eventually be indicated for this patient with PEA, it is not the initial step in management for a patient in cardiac arrest. A different intervention should be performed first.

The first step in any patient with PEA is the initiation of chest compressions. High-quality, uninterrupted chest compressions should be started immediately in any unresponsive patient without a pulse and are critical in the resuscitation of a patient with any type of cardiac arrest (regardless of the underlying rhythm). After chest compressions have been initiated, further resuscitative measures can be considered. There are a number of possible underlying etiologies for this patient's PEA arrest, including hypoxia, thromboembolism (myocardial infarction or pulmonary embolism), or pneumothorax (a complication of mechanical ventilation).

IV amiodarone is used as a second-line agent in patients with cardiac arrest due to ventricular tachycardia or ventricular fibrillation. It is administered as a 300 mg bolus and an additional 150 mg dose can be given 3-5 minutes later. Amiodarone is not recommended for patients with PEA arrest.

Therapeutic hypothermia is recommended if a patient has impaired mental status (e.g., not following commands, no purposeful movements) after the return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC) has been achieved in a patient with cardiac arrest. It has been shown to improve neurological outcomes in post-cardiac arrest patients and is recommended for at least 24 hours. This patient has not yet achieved ROSC, which means that hypothermia is not indicated.

Acute myocardial infarction is an important cause of cardiac arrest, and coronary angiography should be considered once the patient is resuscitated, especially given her recent coronary stent placement (which is associated with a high risk of stent thrombosis and re-infarction). While evaluating the underlying cause of this patient's arrest will be important, she is too unstable to undergo coronary angiography at this time.

Synchronized cardioversion is a treatment option for patients with cardiac arrhythmias who show hemodynamic instability (e.g., in atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response) but still have a palpable pulse. While this patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, the cardiac monitor shows normal sinus rhythm which, together with pulselessness, is consistent with PEA arrest. A different therapy is indicated.

question_text:
A 65-year-old woman who lives in an assisted living facility is brought to the emergency department by her nursing assistant because of shortness of breath for the past 5 hours. The patient has not had fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or urinary symptoms. She has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypertension. Medications include inhaled albuterol and budesonide, and oral hydrochlorothiazide and glyburide. She smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 36 years but quit 4 years ago. The patient is alert and fully oriented but appears dyspneic and is unable to complete a sentence. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 152/80 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 86%. Auscultation of the chest reveals expiratory wheezes over all lung fields. Arterial blood gas analysis on 2 L/min of oxygen shows:

pH
7.34

PO_2

124 mm Hg

PCO_2
49 mm Hg

O_2 saturation
91%

A chest x-ray shows hyperinflated lungs and a flattened diaphragm. Intravenous methylprednisolone is administered and continuous albuterol-ipratropium nebulization therapy is initiated. Broad-spectrum antibiotic treatment is begun. An hour later, repeat arterial blood gas analysis on 4 L/min of oxygen shows:

pH
7.32

PO_2

162 mm Hg

PCO_2
58 mm Hg

O_2 saturation
92%

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

The patient has not had fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or urinary symptoms. She has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypertension. Medications include inhaled albuterol and budesonide, and oral hydrochlorothiazide and glyburide. She smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 36 years but quit 4 years ago. The patient is alert and fully oriented but appears dyspneic and is unable to complete a sentence. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 152/80 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 86%. Auscultation of the chest reveals expiratory wheezes over all lung fields. Arterial blood gas analysis on 2 L/min of oxygen shows: pH 7.34 PO2 124 mm Hg PCO2 49 mm Hg O2 saturation 91% A chest x-ray shows hyperinflated lungs and a flattened diaphragm. Intravenous methylprednisolone is administered and continuous albuterol-ipratropium nebulization therapy is initiated. Broad-spectrum antibiotic treatment is begun. An hour later, repeat arterial blood gas analysis on 4 L/min of oxygen shows: pH 7.32 PO2 162 mm Hg PCO2 58 mm Hg O2 saturation 92% Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The blood gas analysis shows respiratory acidosis, which is an indication for additional respiratory support in patients with an acute COPD exacerbation (AECOPD).
learning_objective: Recognize acute COPD exacerbation with respiratory acidosis, and choose the most appropriate respiratory support.

answers.explanation_why: Nonselective phosphodiesterase inhibitors (e.g., theophylline) have bronchodilatory and antiinflammatory effects and can be considered as an adjunct in the maintenance treatment of severe or refractory COPD. However, it is not routinely recommended for use in AECOPD because of its cardiotoxic effects.

answers.content: Rapid sequence intubation and mechanical ventilation
answers.explanation_why: In patients with AECOPD, rapid sequence intubation is only indicated if the patient cannot protect their airway (e.g., due to vomiting, altered mental status), if the patient is hemodynamically unstable, or if less invasive respiratory support measures have failed or are contraindicated (e.g., impaired/absent spontaneous breathing, poor mask seal). Mechanical ventilation via endotracheal intubation in patients with COPD is associated with an increased risk of complications (e.g., barotrauma) and higher mortality rates.

answers.content: High-flow oxygen therapy via nonrebreather mask
answers.explanation_why: High-flow oxygen therapy (HFOT), which involves providing oxygen at high flow rates (e.g., 60 L/min) in order to achieve an FiO_2 that nearly reaches 100%, is indicated for the treatment of hypoxemic respiratory failure. While HFOT does deliver small amounts of positive airway pressure, it is not an effective treatment for hypercapnic respiratory failure as it does not sufficiently decrease CO_2 levels. Furthermore, this patient's SO_2 is already within the target range for AECOPD (88–92%) with oxygen flow rates of 2–4 L/min; it is not necessary to increase the FiO_2 at this time.

Noninvasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV), typically with bilevel positive airway pressure (BiPAP), is the recommended first-line ventilatory strategy in patients with AECOPD and acute respiratory failure. Indications include respiratory acidosis, as seen here, severe dyspnea with signs of increased work of breathing and/or respiratory muscle fatigue, and persistent hypoxemia despite supplemental oxygen. As the name implies, noninvasive ventilation provides positive pressure ventilation through a noninvasive interface (e.g., facemask). Compared to endotracheal intubation, NIPPV carries a lower risk of complications (e.g., barotrauma, airway trauma) and is associated with decreased hospital length-of-stay, lower mortality, and a decreased risk of complications such as infections.

Invasive mechanical ventilation is indicated only if a trial of NIPPV fails (e.g., poor patient tolerance, worsening hypoxemia), if NIPPV is contraindicated (e.g., altered mental status, high risk of aspiration), or if the patient has severe hemodynamic instability.

Epinephrine has beta-adrenergic properties, which facilitate bronchodilation. However, because of its alpha-adrenergic effects, epinephrine also carries a high risk of cardiovascular complications, e.g., arrhythmias. Epinephrine is not recommended for the management of AECOPD.

question_text:
Four days after undergoing a Whipple procedure for newly diagnosed pancreatic cancer, a 65-year-old man has shortness of breath. His surgery was complicated by bleeding for which he required intraoperative transfusion with 4 units of packed red blood cells and 1 unit of platelets. His temperature is 38.8°C (101.8°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 95/55 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 85%. Cardiac examination shows normal heart sounds and no jugular venous distention. Auscultation of the lungs shows diffuse crackles bilaterally. The extremities are warm and there is no edema. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 9.8 g/dL and a leukocyte count of 17,000/mm^3. Arterial blood gas on room air shows:

pH
7.35

PO_2
41 mm Hg

PCO_2

38 mm Hg

HCO_3^-

20 mEq/L

The patient is intubated and mechanical ventilation is initiated. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Transthoracic echocardiography shows a normally contracting left ventricle. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current condition?
content_preview: Four days after undergoing a Whipple procedure for newly diagnosed pancreatic cancer, a 65-year-old man has shortness of breath. His surgery was complicated by bleeding for which he required intraoperative transfusion with 4 units of packed red blood cells and 1 unit of platelets. His temperature is 38.8°C (101.8°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 95/55 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 85%. Cardiac examination shows normal heart sounds and no jugular venous distention. Auscultation of the lungs shows diffuse crackles bilaterally. The extremities are warm and there is no edema. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 9.8 g/dL and a leukocyte count of 17,000/mm3. Arterial blood gas on room air shows: pH 7.35 PO2 41 mm Hg PCO2 38 mm Hg HCO3- 20 mEq/L The patient is intubated and mechanical ventilation is initiated. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Transthoracic echocardiography shows a normally contracting left ventricle. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current condition?
hint: This patient has respiratory distress, diffuse crackles, bilateral bat wing opacities on chest x-ray, and a PaO_2/FiO_2  ≤ 300 (41 mm Hg/0.21 ≈ 195 mm Hg). In the absence of signs suggestive of cardiogenic pulmonary edema due to heart failure (e.g., jugular venous distension, ventricular gallop, dysfunctional ventricular contractions), this presentation is concerning for acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
learning_objective: Recognize acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).

answers.explanation_why:
Cytokine-induced diffuse inflammatory alveolar damage is the characteristic feature of ARDS. This damage results in noncardiogenic pulmonary edema, a V/Q mismatch, intrapulmonary shunting, increased pulmonary artery pressure (due to hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction), and increased work of breathing (due to decreased lung compliance), and ultimately leads to respiratory distress with type 1 respiratory failure. The left atrial pressure and pulmonary capillary wedge pressure remain unaffected in ARDS.

Sepsis is the most common cause of ARDS and is likely present in this patient as evidenced by the fever, tachycardia, hypotension, warm extremities, and leukocytosis.

images.title: Pathophysiology of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)

answers.explanation_why: Increased left atrial pressure would most likely be seen in left heart failure. However, the absence of specific findings on examination and echocardiography make heart failure unlikely. The left atrial pressure does not increase in ARDS.

answers.content: Acute occlusion of a pulmonary artery
answers.explanation_why: Pulmonary embolism (PE) is a possible complication of abdominal surgery and can manifest with respiratory distress and tachycardia. However, chest x-rays in patients with PEs would be normal, show nonspecific abnormalities (e.g., atelectasis, pleural effusions), or disclose evidence of pulmonary infarction (e.g., Hampton hump), but bilateral bat wing opacities would not be expected. Furthermore, acute PE will typically present with respiratory alkalosis due to hyperventilation.

Decreased chest wall compliance occurs with advancing age and certain musculoskeletal disorders. However, respiratory compromise due to decreased chest wall compliance typically manifests with a chronic progressive course, not with acute onset hypoxemia. This patient has ARDS, which is characterized by decreased compliance of the lung parenchyma and does not affect the chest wall.

Transfusion-related lung injury (TRALI) as a result of anti-leukocyte antibodies can cause ARDS after blood transfusion. Given this patient's history of multiple blood transfusions, he is at an increased risk for developing TRALI. However, TRALI typically presents within 6 hours of blood transfusion, and this patient developed symptoms 4 days after surgery, so the diagnosis is unlikely.

images.title: Diffuse airspace opacification
images.description: X-ray chest (AP view) of a patient with adult respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)Confluent and multifocal airspace opacities (examples indicated by green overlay) predominate in the lower zones of the lungs. Air bronchograms (examples indicated by red lines) are visible in some locations. There are no Kerley lines or pleural effusions. The cardiac silhouette size is normal. An endotracheal tube (arrow) is present.ARDS and other causes of noncardiogenic edema can produce extensive airspace opacification, as can cardiogenic edema, diffuse pneumonia, diffuse alveolar hemorrhage, pneumonic-type adenocarcinoma, and pulmonary alveolar proteinosis. Radiography alone cannot establish a diagnosis of ARDS.

question_text: A 3-week-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of a 3-day history of progressive lethargy and difficulty feeding. He was born at term and did not have difficulty feeding previously. His temperature is 39.4°C (103°F), pulse is 220/min, respirations are 45/min, and blood pressure is 50/30 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on 100% oxygen shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Examination shows dry mucous membranes, delayed capillary refill time, and cool skin with poor turgor. Despite multiple attempts by the nursing staff, they are unable to establish peripheral intravenous access. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 3-week-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of a 3-day history of progressive lethargy and difficulty feeding. He was born at term and did not have difficulty feeding previously. His temperature is 39.4°C (103°F), pulse is 220/min, respirations are 45/min, and blood pressure is 50/30 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on 100% oxygen shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Examination shows dry mucous membranes, delayed capillary refill time, and cool skin with poor turgor. Despite multiple attempts by the nursing staff, they are unable to establish peripheral intravenous access. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This infant's poor feeding, lethargy, high fever, tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypotension should raise concern for septic shock.
learning_objective: Recognize septic shock in a child, and choose the most appropriate next step in management.

answers.explanation_why: Rapid sequence intubation can be an important part of the management of patients with shock if there is a concern for airway compromise or impending respiratory failure. Although this patient is tachypneic, his oxygen saturation of 97% is currently stable with supplemental oxygen.

Intramuscular epinephrine is vital in the management of anaphylactic shock. Moreover, epinephrine is indicated in pediatric life support if effective circulation cannot be achieved (e.g., hypotension unresponsive to fluid administration). While it may be necessary to administer epinephrine to this hemodynamically unstable patient, another intervention is required first. Moreover, in septic shock, intramuscular administration is not the preferred route for vasopressors.

Femoral vein cannulation is a common method of gaining central venous access in critically ill patients. It allows for the administration of fluids and drugs that should not be infused through smaller peripheral lines for a long period of time (e.g., vasoactive agents, potassium chloride). However, in a patient who is hemodynamically unstable and has no peripheral access, another more rapid intervention is required to avoid a delay in critical resuscitation.

Internal jugular vein cannulation is a common method of gaining central venous access in critically ill patients. It allows for the administration of fluids and drugs that should not be infused through smaller peripheral lines for a long period of time (e.g., vasoactive agents, potassium chloride). However, in a patient who is hemodynamically unstable and has no peripheral access, another more rapid intervention is required to avoid a delay in critical resuscitation.

In children with septic shock, vascular or intraosseous (IO) access should be established within the first few minutes of resuscitation. IO access is indicated if peripheral intravenous access cannot be established after three attempts. IO access is preferred to central venous access, as it is typically obtained quickly, and there is a high rate of success on the first attempt. The most common location for IO cannulation is the proximal tibia.

Ultrasound guidance increases the rate of success in establishing peripheral venous access. However, this procedure can be time-consuming, even with an experienced operator. In a hemodynamically unstable patient, a more rapid form of access should be obtained to prevent a delay in critical resuscitation.

Umbilical vein cannulation can be a lifesaving method of vascular access in neonatal resuscitation (< 10–14 days of age) and is commonly used during resuscitation immediately after delivery. Because this patient is 3 weeks old, it is unlikely that he still has a patent umbilical vein.

question_text:
A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being rescued from a fire in his apartment complex. He briefly lost consciousness while he was trapped in a smoke-filled room before firefighters were able to free him 20 minutes later. He reports headache, dizziness, and occasional cough. He has no difficulty breathing, speaking, or swallowing. He appears mildly uncomfortable and agitated. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 155/68 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Breath sounds are coarse. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:

pH
7.30

PCO_2

38 mm Hg

PO_2

70 mm Hg

HCO_3^-

18 mEq/L

COHb
2% (N < 3)

In addition to oxygen supplementation with a nonrebreather mask, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being rescued from a fire in his apartment complex. He briefly lost consciousness while he was trapped in a smoke-filled room before firefighters were able to free him 20 minutes later. He reports headache, dizziness, and occasional cough. He has no difficulty breathing, speaking, or swallowing. He appears mildly uncomfortable and agitated. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 155/68 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Breath sounds are coarse. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows: pH 7.30 PCO2 38 mm Hg PO2 70 mm Hg HCO3- 18 mEq/L COHb 2% (N < 3) In addition to oxygen supplementation with a nonrebreather mask, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Burning household items (e.g., plastics, furniture, rubber) can release cyanide, which causes toxicity seconds after inhalation. Cyanide binds to the mitochondrial cytochrome complex, which increases anaerobic metabolism and causes lactic acidosis. This patient's neurologic symptoms (e.g., headache, dizziness) and metabolic acidosis following smoke inhalation should raise concern for cyanide intoxication.
learning_objective: Recognize cyanide poisoning from smoke inhalation, and choose the appropriate antidote.

answers.explanation_why: Intravenous dimercaprol is a therapy for metal toxicity (e.g., arsenic, mercury, lead, or gold toxicity). This drug does not play a role in the treatment of cyanide toxicity.

Hyperbaric oxygen therapy is the first-line treatment for carbon monoxide toxicity, which is caused by smoke inhalation and can manifest with headache, confusion, nausea, vomiting, and, in severe cases, loss of consciousness. This patient's normal carboxyhemoglobin levels make carbon monoxide toxicity unlikely. Patients with cyanide toxicity should receive treatment with 100% oxygen; however, hyperbaric oxygen therapy is not recommended.

Methylene blue is the treatment of choice for methemoglobinemia. This drug acts by reducing the ferric iron (Fe^3+) of methemoglobin (unable to bind oxygen) back to the ferrous iron (Fe^2+) of hemoglobin. Patients with methemoglobinemia typically present after exposure to an oxidizing agent (e.g., nitrates, dapsone) with clinical signs of cyanosis but normal PO_2 on arterial blood gas analysis. Methylene blue was used in the treatment of cyanide poisoning, but it is no longer used for such treatment because it can release free cyanide and thereby worsen cyanide toxicity.

All patients with suspected acute cyanide poisoning should receive antidotal treatment in addition to supportive measures (e.g., 100% oxygen therapy) and body surface decontamination. Cyanide poisoning is primarily a clinical diagnosis, and antidotal treatment should not be delayed for further diagnostic testing. Intravenous hydroxocobalamin is the first-line antidote because it acts rapidly, does not affect tissue oxygenation, and has minimal adverse effects. Hydroxocobalamin binds cyanide directly, forming cobalamin, which is then excreted in urine. This drug can be coadministered with sodium thiosulfate to enhance cyanide elimination.

Alternative treatment for patients with cyanide poisoning includes nitrites (e.g., amyl or sodium nitrite), which induce methemoglobinemia. Cyanide preferentially binds to methemoglobin, forming the compound cyanomethemoglobin and freeing cytochrome complex IV to resume oxidative phosphorylation. Because of the risk of worsening tissue hypoxia, this therapy should not be used in patients with inhalation injury unless concomitant carbon monoxide toxicity has been excluded.
N-acetylcysteine is an antioxidant used to restore depleted hepatic glutathione in patients with acetaminophen toxicity. It does not play a role in the treatment of cyanide toxicity.
