question_text: An 18-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her father 20 minutes after he found her unconscious on her bedroom floor. The father reports that he had an argument with the patient earlier in the evening, after which she swallowed a handful of pills. She has major depressive disorder, anorexia nervosa, and migraine headaches. Her father has chronic constipation and hypothyroidism. On arrival, she is obtunded. Her temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure 90/70 mm Hg. Examination shows dry, flushed skin. Her pupils are dilated and react sluggishly to light. Bowel sounds are hypoactive. ECG shows sinus tachycardia and widened QRS complexes. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's widened QRS complexes?
content_preview: An 18-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her father 20 minutes after he found her unconscious on her bedroom floor. The father reports that he had an argument with the patient earlier in the evening, after which she swallowed a handful of pills. She has major depressive disorder, anorexia nervosa, and migraine headaches. Her father has chronic constipation and hypothyroidism. On arrival, she is obtunded. Her temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure 90/70 mm Hg. Examination shows dry, flushed skin. Her pupils are dilated and react sluggishly to light. Bowel sounds are hypoactive. ECG shows sinus tachycardia and widened QRS complexes. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's widened QRS complexes?
hint: A combination of antimuscarinic effects (e.g., sedation, dry flushed skin, hyperthermia, pupillary dilation, decreased bowel sounds, sinus tachycardia) with α_1 receptor blockade (hypotension) is suggestive of intoxication with tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs), which are used in the treatment of major depressive disorder and for migraine prophylaxis. Another specific effect of TCAs is responsible for a wide QRS complex on ECG.
learning_objective: Recognize tricyclic antidepressant overdose, and recall its effect on cardiac conduction.

answers.explanation_why: Serotonergic overactivity (i.e., serotonin syndrome) can be caused by drugs such as TCAs, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, triptans, and ergotamine. Serotonin syndrome manifests with tachycardia, hyperthermia, and altered mental status, as seen here. Given that this patient has major depressive disorder and migraine, she may have been prescribed one or more of the aforementioned drugs. However, this patient's wide QRS complex is not explained by serotonergic overactivity.

Increased potassium loss is seen in patients with anorexia nervosa, commonly as a result of laxative abuse. This patient with anorexia nervosa might have access to laxatives because her father has chronic constipation. However, the characteristic ECG findings in hypokalemia are U waves, T wave flattening, a prolonged PR interval, and/or a prolonged QT interval; a wide QRS complex is not explained by hypokalemia, although it can be seen in hyperkalemia.

Excessive beta-adrenergic receptor blockade due to a beta blocker overdose can cause hypotension and an altered mental status, as seen here. Additionally, this patient may have been prescribed beta blockers for migraine prophylaxis. However, typical ECG features of beta blocker toxicity are sinus bradycardia (β_1 receptor blockade prevents the reflex tachycardia associated with hypotension) and a wide PR interval (due to a first-degree AV block); the wide QRS complex in this patient is not explained by beta-adrenergic receptor blockade.

TCAs directly inhibit fast sodium channels and cause an intraventricular conduction delay, which manifests as wide QRS complexes. Wide QRS complexes correlate positively with the risk of seizures and ventricular tachyarrhythmias from TCA toxicity. A QRS complex > 100 ms in duration is, therefore, an indication for initiating sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO_3) therapy in patients with TCA overdose. NaHCO_3 therapy, which increases extracellular Na^+ concentration, leads to an increased Na^+ concentration gradient across the cellular membrane and thereby attenuates the Na^+ channel blockade. In patients with CNS depression, avoidance of respiratory acidosis is important because acidemia increases the release of lipid- and protein-bound TCA as well as the binding of TCA to Na^+ channels. NaHCO_3 therapy as well as early intubation and mechanical ventilation is helpful in this regard.

images.title: ECG abnormalities in tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) toxicity
images.description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)– Sinus tachycardia (heart rate: ∼143/min)
– Left-axis deviation (R > S in lead I; S > R in aVF)
– Widened QRS complexes (∼160 ms in lead II)
– QT prolongation (QTc ∼556 ms)
– Prominent R wave in aVRIn a patient with suspected drug overdose, wide complex sinus tachycardia with QT prolongation and a prominent R wave in aVR suggest sodium channel blocker toxicity, which may indicate TCA overdose.

answers.explanation_why: Adrenergic overactivity can be caused by an excessive intake of synthetic thyroid hormone. Adrenergic overactivity causes tachycardia, hyperthermia, and dilated pupils, as seen here. Additionally, this patient may have had access to thyroid medications because her father has hypothyroidism. However, her wide QRS complex is not explained by adrenergic overactivity; the classic ECG changes of increased adrenergic activity are sinus tachycardia with shortening of PR and QT intervals.

question_text:
An 82-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of worsening confusion. His caretaker at the skilled nursing care facility where he resides says that, since he had a “mini-stroke” 2 weeks ago, he has been a “poor eater”. He has dementia, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Current medications include lisinopril, metoprolol, inhaled budesonide, and pravastatin. He is oriented to person but not to place or time. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 100/68 mm Hg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes, poor skin turgor, and cracked lips. Capillary refill time is greater than 3 seconds. Serum studies show:

Glucose
95 mg/dL

Creatinine
1.5 mg/dL

Na^+
155 mEq/L

K^+

3.7 mEq/L

Cl^-

110 mEq/L

HCO_3^-

22 mEq/L

Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
content_preview: An 82-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of worsening confusion. His caretaker at the skilled nursing care facility where he resides says that, since he had a “mini-stroke” 2 weeks ago, he has been a “poor eater”. He has dementia, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Current medications include lisinopril, metoprolol, inhaled budesonide, and pravastatin. He is oriented to person but not to place or time. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 100/68 mm Hg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes, poor skin turgor, and cracked lips. Capillary refill time is greater than 3 seconds. Serum studies show: Glucose 95 mg/dL Creatinine 1.5 mg/dL Na+ 155 mEq/L K+ 3.7 mEq/L Cl- 110 mEq/L HCO3- 22 mEq/L Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
hint: This patient's hypotension, tachycardia, dry mucous membranes, and delayed capillary refill, along with hypernatremia (likely chronic—i.e., developing over the past 2 weeks) and elevated creatinine concentration, should raise concern for hypernatremia with severe hypovolemia. Management involves volume repletion followed by correction of excess sodium with free water.
learning_objective: Choose the initial management for severe hypovolemia with hypernatremia.

answers.explanation_why: Intravenous administration of free water, a hypotonic fluid with an osmolality of zero, would lead to rapid lowering of the serum sodium concentration but would not increase the patient's extracellular fluid volume sufficiently to treat his hypovolemia. Rapid correction of hypernatremia carries a risk of causing cerebral edema. Additionally, intravenous infusion of free water can cause hemolysis (due to the large difference in tonicity between free water and red blood cells).

answers.content: Intravenous administration of 5% dextrose in 0.45% saline
answers.explanation_why: Intravenous administration of 5% dextrose in 0.45% saline, a hypertonic fluid, can simultaneously correct a free water deficit (to lower the serum sodium concentration) and increase extracellular fluid volume. However, after the dextrose is rapidly metabolized, the resulting 0.45% saline is hypotonic. Thus, this fluid would not be sufficiently effective for volume repletion in this patient, who presents with signs and symptoms of severe hypovolemia.

Intravenous administration of 0.9% saline, an isotonic fluid, is the best initial step in the management of this patient with severe hypovolemia and hypernatremia. Although normal saline only increases extracellular fluid volume and has a minimal effect on lowering the serum sodium concentration, it should be administered first in a patient with hypovolemic shock to prevent severe complications of volume depletion, such as myocardial and/or cerebral ischemia. After adequate expansion of the extracellular fluid volume, the next step in management is to correct the hypernatremia with a gradual infusion of 5% dextrose in 0.45% saline. Hypotonic saline is preferred in patients with subacute or chronic mild hypovolemic hypernatremia because it corrects the free water deficit without rapidly decreasing the serum osmolality, which can cause cerebral edema.

answers.content: Intravenous administration of 5% dextrose in water
answers.explanation_why: Gradual intravenous administration of 5% dextrose in water is a common initial fluid regimen to lower the serum sodium concentration of patients with euvolemic or hypervolemic hypernatremia. However, following the rapid metabolism of dextrose, the resulting free water is very hypotonic. Thus, it would not increase this patient's extracellular fluid volume sufficiently to treat his hypovolemia.

Intravenous administration of 0.45% saline, a hypotonic fluid, can simultaneously correct a free water deficit (to lower the serum sodium concentration) and increase the patient's extracellular fluid volume. However, hypotonic fluids would not be sufficiently effective for volume repletion in this patient, who presents with signs and symptoms of severe hypovolemia.

question_text: A 72-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of increasing abdominal pain for 6 hours. The pain is dull and diffuse over her abdomen and radiates to her lower back bilaterally. Three weeks ago, she was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation and started on warfarin. Her only other medication is 1 g of acetaminophen three times daily for osteoarthritis of her knees. Her pulse is 87/min and blood pressure is 112/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows abdominal tenderness to palpation at both lower quadrants. A CT scan of the abdomen shows a retroperitoneal mass and hazy margins of the surrounding structures. In addition to discontinuation of warfarin, the most appropriate next step in management is administration of which of the following?
content_preview: A 72-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of increasing abdominal pain for 6 hours. The pain is dull and diffuse over her abdomen and radiates to her lower back bilaterally. Three weeks ago, she was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation and started on warfarin. Her only other medication is 1 g of acetaminophen three times daily for osteoarthritis of her knees. Her pulse is 87/min and blood pressure is 112/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows abdominal tenderness to palpation at both lower quadrants. A CT scan of the abdomen shows a retroperitoneal mass and hazy margins of the surrounding structures. In addition to discontinuation of warfarin, the most appropriate next step in management is administration of which of the following?
hint: This patient presents with dull abdominal pain radiating to her lower back, which, in combination with the abdominal CT findings, suggests retroperitoneal hemorrhage. High-dose acetaminophen can interact with warfarin, resulting in increased warfarin activity, which affects the extrinsic coagulation system.
learning_objective: Choose the treatment for warfarin-induced retroperitoneal hemorrhage.

answers.explanation_why:
This patient's history of taking warfarin for atrial fibrillation and high-dose acetaminophen for osteoarthritis likely contributed to the retroperitoneal hematoma. Acetaminophen metabolites inhibit vitamin K-dependent carboxylase and thereby the formation of coagulation factors in the extrinsic pathway. This patient should receive intravenous prothrombin complex concentrate to replenish the vitamin K-dependent factors (II, VII, IX, X) and intravenous phytonadione, a vitamin K produced by plants, to aid in factor activation.

See “Overview of anticoagulant reversal” table.

Desmopressin and platelet concentrate are beneficial in patients with bleeding due to platelet dysfunction (e.g., uremia, antiplatelet agents). Platelet dysfunction usually manifests with mucosal bleeding (e.g., bleeding gums, epistaxis, petechiae, purpura, ecchymosis). In contrast, warfarin affects the coagulation cascade, which results in deep tissue bleeding (retroperitoneal hemorrhage) seen in this patient.

answers.content: Fresh frozen plasma and tranexamic acid
answers.explanation_why: Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) contains all the clotting factors required for warfarin reversal but is considered a second-line agent. Because of its side effect profile, which includes volume overload and transfusion reactions, a different reversal agent is preferred. Tranexamic acid is an antifibrinolytic agent mainly used for treating severe blood loss due to severe trauma, surgery, and post-partum hemorrhage, but it is not classically used for warfarin reversal.

answers.content: Aminocaproic acid and packed red blood cells
answers.explanation_why: Aminocaproic acid is an antifibrinolytic agent that inhibits the plasminogen-plasmin system. It is indicated for excessive bleeding in patients on thrombolytics (e.g., streptokinase, tPA), but it would not be used to counteract the effects of warfarin in the case of hemorrhage. Packed red blood cells (pRBC) are classically indicated in severe blood loss due to acute hemorrhage (with or without hypovolemic shock) or symptomatic anemia (e.g., G6PD deficiency). However, in a patient without signs of hypoxia (e.g., tachycardia, hypotension, dyspnea) or anemia (e.g., exertional dyspnea. fatigue, pallor), pRBC should not be administered. Moreover, administration of pRBC would not reverse warfarin-induced hemorrhage.

Protamine sulfate, a heparin antidote, is mainly used for the treatment of heparin overdose, and hydroxyethyl starch is an intravascular volume expander used in patients with hypovolemic shock or severe hemorrhage (due to trauma and/or surgery). However, neither agent would reverse a warfarin-induced hemorrhage.

answers.content: Factor VIII and von Willebrand factor
answers.explanation_why: Factor VIII and von Willebrand factor (vWF) are indicated for managing acute bleeding and to prevent surgical bleeding in patients with hemophilia A or vWF deficiency. However, neither agent would reverse warfarin-induced hemorrhage.

question_text: A 34-year-old woman with a history of depression is brought to the emergency department by her husband 45 minutes after ingesting an unknown amount of a termite poison in a suicide attempt. She has abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. Her husband reports that she has had two episodes of watery diarrhea on the way to the emergency department. A distinct, garlic-like odor on the breath is noted on examination. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia and QTc prolongation. Administration of which of the following is most appropriate?
content_preview: A 34-year-old woman with a history of depression is brought to the emergency department by her husband 45 minutes after ingesting an unknown amount of a termite poison in a suicide attempt. She has abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. Her husband reports that she has had two episodes of watery diarrhea on the way to the emergency department. A distinct, garlic-like odor on the breath is noted on examination. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia and QTc prolongation. Administration of which of the following is most appropriate?
hint: While abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and watery diarrhea are rather nonspecific findings that can occur in several types of poisoning, the garlic-like odor on the breath and QTc prolongation suggest arsenic poisoning. Arsenic is a common component of pesticides.
learning_objective: Recognize arsenic poisoning, and choose the most appropriate chelation therapy.

answers.explanation_why: N-acetylcysteine is used to treat acetaminophen toxicity, which can also cause nonspecific symptoms (e.g., nausea, vomiting) in the first 24 hours after ingestion. However, this patient's history of recent pesticide ingestion does not suggest acetaminophen poisoning.

Fomepizole is used to treat methanol or ethylene glycol poisoning, which can also cause nausea, abdominal pain, and QTc prolongation. However, ethylene glycol causes a sweet-smelling rather than garlic-like odor on the breath. Moreover, methanol and ethylene glycol poisoning also commonly manifest with altered mental status, headaches, and seizures.

Deferoxamine is used to treat acute iron toxicity, which also causes gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., abdominal pain, nausea, hematemesis, diarrhea) within 6 hours of ingestion. However, this patient has no history of excessive iron ingestion and iron toxicity would not explain this patient's garlic-like odor on the breath.

Physostigmine is used to treat anticholinergic poisoning, which can also cause tachycardia and QTc prolongation. However, patients usually also have mydriasis, dry mouth, and warm and flushed skin; they do not develop garlic-like odor on the breath. Finally, this patient has no history of anticholinergic agent intake (e.g., atropine, deadly nightshade).

EDTA is used to treat acute lead poisoning, which causes constipation rather than diarrhea. Additionally, patients usually have additional signs and symptoms, including headache, seizures, muscle weakness, and paresthesias. This patient has no history of ingesting lead-containing products.

In combination with atropine, pralidoxime is used to treat organophosphate poisoning, which can also cause a garlic-like (or petrol-like) odor on the breath. Organophosphates are also found in pesticides. However, patients usually have additional signs and symptoms of cholinergic crisis such as hypotension, increased salivation, uncontrolled urination, bronchospasm, muscle fasciculations, and bradycardia (in contrast to this patient's tachycardia), none of which are present in this patient.

Arsenic toxicity results from its ability to bind strongly to sulfhydryl groups, thereby affecting the activity of different enzyme systems. Affected processes include glucose metabolism, glutathione metabolism, and cellular respiration (e.g., pyruvate dehydrogenase complex). Treatment for arsenic poisoning includes chelation therapy, cardiac monitoring (because of the risk of QTc prolongation), and fluid administration (to encourage urine output). Dimercaprol chelates several heavy metals, including arsenic, to form more stable, nontoxic, soluble compounds that are then excreted in the urine.

In cases of recent arsenic ingestion (within an hour), additional therapies include gastric lavage and activated charcoal (to absorb arsenic in the gastrointestinal tract). Dimercaptosuccinic acid (succimer) is more commonly used as chelation therapy for arsenic poisoning in children.

question_text: A 33-year-old man is evaluated by paramedics after being found unconscious outside of his home. He has no palpable pulses. Physical examination shows erythematous marks in a fern-leaf pattern on his lower extremities. An ECG shows ventricular fibrillation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
content_preview: A 33-year-old man is evaluated by paramedics after being found unconscious outside of his home. He has no palpable pulses. Physical examination shows erythematous marks in a fern-leaf pattern on his lower extremities. An ECG shows ventricular fibrillation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
hint: The fern-leaf pattern on the patient's lower extremities is caused by local hyperemia.
learning_objective: Recognize a lightning strike.

answers.explanation_why: The fern-leaf pattern seen on this patient's lower extremities is also referred to as a Lichtenberg figure, which is pathognomonic of a lightning strike. In about 30% of cases, a lightning strike is fatal; the most common cause of death is cardiac arrest due to a fatal arrhythmia, such as ventricular fibrillation or asystole. Superficial burns and metallization of the skin may also occur after a lightning strike injury.

images.title: Lichtenberg figures
images.description: Faint erythematous cutaneous markings in a fern leaf pattern (Lichtenberg figures; example indicated by arrow) are visible on the lower left leg.Lichtenberg figures are pathognomonic of lightning injury.

answers.explanation_why: Cholesterol emboli, as well as other vascular diseases that cause slower blood flow due to obstruction of blood vessels (e.g., vasculitis, atherosclerosis), can lead to livedo reticularis. However, cholesterol emboli are unlikely to lead to ventricular fibrillation and have a different appearance than the fern-leaf pattern seen here.
Severe hypothermia (< 82°F) can lead to pulselessness or ventricular fibrillation. However, the usual skin finding with hypothermia is livor mortis, rather than the fern-leaf pattern seen here.

images.title: Livor mortis
images.description: Photograph of a deceased patientPurple discoloration of the skin is visible in the dependent parts of the body.This is the typical appearance of livor mortis. The intensity of the discoloration and color depends on the cause of death.

answers.explanation_why: Opioid overdose should always be considered when a person is found unconscious without a known history of present illness or past medical history. Although opioid overdose can result in cardiac abnormalities, the associated skin findings do not appear in a fern-leaf pattern.

Infective endocarditis can cause arrhythmias if a perivalvular abscess forms. Skin findings associated with infective endocarditis include Janeway lesions, splinter hemorrhages, and Osler nodes. However, these skin findings do not have the fern-leaf pattern seen in this patient. Furthermore, severe constitutional symptoms (e.g., high fever, malaise) and progression over at least days would be expected with infective endocarditis.

images.title: Janeway lesions
images.description: Multiple erythematous macules are visible on the thenar eminence and the base of the thumb.These Janeway lesions are typically caused by septic microembolisms secondary to infective endocarditis.

question_text: Two hours after admission to the intensive care unit, a 56-year-old man with necrotizing pancreatitis develops profound hypotension. His blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg and he is started on vasopressors. A central venous access line is placed. Which of the following is most likely to decrease the risk of complications from central venous catheter placement?
content_preview: Two hours after admission to the intensive care unit, a 56-year-old man with necrotizing pancreatitis develops profound hypotension. His blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg and he is started on vasopressors. A central venous access line is placed. Which of the following is most likely to decrease the risk of complications from central venous catheter placement?
hint: Precautions must be taken when placing central venous catheters to prevent central-line associated bloodstream infections (CLABSI).
learning_objective: Choose the most effective strategy to decrease the risk of central-line associated bloodstream infections.

answers.explanation_why: Anticoagulation is not routinely performed after central venous line placement to reduce the risk of catheter-related complications. Flushing of the line with heparin should only be considered in patients who require long-term central venous access.

answers.content: Initiation of periprocedural systemic antibiotic prophylaxis
answers.explanation_why: Periprocedural systemic antibiotic prophylaxis is not routinely performed during CVL insertion to reduce catheter colonization or CLABSI. Flushing of the line with antibiotics is generally only considered in patients who require long-term central venous access or who are immune suppressed.

answers.content: Replacement of the central venous line every 7-10 days
answers.explanation_why: Routine replacement of CVL every 7–10 days is not recommended because it does not reduce the risk of CLABSI and unnecessarily exposes the patient to additional procedures. Central lines should be inserted and accessed only when absolutely necessary and then removed as soon as possible. Hospitalized patients with CVLs should be assessed daily to determine whether or not the line can be removed.

answers.content: Preparation of the patient's skin with chlorhexidine and alcohol
answers.explanation_why: Proper hand hygiene and preparing the patient's skin with chlorhexidine and alcohol is the most effective strategy in decreasing the risk of infection (e.g., CLABSI) from CVL placement. Chlorhexidine has proven superior to iodine-based compounds for antisepsis.

answers.content: Placement of the central venous line in the femoral vein
answers.explanation_why: Placing the CVL in the femoral vein would not reduce complications, as femoral lines carry an increased risk of CLABSI due to their location. The preferred sites for CVL insertion are the subclavian and internal jugular veins. While the subclavian site minimizes the risk of infection, it is associated with a higher rate of iatrogenic pneumothorax. The internal jugular site, on the other hand, is associated with a greater risk of infection but a lower risk of pneumothorax.

question_text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle collision in which he was a restrained passenger. The patient is confused. His pulse is 140/min and blood pressure is 85/60 mm Hg. Examination shows a hand-sized hematoma on the anterior chest wall. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia. Which of the following structures is most likely injured in this patient?
content_preview: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle collision in which he was a restrained passenger. The patient is confused. His pulse is 140/min and blood pressure is 85/60 mm Hg. Examination shows a hand-sized hematoma on the anterior chest wall. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia. Which of the following structures is most likely injured in this patient?
hint: This patient's presentation of shock (hypotension, tachycardia, altered mental status) after severe blunt chest trauma in the setting of a motor vehicle accident is highly suggestive of blunt thoracic aortic injury.
learning_objective: Recognize injury to the aortic isthmus.

answers.explanation_why: Papillary muscle rupture is a notorious complication after a myocardial infarction and presents with acute hypotension, new-onset mitral regurgitation, and subsequent pulmonary edema. Rapid deceleration injury in a motor vehicle accident is not associated with papillary muscle rupture.

The aortic isthmus, a physiological narrowing at the final section of the aortic arch, is located just distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery and is tethered by the ligamentum arteriosum. It is the most common site of injury due to blunt aortic trauma because it is extremely vulnerable to rapid deceleration injury, which can occur in motor vehicle accidents when the chest smashes against the steering wheel or is abruptly restrained by the seatbelt.

Management aims to assess the severity of injury and includes a CT angiography in hemodynamically stable patients or a TEE if hemodynamically unstable.

In rare cases, rapid deceleration injury in the setting of a motor vehicle accident can lead to a large aortic tear that extends to the aortic valve. Nevertheless, this is not a common site of injury. Moreover, a diastolic murmur would be heard due to new-onset aortic regurgitation.

Injury to the inferior vena cava may occur in patients after blunt decelerating trauma, but it is extremely rare. Aside from that, the hematoma seen on the patient's chest would not be typical as injury to the inferior vena cava would likely result in retroperitoneal hematoma.

Although the coronary arteries may also be affected together with aortic injury, the absence of ST-segment abnormalities on this patient's ECG makes involvement of the left main coronary artery unlikely.

question_text: A 23-year-old man is admitted to the intensive care unit with acute respiratory distress syndrome due to influenza A. He has no history of serious illness and does not smoke. An x-ray of the chest shows diffuse bilateral infiltrates. Two weeks later, his symptoms have improved. Pulmonary examination shows fewer inspiratory crackles than at the time of admission. This patient is most likely to develop which of the following long-term complications?
content_preview: A 23-year-old man is admitted to the intensive care unit with acute respiratory distress syndrome due to influenza A. He has no history of serious illness and does not smoke. An x-ray of the chest shows diffuse bilateral infiltrates. Two weeks later, his symptoms have improved. Pulmonary examination shows fewer inspiratory crackles than at the time of admission. This patient is most likely to develop which of the following long-term complications?
hint: This long-term complication typically manifests with ground-glass opacities and thickening of the interlobular septa on CT scan.
learning_objective: Recognize acute respiratory distress syndrome, and recall its long-term complications.

answers.explanation_why: Pulmonary embolism commonly develops in patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) during the hospitalization period. It is primarily caused by immobilization, stasis of blood, and endothelial damage, which can activate the coagulation cascade. However, pulmonary embolism is not considered a long-term complication of ARDS.

Patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) are at increased risk for interstitial lung disease. The first stage of ARDS is characterized by damage to capillaries and epithelial cells in the lungs (diffuse alveolar damage), which causes exudation of protein-rich fluid into the alveolar space and the formation of hyaline membranes. This damage is repaired by the proliferation of type II pneumocytes and infiltration of fibroblasts, ultimately leading to progressive interstitial fibrosis and restrictive lung disease.

images.title: Pathophysiology of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)

answers.explanation_why: Spontaneous pneumothorax occurs most commonly with obstructive lung disease (e.g., emphysema-predominant COPD) and is not a typical complication of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). Iatrogenic (not spontaneous) pneumothorax may occur acutely as a complication of mechanical ventilation for the treatment of ARDS.

Panacinar emphysema, which is characterized by destruction of the entire acinus, is associated with α1-antitrypsin deficiency. Panacinar emphysema is not a complication of acute respiratory distress syndrome.
Asthma is a reversible obstructive lung disease that is triggered by exposure to allergens, GERD, cold air, and exercise. Asthma is not a complication of acute respiratory distress syndrome.

question_text: A 61-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance because of severe retrosternal chest pain and shortness of breath for 30 minutes. Paramedics report that an ECG recorded en route to the hospital showed ST-segment elevation in I, aVL, and the precordial leads. On arrival, the patient is unresponsive to painful stimuli. Examination shows neither respiration nor pulse. Despite appropriate lifesaving measures, he dies 10 minutes later. Which of the following is the most likely cause of death in this patient?
content_preview: A 61-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance because of severe retrosternal chest pain and shortness of breath for 30 minutes. Paramedics report that an ECG recorded en route to the hospital showed ST-segment elevation in I, aVL, and the precordial leads. On arrival, the patient is unresponsive to painful stimuli. Examination shows neither respiration nor pulse. Despite appropriate lifesaving measures, he dies 10 minutes later. Which of the following is the most likely cause of death in this patient?
hint: The patient's chest pain and dyspnea combined with the finding of ST-segment elevation in a proximal left anterior descending distribution on ECG are highly suggestive of myocardial infarction (MI). The patient's subsequent death within an hour of symptom onset is known as sudden cardiac death (SCD).
learning_objective: Recognize myocardial infarction, and recall its early complications.

answers.explanation_why: MI that affects the interventricular septum has the potential to rupture, creating a left-to-right shunt and right heart failure. While this would also present with shortness of breath, it would usually not occur until 3–5 days after MI.

Depending on the extent and distribution of a MI, contractility of the left ventricle can decrease to the point of left ventricular failure. In addition, MI can cause papillary muscle rupture resulting in mitral valve regurgitation and left ventricular failure. While acute left heart failure secondary to MI does present with shortness of breath and chest pain, it typically occurs several hours after MI and is thus not the most common cause of SCD.

In ventricular aneurysm, a portion of the ventricular free wall affected by the MI will outpouch, putting patients at risk for cardiac arrhythmia, heart failure, and cardiac tamponade, all of which can cause sudden cardiac death. However, ventricular aneurysm happens between 2 weeks and several months after MI.

Thromboembolism can result from left ventricular aneurysm or new onset atrial fibrillation post-MI and can cause hemorrhagic stroke. However, these complications typically take days to weeks to develop, and stroke is not a common cause of sudden cardiac death in patients with MI.

MI can cause weakness of the ventricular free wall, which makes it prone to rupture under the high pressures of systole. This results in cardiac tamponade and is often fatal. However, ventricular free wall rupture occurs usually within the first 2 weeks of MI, when necrosis has had time to sufficiently weaken the ventricular free wall tissue, not during first hour post-MI.

Ventricular fibrillation is a cardiac arrhythmia in which multiple ectopic foci of electrical activity within the ventricle cause disorganized depolarization and diminished cardiac output. Patients with ventricular fibrillation require rapid defibrillation and CPR, otherwise hemodynamic instability can lead to loss of consciousness and SCD, which is the leading cause of death post-MI. SCD after MI is usually due to ventricular tachyarrhythmias such as ventricular tachycardia or ventricular fibrillation.

question_text: A previously healthy 5-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of difficulty breathing and vomiting that began 1 hour after she took an amoxicillin tablet. She appears anxious. Her pulse is 140/min, respirations are 40/min, and blood pressure is 72/39 mmHg. She has several well-circumscribed, raised, erythematous plaques scattered diffusely over her trunk and extremities. Pulmonary examination shows diffuse, bilateral wheezing. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy?
content_preview: A previously healthy 5-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of difficulty breathing and vomiting that began 1 hour after she took an amoxicillin tablet. She appears anxious. Her pulse is 140/min, respirations are 40/min, and blood pressure is 72/39 mmHg. She has several well-circumscribed, raised, erythematous plaques scattered diffusely over her trunk and extremities. Pulmonary examination shows diffuse, bilateral wheezing. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy?
hint: The patient's acute hypotension, tachycardia, respiratory distress, and dermatologic findings in the setting of recent antibiotic use are consistent with anaphylaxis.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy for anaphylaxis.

answers.explanation_why: Glucocorticoids such as methylprednisolone are commonly given as an adjunctive treatment in anaphylaxis. However, glucocorticoids take several hours before onset of action and would not address the acute hypotension and respiratory distress seen in this patient.

Albuterol, a beta-2 receptor agonist, can be used as an adjunctive medication in the treatment of anaphylaxis to counteract the smooth muscle contraction that causes bronchospasm. However, it would not address the hypotension seen in this patient and is not the best initial treatment.

Norepinephrine causes vasoconstriction and increased inotropy via its effects on both alpha-1 adrenergic receptors and beta-1 adrenergic receptors. It is a second-line agent for anaphylaxis and not the best initial choice of therapy. Furthermore, it would not address this patient's respiratory distress.

Diphenhydramine, a first-generation antihistamine, can be used as an adjunctive medication in the treatment of anaphylaxis to relieve symptoms of itching and urticaria. However, an antihistamine would not address this patient's hypotension, respiratory distress, or the underlying mechanism of her symptoms.

Cimetidine, an H2 antihistamine, can be used as an adjunctive medication in the treatment of anaphylaxis to potentiate the actions of H1 antihistamines for itching and urticaria. However, an antihistamine would not address this patient's hypotension, respiratory distress, or the underlying mechanism of her symptoms.

Dobutamine causes increased inotropy via its effects on beta-1 adrenergic receptors, as well as peripheral vasodilation via its effects on beta-2 adrenergic receptors. Although its inotropic effects make dobutamine useful in the treatment of cardiogenic shock, it would actually worsen this patient's hypotension.

Phenylephrine causes vasoconstriction via its effects on alpha-1 adrenergic receptors and is used to treat hypotension in patients with shock. However, it is not the most appropriate initial medication in the treatment of anaphylaxis and would not address this patient's respiratory distress.

Epinephrine should be administered immediately if anaphylaxis, a type I hypersensitivity reaction, is suspected. Epinephrine acts at both beta-adrenergic receptors (at lower doses) and alpha-adrenergic receptors (at higher doses) to help increase blood pressure, increase bronchodilation, reduce mucosal edema in the upper airway, and reduce the release of inflammatory mediators from mast cells and basophils.

question_text: A 57-year-old woman is admitted to the intensive care unit for management of shock. Her pulse is feeble and blood pressure is 86/45 mm Hg. The patient undergoes pulmonary artery catheterization which shows an elevated pulmonary capillary wedge pressure and increased systemic vascular resistance. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?
content_preview: A 57-year-old woman is admitted to the intensive care unit for management of shock. Her pulse is feeble and blood pressure is 86/45 mm Hg. The patient undergoes pulmonary artery catheterization which shows an elevated pulmonary capillary wedge pressure and increased systemic vascular resistance. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?
hint: This patient might have presented with substernal chest pain radiating to her jaw.
learning_objective: Recognize cardiogenic shock, and recall its effect on mental status.

answers.content: Cold skin due to loss of intravascular fluid volume
answers.explanation_why: Loss of intravascular fluid volume is consistent with hypovolemic shock. In hypovolemic shock, the sympathetic nervous system is activated, which causes vasoconstriction and thus an increased SVR. Although SVR is increased in this patient, her PCWP is inconsistent with hypovolemic shock. Hypovolemic shock would result in a decreased PCWP due to preload reduction from intravascular depletion.

Bradycardia due to neurologic dysfunction is consistent with increased intracranial pressure (Cushing reflex) and spinal cord damage above T_6 level. Spinal cord damage can cause hypotension and feeble peripheral pulses (neurogenic shock). However, neurogenic shock would be associated with decreased SVR (due to peripheral vasodilation) and decreased PCWP (due to preload reduction from intravascular depletion). Patients with increased ICP would have hypertension.

answers.content: Bronchospasm due to excessive histamine release
answers.explanation_why: Bronchospasm due to excessive histamine release is consistent with anaphylactic shock. Anaphylactic shock is caused by a type I hypersensitivity reaction that may lead to circulatory failure (distributive shock). In anaphylactic shock, the SVR and PCWP are both decreased due to histamine-mediated vasodilation and capillary leak.

answers.content: Mottled skin due to release of endotoxins
answers.explanation_why: Release of endotoxins is consistent with septic shock. Septic shock results from systemic vasodilation and capillary leakage. Initially, the skin is typically warm and flushed, but as shock progresses, the skin becomes mottled, cool and pale. However, septic shock typically results in decreased SVR (due to peripheral vasodilation) and decreased PCWP (due to decreased left ventricular preload caused pooling of blood in peripheral circulation).

answers.content: Confusion due to decreased stroke volume
answers.explanation_why: Confusion due to decreased stroke volume is consistent with cardiogenic shock, which is the most likely cause of shock in this patient. Poor left ventricular output results in elevated pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP). In addition, hypotension activates the sympathetic nervous system, resulting in vasoconstriction and increased systemic vascular resistance (SVR). Peripheral vasoconstriction also causes cold, clammy extremities.

question_text:
An 84-year old woman is brought to the emergency department from a nursing facility because of confusion and aggressive behavior. She has had multiple episodes of diarrhea the last 3 days. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), blood pressure is 82/51 mm Hg, and pulse is 110/min. She is disoriented to place and time. Her extremities are warm and dry; her pulses are weak. Placement of a foley catheter yields cloudy urine with a foul odor. This patient is most likely to have which of the following hemodynamic profiles?

Cardiac output
Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure
Systemic vascular resistance
Central venous pressure

A
Decreased
decreased
decreased
decreased

B
Increased
decreased
decreased
decreased

C
Decreased
increased
increased
increased

D
Increased
increased
increased
increased

E
Decreased
decreased
increased
decreased
content_preview: An 84-year old woman is brought to the emergency department from a nursing facility because of confusion and aggressive behavior. She has had multiple episodes of diarrhea the last 3 days. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), blood pressure is 82/51 mm Hg, and pulse is 110/min. She is disoriented to place and time. Her extremities are warm and dry; her pulses are weak. Placement of a foley catheter yields cloudy urine with a foul odor. This patient is most likely to have which of the following hemodynamic profiles? Cardiac output Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure Systemic vascular resistance Central venous pressure A Decreased decreased decreased decreased B Increased decreased decreased decreased C Decreased increased increased increased D Increased increased increased increased E Decreased decreased increased decreased
hint: Infection should always be considered as a cause of altered mental status in an older patient.
learning_objective: Recognize septic shock, and recall its hemodynamic findings.

answers.explanation_why: This profile suggests neurogenic shock, which is an uncommon consequence of CNS trauma and is caused by loss of sympathetic tone. It results in a form of distributive shock with vasodilation and reduced SVR, as well as relative bradycardia and decreased cardiac output. Without history or evidence of significant head, neck, or spine trauma, this etiology is very unlikely to explain the patient's presentation.

This profile suggests septic shock, most likely due to a urinary tract infection, which is the most common type of distributive shock. Septic shock involves an excessive inflammatory response to a disseminated infection, triggering the release of circulating cytokines and bacterial toxins. Consequently, these mediators induce pathological vasodilatation, resulting in decreased systemic vascular resistance (afterload), as well as decreased central venous pressure and pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (preload). The drop in afterload, together with a compensatory increase in heart rate, leads to elevated cardiac output (CO). Although CO may decrease in the decompensation stage due to myocardial ischemia, this is unlikely in a patient with new onset of symptoms. Patients with septic shock often present with warm, flushed skin as a result of this pathophysiology (see “Typical hemodynamic parameters of types of shock” table).

The most important initial steps in the management of septic shock are aggressive fluid resuscitation with crystalloids and the early administration of empiric antibiotic therapy. Vasopressors should be added if there is no improvement with intravenous fluid management.

This profile suggests cardiogenic shock, which results from any process that significantly decreases cardiac output. It is generally characterized either as obstructive shock (due to cardiac tamponade, massive pulmonary embolism, tension pneumothorax, etc.) versus non-obstructive shock (due to acute myocardial infarction, acute heart failure, arrhythmia, valvular heart disease, etc). In response to the decrease in cardiac output, there is increase in SVR. Poor forward flow leads to increases in PCWP and CVP. In cardiogenic shock, patients will have cold, clammy skin on exam. This patient has no historical or examination elements to suggest a cardiogenic etiology of her presentation.

This hemodynamic profile is most consistent with an increase in overall sympathetic tone, such as secondary to sympathomimetic drug ingestion or recreational drug use (cocaine, amphetamines, etc). This patient's presentation and vital signs are not consistent with this answer, as she does not have evidence of hypertension but is hypotensive on exam.

This profile suggests hypovolemic shock, which is shock related to loss of intravascular fluid. It is most often due to hemorrhage (often referred to as hemorrhagic shock). To maintain tissue perfusion, there is a compensatory tachycardia and increase in SVR. Despite these responses, there is an overall decrease in CVP, PCWP, as well as reduced stroke volume and cardiac output. On exam these patients will have cold and clammy skin. The patient described here has no history suggestive of significant blood loss.

question_text: A 36-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital for the evaluation of progressive breathlessness. She has no history of major medical illness. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 115/min, and respirations are 22/min. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 99%. Cardiac examination shows a loud S_1 and S_2. There is a grade 2/6 early systolic murmur best heard in the 2^nd right intercostal space. Cardiac catheterization shows a mixed venous oxygen saturation of 55% (N = 65–70). Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's breathlessness?
content_preview: A 36-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital for the evaluation of progressive breathlessness. She has no history of major medical illness. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 115/min, and respirations are 22/min. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 99%. Cardiac examination shows a loud S1 and S2. There is a grade 2/6 early systolic murmur best heard in the 2nd right intercostal space. Cardiac catheterization shows a mixed venous oxygen saturation of 55% (N = 65–70). Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's breathlessness?
hint: Mixed oxygen venous saturation (SvO_2) is the oxygen saturation in the pulmonary artery. This is a measure of the oxygen content in the venous system compared to pulse oximetry, which is often used as a surrogate for arterial hemoglobin saturation (S_aO_2)
learning_objective: Recognize severe anemia as a cause of dyspnea.

answers.explanation_why: Carbon dioxide retention is increased in hypoventilation or lung disease and can cause dyspnea, tachycardia, and occasionally, evidence of hyperdynamic circulation (e.g., loud S_1/S_2, ejection systolic murmur). A low mixed venous oxygen saturation can be seen during an exacerbation of lung disease or extreme hypoventilation. However, oxygen saturation on pulse oximetry would also be low.

Severe aortic stenosis, which causes a decreased left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF), can present with dyspnea, a soft S_2, a systolic murmur in the 2^nd right intercostal space (aortic area), and a decreased mixed venous oxygen saturation due to decreased cardiac output and increased tissue O_2 extraction. However, aortic stenosis produces a mid-to-late systolic murmur instead of the early murmur in this patient and it does not explain this patient's loud S_1. In this patient with evidence of hyperdynamic circulation, the LVEF would most likely be increased.

Increased peripheral shunting due to AV fistulas can present with tachycardia and evidence of hyperdynamic circulation (e.g., loud S_1/S_2, ejection systolic murmur). However, shunting would cause the oxygenated blood to bypass the tissues and enter the veins, leading to an increase in mixed venous oxygen saturation, not a decrease.

Increased pulmonary vascular resistance is seen in pulmonary hypertension, which can cause a loud S_2 in the second intercostal space as well as a decreased mixed venous oxygen saturation (S_vO_2). However, the loud S_2 would be due to a loud P_2 and would, therefore, be heard best at the left 2^nd intercostal space (pulmonary area). Moreover, if S_vO_2 was decreased in a patient with pulmonary hypertension, the oxygen saturation would also be decreased. Also, pulmonary hypertension alone does not explain the loud S_1 and the murmur in this patient.

Dyspnea, tachycardia, and evidence of hyperdynamic circulation (e.g., loud S_1/S_2, systolic ejection murmur due to increased blood flow) are features of severe anemia. In patients with anemia, the arterial partial pressure of oxygen (P_aO_2), which reflects dissolved oxygen content, and the arterial hemoglobin oxygen saturation (S_aO_2) remain normal. However, the total arterial oxygen content (C_aO_2), which is given by the formula [1.34 x S_aO_2 x hemoglobin concentration] + [0.003 x P_aO_2]), would be decreased because the total hemoglobin concentration is decreased. Therefore, the amount of oxygen delivered to tissues (DO_2) is decreased and tissues extract more oxygen per gram of hemoglobin in order to meet the metabolic demands (VO_2). This results in a decreased hemoglobin oxygen saturation in venous blood, which is measured by S_vO_2.
answers.explanation_but: Other causes of decreased S_vO_2 include decreased DO_2 due to hypoxemia caused by a lung disease, increased tissue O_2 extraction due to decreased cardiac output (e.g., heart failure, hypovolemic shock), increased VO_2 (e.g., exercise, high fever, seizures), and an inability of hemoglobin to bind to O_2 (e.g., carbon monoxide poisoning). If S_vO_2 is decreased as a result of decreased cardiac output or increased VO_2, S_aO_2 would usually be normal. However, pulse oximetry may erroneously show a decreased oxygen saturation in the case of decreased cardiac output because of poor peripheral circulation. If S_vO_2 is decreased as a result of lung disease or carbon monoxide poisoning, S_aO_2 would also be decreased. However, pulse oximetry may erroneously show a normal oxygen saturation in the case of carbon monoxide poisoning because carboxyhemoglobin has a cherry red color. Estimation of true S_aO_2 requires arterial blood gas analysis.

question_text:
A 54-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of high fever and confusion for the past 10 hours. His wife reports that 1 week ago during a trip to Guatemala he underwent an emergency appendectomy. His temperature is 40.1°C (104.2°F), pulse is 132/min, and blood pressure is 74/46 mm Hg. He is oriented only to person. Physical examination shows a surgical wound in the right lower quadrant with purulent discharge. The skin is warm and dry. Serum studies show a sodium concentration of 138 mEq/L, potassium concentration of 3.7 mEq/L, and lactate concentration of 3.5 mEq/L (N = 0.5–2.2). Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:

pH
7.21

PCO_2
36 mm Hg

HCO_3^-
14 mEq/L

O_2 saturation
87%

Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these laboratory changes?
content_preview: A 54-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of high fever and confusion for the past 10 hours. His wife reports that 1 week ago during a trip to Guatemala he underwent an emergency appendectomy. His temperature is 40.1°C (104.2°F), pulse is 132/min, and blood pressure is 74/46 mm Hg. He is oriented only to person. Physical examination shows a surgical wound in the right lower quadrant with purulent discharge. The skin is warm and dry. Serum studies show a sodium concentration of 138 mEq/L, potassium concentration of 3.7 mEq/L, and lactate concentration of 3.5 mEq/L (N = 0.5–2.2). Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows: pH 7.21 PCO2 36 mm Hg HCO3- 14 mEq/L O2 saturation 87% Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these laboratory changes?
hint: This patient has clinical features of septic shock (e.g., fever, tachycardia, hypotension, warm and dry skin) due to infection of his appendectomy surgical site. His metabolic acidosis is likely due to the accumulation of lactic acid from septic shock. Assess for appropriate compensation using the Winter formula: expected pCO_2  = (1.5 x HCO_3^-) + 8 (± 2).
learning_objective: Recognize respiratory fatigue in septic shock.

answers.explanation_why: Hyperventilation results in respiratory alkalosis, which manifests with a lower-than-expected pCO_2. This patient's pCO_2 is higher than predicted by the Winter formula.

Patients with primary adrenal insufficiency who experience an acute stressor, such as a serious infection, have an increased risk of developing shock as a result of adrenal crisis. However, primary adrenal insufficiency typically causes hyponatremia and hyperkalemia (due to hypoaldosteronism), which are not seen here. Additionally, this patient's pCO_2 is higher than predicted by the Winter formula, which indicates a secondary acid-base disturbance. Primary adrenal insufficiency would not cause this secondary disturbance.

Salicylate toxicity typically presents with hyperthermia, altered mental status, and metabolic acidosis. However, salicylates also cause respiratory alkalosis (due to increased respiratory rate resulting from activation of the respiratory center of the medulla), which manifests with a lower-than-expected pCO_2 value. This patient's pCO_2, however, is higher than predicted by the Winter formula.

Per the Winter formula, a pCO_2  of 27–31 mm Hg would reflect an appropriate respiratory compensation for this patient's metabolic acidosis. Instead, this patient's pCO_2 is 36 mm Hg, which indicates the presence of a respiratory acidosis in addition to the metabolic acidosis. Respiratory acidosis is caused by hypoventilation (e.g., from respiratory fatigue in critically ill patients), which leads to CO_2 retention.

Diabetic ketoacidosis can cause hypotension and altered mental status, as seen in this patient, and is often precipitated by an infection. DKA is the initial manifestation of type 1 diabetes mellitus in approximately 30% of cases. However, hallmark symptoms of DKA (e.g., polyuria, polydipsia, nausea, and vomiting) are not seen here. Also, this patient's pCO_2 is higher than the Winter formula would predict. DKA often manifests with hyperventilation, which leads to a lower-than-expected pCO_2.

question_text:
A 47-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after his neighbor found him collapsed on his front porch in a pool of vomitus. On arrival, he is oriented only to self. His pulse is 103/min and respirations are 30/min. Neurologic examination shows muscle spasms in the arms and jaw. Serum studies show:

Na^+

137 mEq/L

Cl^-

99 mEq/L

HCO_3^-

8 mEq/L

Osmolality
328 mOsmol/kg H_2O

The difference between the calculated and observed serum osmolality is 32 mOsmol/kg H_2O. Urinalysis shows oxalate crystals. This patient is most likely experiencing toxicity from which of the following substances?
content_preview: A 47-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after his neighbor found him collapsed on his front porch in a pool of vomitus. On arrival, he is oriented only to self. His pulse is 103/min and respirations are 30/min. Neurologic examination shows muscle spasms in the arms and jaw. Serum studies show: Na+ 137 mEq/L Cl- 99 mEq/L HCO3- 8 mEq/L Osmolality 328 mOsmol/kg H2O The difference between the calculated and observed serum osmolality is 32 mOsmol/kg H2O. Urinalysis shows oxalate crystals. This patient is most likely experiencing toxicity from which of the following substances?
hint: This patient presents with acute encephalopathy, signs of tetany (muscle spasms), and hyperventilation. His laboratory studies are notable for an elevated anion gap AG = 137 - (99 + 8) = 30 and an elevated osmolar gap (32 mOsmol/kg H_2O). The presence of oxalate crystals in the urine indicates that he ingested a substance that is metabolized to oxalate.
learning_objective: Recognize ethylene glycol toxicity, and recall its metabolic products.

answers.explanation_why: Methanol is an alcohol that is metabolized to formate, a toxic substance that can cause end-organ damage. Although methanol poisoning would explain many of this man's symptoms (anion gap, altered mental status, increased serum osmolar gap), the key distinguishing feature in this patient is the formation of urine oxalate crystals, which is not seen with methanol toxicity.
answers.explanation_but: Methanol poisoning classically causes optic neuropathy with resulting optic disc hyperemia (blurred vision or blindness).

answers.explanation_why: Ethylene glycol is enzymatically oxidized by alcohol dehydrogenase, then aldehyde dehydrogenase, to form oxalate, glyoxylate, and glycolate. These metabolites collect in the renal system and are detectable in the urine as oxalate crystals, which can cause flank pain, hematuria, oliguria, and acute kidney injury. Hypocalcemia, the cause of this patient's tetany, is a result of calcium being consumed by oxalate to form calcium oxalate. Other signs of ethylene glycol poisoning include altered mental status and tachypnea (due to respiratory compensation for metabolic acidosis). Treatment of ethylene glycol poisoning consists of fomepizole to competitively inhibit alcohol dehydrogenase, as ethylene glycol itself is not nearly as toxic as its metabolites.

Parathion is an organophosphate that can cause cholinergic toxicity. Although this patient's altered mental status and vomiting may also be seen in organophosphate poisoning, oxalate crystals would not be seen. Additionally, he lacks the other classic symptoms of cholinergic toxicity (e.g., miosis, bradycardia, and diaphoresis), which makes this an unlikely cause of his symptoms.

Isopropyl alcohol ingestion can cause altered mental status and elevated osmolar gap, which are seen in this patient. However, it would not explain the elevated anion gap or oxalate crystals in the urine.

Aspirin toxicity can cause altered mental status, vomiting, tachypnea, and an anion gap, which is similar to this patient's presentation. However, this condition would not explain the urine oxalate crystals.
answers.explanation_but: Aspirin toxicity causes early respiratory alkalosis because the drug stimulates the respiratory center of the CNS, resulting in tachypnea. It then causes late elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis because the drug itself is acidic.

question_text: A 54-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up appointment. Three weeks ago he underwent emergency cardiac catheterization because of myocardial infarction. He was hospitalized longer than expected because of decreased kidney function. The patient says his symptoms have since improved greatly. He is now urinating significantly more than before the procedure. His serum creatinine concentration is 1.6 mg/dL and blood urea nitrogen concentration is 20 mg/dL. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications?
content_preview: A 54-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up appointment. Three weeks ago he underwent emergency cardiac catheterization because of myocardial infarction. He was hospitalized longer than expected because of decreased kidney function. The patient says his symptoms have since improved greatly. He is now urinating significantly more than before the procedure. His serum creatinine concentration is 1.6 mg/dL and blood urea nitrogen concentration is 20 mg/dL. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications?
hint: This patient has most likely developed acute kidney injury (AKI) as a result of contrast-induced nephropathy (due to cardiac catheterization) and possibly renal ischemia due to myocardial infarction. The onset of polyuria three weeks after the development of AKI is consistent with the polyuric phase of AKI.
learning_objective: Recognize the polyuric phase of acute kidney injury, and recall its associated electrolyte abnormalities.

answers.explanation_why: Three weeks after exposure to contrast, this patient is in the polyuric phase of AKI and is actually at risk for hypomagnesemia, rather than hypermagnesemia. During this period, patients lose several electrolytes that are normally reabsorbed by the tubules, including magnesium, into the urine.

Three weeks after exposure to contrast, this patient is in the polyuric phase of AKI. During this period, patients have difficulty excreting H^+ ions and regenerating bicarbonate (a function of the tubular system), putting them at risk for metabolic acidosis, rather than alkalosis.

Three weeks after exposure to contrast, this patient is in the polyuric phase of AKI and is actually at risk for hyponatremia, rather than hypernatremia. During this period, patients lose several electrolytes that are normally reabsorbed by the tubules, including sodium, into the urine.

Patients with AKI usually regain full glomerular filtration function approx. 2 weeks after the inciting event, while tubular reabsorption remains impaired, which results in increased urine production and consequent polyuria. The polyuric phase of AKI is characterized by the loss of several electrolytes that are normally reabsorbed by the tubules, including potassium, sodium, and magnesium.

Patients in the polyuric phase of AKI are at risk for volume depletion, a state in which GFR and sodium delivery to the distal nephrons decreases, causing the release of renin. Therefore, this patient would actually have an increase in renin release.

question_text: Seventy-two hours after admission for an acute myocardial infarction, a 48-year-old man develops dyspnea and a productive cough with frothy sputum. Physical examination shows coarse crackles in both lungs and a blowing, holosystolic murmur heard best at the apex. ECG shows Q waves in the anteroseptal leads. Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure is 23 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s current condition?
content_preview: Seventy-two hours after admission for an acute myocardial infarction, a 48-year-old man develops dyspnea and a productive cough with frothy sputum. Physical examination shows coarse crackles in both lungs and a blowing, holosystolic murmur heard best at the apex. ECG shows Q waves in the anteroseptal leads. Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure is 23 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s current condition?
hint: This patient's new murmur (blowing, holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex) and evidence of heart failure (dyspnea, bilateral crackles, elevated capillary wedge pressure) suggest acute mitral regurgitation.
learning_objective: Recognize rupture of the chordae tendinae post-myocardial infarction.

answers.explanation_why: Postmyocardial infarction syndrome is a type of pericarditis that arises from an autoimmune reaction to exposed myocardial antigens after acute MI. Patients present with dyspnea, tachypnea, and tachycardia. However, this syndrome would manifest 2–10 weeks after an MI rather than 72 hours as seen in this patient. Furthermore, fever is usually present, cardiac auscultation would reveal a pericardial friction rub, and ECG would show ST elevations in all leads.

Aortic root dilation can occur in postinfarction fibrinous pericarditis, which commonly manifests 1–3 days after MI. Patients with aortic root dilation present with features of aortic regurgitation. These patients have diastolic, not systolic, murmurs. Moreover, this patient is missing other symptoms of pericarditis, such as chest pain and a friction rub.

Chordae tendinae or papillary muscle rupture most commonly occurs 2–7 days after acute myocardial infarction and is due to extensive coagulative necrosis and the formation of granulation tissue at the area of infarction. This patient's localization of Q waves in the anteroseptal leads (e.g., V1–V4) suggests an infarction of the left anterior descending artery, which supplies the anterolateral papillary muscle. Acute mitral regurgitation can lead to signs of heart failure, as seen in this patient. The posteromedial papillary muscle is supplied only by the posterior descending artery and is at especially high risk of ischemia due to lack of collateral supply.

images.title: Timeline of most common post myocardial infarction complications

answers.content: Rupture of the ventricular free wall
answers.explanation_why: Ventricular wall rupture can occur within 2 weeks of myocardial infarction and typically results in hemopericardium and cardiac tamponade, which can manifest with profound right heart failure, shock, and often death. While free wall rupture and cardiac tamponade can also cause acute pulmonary edema, additional expected findings would include pulsus paradoxus and muffled heart sounds, none of which is observed in this patient.

Rupture of the interventricular septum may occur within the first 2 weeks after MI and typically presents with sudden hemodynamic instability (hypotension, tachycardia), dyspnea, and new-onset holosystolic murmur. However, because blood is shunted from left to right, patients typically present with signs of right heart failure (e.g., increased JVP, peripheral edema) rather than the signs of isolated left heart failure (e.g., pulmonary edema, elevated PCWP) seen here. Moreover, the expected murmur would be heard best over the left sternal border, not the apex.

question_text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of acute left-sided chest pain and dyspnea following a motor vehicle accident. His pulse is 122/min and blood pressure is 85/45 mm Hg. Physical examination shows distended neck veins and tracheal displacement to the right side. The left chest is hyperresonant to percussion and there are decreased breath sounds. This patient would most benefit from needle insertion at which of the following anatomical sites?
content_preview: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of acute left-sided chest pain and dyspnea following a motor vehicle accident. His pulse is 122/min and blood pressure is 85/45 mm Hg. Physical examination shows distended neck veins and tracheal displacement to the right side. The left chest is hyperresonant to percussion and there are decreased breath sounds. This patient would most benefit from needle insertion at which of the following anatomical sites?
hint: This pediatric patient presents with acute respiratory distress, hemodynamic instability, a hyperresonant chest with reduced ipsilateral expansion, contralateral tracheal deviation, and distended neck veins after sustaining trauma, which is consistent with a tension pneumothorax.
learning_objective: Recognize tension pneumothorax, and choose the correct anatomical site for needle decompression.

answers.content: 2nd left intercostal space along the midclavicular line
answers.explanation_why:
The 2^nd left intercostal space along the midclavicular line is the recommended needle insertion site for emergency decompression of a tension pneumothorax in a child. The patient here is unstable with hypotension and tachycardia, so the pneumothorax should be decompressed as quickly as possible. Since the neurovascular bundle runs below each rib, the upper edge of the rib is the preferred puncture site to help mitigate the risk of excessive bleeding and nerve damage. Emergency needle thoracostomy should be followed by chest tube placement in the 5^th intercostal space along the midaxillary line.

According to the Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS) guidelines, the 2^nd left intercostal space along the midclavicular line is no longer the preferred needle insertion site for emergency decompression of a tension pneumothorax in adults. This location is associated with high failure rates because of increased anterior chest wall thickness. Instead, placing the needle in the 5^th left intercostal space along the midaxillary line is preferable.

images.title: Thoracostomy sites
images.description: The 2^nd intercostal space, located at the midclavicular line (1; orange marker), can be used in both adults and children for emergency needle thoracostomy to decompress a tension pneumothorax.The 4^th or 5^th intercostal space, between the anterior and midaxillary lines (2; blue marker), is the standard site for tube thoracostomy in both adults and children and in adults may also be used for needle thoracostomy.

answers.content: 5th left intercostal space along the midaxillary line
answers.explanation_why: The 5^th left intercostal space along the midaxillary line is a common site for a chest tube placement to treat pleural effusions, hemothorax, or pneumothorax in both children and adults. Although the Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS) guidelines also recommend this insertion site for emergency needle decompression of a tension pneumothorax in adults, a different site is recommended in children.

answers.content: 8th left intercostal space along the posterior axillary line
answers.explanation_why: The 8^th left intercostal space along the posterior axillary line is a possible location to perform a thoracocentesis, which may be necessary in patients with pleural effusion. Although pleural effusion also manifests with acute respiratory distress, reduced ipsilateral chest expansion, and contralateral tracheal deviation as seen here, it causes dullness to percussion, not hyperresonance.

answers.content: Subxiphoid space in the left sternocostal margin
answers.explanation_why: The subxiphoid space in the left sternocostal margin is the typical puncture site for performing a pericardiocentesis. Tachycardia, hypotension, and distended neck veins can also be seen in pericardial tamponade. However, decreased breath sounds and hyperresonance on percussion of the left lung are not features of pericardial tamponade.

answers.content: 5th left intercostal space along the midclavicular line
answers.explanation_why: The apex of the heart is located behind the 5^th left intercostal space along the midclavicular line. This puncture site is not recommended because of the high risk of damaging the heart. In addition, needle insertion at this site does not provide decompression of a tension pneumothorax.

question_text:
Four days after admission to the hospital for acute pancreatitis, a 41-year-old man develops hypotension and fever. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.3°F), pulse is 115/min, and blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows warm extremities, asymmetric calf size, and blood oozing around his IV sites. There are numerous small, red, nonblanching macules and patches covering the extremities, as well as several large ecchymoses. His hemoglobin concentration is 9.0 g/dL. A peripheral blood smear shows schistocytes and decreased platelets. Which of the following sets of serum findings are most likely in this patient?

Prothrombin time
Partial thromboplastin time
Fibrinogen
D-dimer

A
Increased
increased
decreased
normal

B
Normal
normal
normal
normal

C
Increased
increased
decreased
increased

D
Normal
increased
normal
normal

E
Normal
normal
normal
increased
content_preview: Four days after admission to the hospital for acute pancreatitis, a 41-year-old man develops hypotension and fever. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.3°F), pulse is 115/min, and blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows warm extremities, asymmetric calf size, and blood oozing around his IV sites. There are numerous small, red, nonblanching macules and patches covering the extremities, as well as several large ecchymoses. His hemoglobin concentration is 9.0 g/dL. A peripheral blood smear shows schistocytes and decreased platelets. Which of the following sets of serum findings are most likely in this patient? Prothrombin time Partial thromboplastin time Fibrinogen D-dimer A Increased increased decreased normal B Normal normal normal normal C Increased increased decreased increased D Normal increased normal normal E Normal normal normal increased
hint: This patient has vital signs consistent with sepsis (e.g., fever, hypotension, tachycardia) from his acute pancreatitis, signs of bleeding dysfunction (e.g., blood oozing around IV sites, petechiae, and ecchymoses), and peripheral blood smear findings of schistocytes and thrombocytopenia. These findings are consistent with a diagnosis of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

answers.explanation_why: These serum findings are most consistent with liver disease, such as cirrhosis. Cirrhosis is caused by chronic damage to the liver parenchyma and manifests with impaired liver function, which can cause decreased production of coagulation factors. As a result, patients can develop a bleeding diathesis (e.g., blood oozing around IV sites, prolonged PT and PTT). However, cirrhosis typically also causes other manifestations, such as jaundice, asterixis, spider angiomata, and ascites. This patient's acute presentation is most consistent with DIC, which results in a different set of serum findings.

These serum findings are normal but could be seen in patients with thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura or hemolytic uremic syndrome (TTP/HUS). This spectrum of conditions is characterized by the formation of microthrombi that occlude the microvasculature and can manifest with fevers, petechiae, purpura, mucosal bleeding, and schistocytes and thrombocytopenia on peripheral blood smear. However, this condition typically also causes neurologic symptoms (e.g., altered mental status, delirium, or seizures) and impaired renal function. This patient's acute presentation is most consistent with DIC, which results in a different set of serum findings.

These serum findings are most consistent with DIC as evidenced by increased prothrombin time (PT), partial thromboplastin time (PTT), and D-dimer. DIC is a disorder characterized by systemic activation of the clotting cascade with microthrombi formation, which results in the exhaustion of all clotting factors. Microthrombi precipitate microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, which results in schistocytes on peripheral blood smear. The depletion of clotting factors prolongs the PT and PTT. Fibrinogen is activated in the clotting cascade to become fibrin; thus, a decrease in fibrinogen is expected in patients with DIC.

These serum findings are most consistent with heparin use. Heparin is an anticoagulant used routinely for the prevention and treatment of venous thromboembolism. Heparin indirectly inhibits thrombin and factor Xa, which increases partial thromboplastin time. Complications of heparin administration include bleeding and heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). However, this patient has additional clinical manifestations that are not caused by complications of heparin therapy, including acute-onset fever, hypotension, tachycardia, and schistocytes on peripheral blood smear. Moreover, HIT typically develops 5–14 days after initiation of heparin therapy. This patient's acute presentation is most consistent with DIC, which results in a different set of serum findings.

These serum findings are most consistent with deep venous thrombosis (DVT), an obstruction of a vein by a blood clot. DVT most commonly occurs in the legs and can result in asymmetrical calf size. Pulmonary embolism (PE), a serious complication of DVT, can manifest with fevers, tachycardia, and hypotension. However, neither of these conditions results in bleeding or thrombocytopenia. This patient's acute presentation is most consistent with DIC, which results in a different set of serum findings.
