question_text: A 34-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by paramedics 30 minutes after he sustained a stab wound to the left chest during an attempted robbery. On arrival, he is alert and oriented to person and place, but not time. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a knife in situ that enters the thoracic wall just above the 7^th rib in the left midaxillary line. The right lung is clear to auscultation; auscultation of the left lung and cardiac examination remain inconclusive as the patient does not tolerate being examined near the entrance wound. Abdominal examination shows mild diffuse abdominal pain without guarding or rebound. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Five minutes later, the patient becomes unresponsive. Repeat vital signs are temperature 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse 120/min, respirations 28/min, and blood pressure 88/50 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 34-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by paramedics 30 minutes after he sustained a stab wound to the left chest during an attempted robbery. On arrival, he is alert and oriented to person and place, but not time. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a knife in situ that enters the thoracic wall just above the 7th rib in the left midaxillary line. The right lung is clear to auscultation; auscultation of the left lung and cardiac examination remain inconclusive as the patient does not tolerate being examined near the entrance wound. Abdominal examination shows mild diffuse abdominal pain without guarding or rebound. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Five minutes later, the patient becomes unresponsive. Repeat vital signs are temperature 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse 120/min, respirations 28/min, and blood pressure 88/50 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient has sustained penetrating chest trauma, which can result in a number of potentially life-threatening conditions (e.g., pneumothorax, hemothorax, hemopericardium, hemoperitoneum, organ laceration). Since the patient has become hemodynamically unstable (hypotension, tachycardia), speed and comprehensiveness in assessing and treating the underlying condition are essential.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate diagnostic test for a hemodynamically unstable patient with penetrating chest trauma.

answers.explanation_why: Emergency tube thoracostomy is the treatment of choice when hemodynamic instability is caused by tension pneumothorax or hemothorax. Tube thoracostomy should only be performed prior to establishing the diagnosis if there is strong clinical suspicion for the underlying condition (e.g., absent breath sounds on auscultation and hyperresonance to percussion in a patient with pneumothorax). This patient's auscultation findings remain inconclusive, so tube thoracostomy is not indicated at this point.

answers.content: Extended focused assessment with sonography in trauma (eFAST)
answers.explanation_why: Extended focused assessment with sonography in trauma (eFAST) is typically used during the primary ABCDE survey and subsequent reassessments of patients with penetrating chest trauma to establish a diagnosis and guide management. eFAST is especially useful for hemodynamically unstable patients because it is fast, comprehensive (includes views of the heart and both hemithoraces to detect cardiac tamponade, hemothorax, and/or pneumothorax), and can be discontinued at any point. In cases of hemodynamic instability where there is a strong clinical suspicion of cardiac tamponade (e.g., muffled heart sounds, distended neck veins) or tension pneumothorax (e.g., absent breath sounds, hyperresonance to percussion on the ipsilateral side), emergency pericardiocentesis or tube thoracostomy, respectively, should not be delayed by imaging.

Pericardiocentesis is the treatment of choice for cardiac tamponade, which can result from penetrating chest trauma and manifest with hemodynamic instability. Pericardiocentesis should only be performed prior to establishing the diagnosis if there is strong clinical suspicion for this condition (e.g., muffled heart sounds on auscultation, distended jugular veins). This patient's cardiac auscultation remains inconclusive, so pericardiocentesis is not indicated at this point.

answers.content: Removal of the knife with direct pressure on the wound
answers.explanation_why: Penetrating objects often tamponade the wound, so removal can cause further hemorrhage. Removal should therefore only be performed in settings where definitive care is possible (i.e., by a surgeon in an operating room), preferably not in the emergency department.

answers.content: CT scan of the chest and abdomen
answers.explanation_why: CT scan of the chest and abdomen can be used to assess patients with penetrating chest trauma. It is important to consider concomitant intraabdominal injuries in cases of penetrating trauma below the nipples, which this patient has. However, CT scans should not be performed on hemodynamically unstable patients who are at risk of further deterioration while undergoing the scan.

question_text: A 75-year-old man who is being treated in the hospital for new-onset congestive heart failure alerts his nurse because he is feeling unwell. He reports feeling dizzy and nauseous and that he had to lie down again after trying to stand up to go to the bathroom. He says that his symptoms began 30 minutes after he was brought back to the ward from the radiology department, where he underwent a CT scan of the chest to evaluate an incidental pulmonary nodule found on chest x-ray. Medical history is remarkable for coronary artery disease and hypertension. After admission, bisoprolol therapy was temporarily discontinued and he was started on furosemide. His other medications are aspirin, lisinopril, and atorvastatin. The physician on call takes the patient’s vital signs and measures a pulse of 138/min and blood pressure of 95/70 mm Hg. Further investigation reveals that the changes in the patient's pulse and blood pressure were not detected despite continuous cardiac telemetry being a part of the patient's admission orders. Which of the following is the most likely cause for the error that occurred in this scenario?
content_preview: A 75-year-old man who is being treated in the hospital for new-onset congestive heart failure alerts his nurse because he is feeling unwell. He reports feeling dizzy and nauseous and that he had to lie down again after trying to stand up to go to the bathroom. He says that his symptoms began 30 minutes after he was brought back to the ward from the radiology department, where he underwent a CT scan of the chest to evaluate an incidental pulmonary nodule found on chest x-ray. Medical history is remarkable for coronary artery disease and hypertension. After admission, bisoprolol therapy was temporarily discontinued and he was started on furosemide. His other medications are aspirin, lisinopril, and atorvastatin. The physician on call takes the patient’s vital signs and measures a pulse of 138/min and blood pressure of 95/70 mm Hg. Further investigation reveals that the changes in the patient's pulse and blood pressure were not detected despite continuous cardiac telemetry being a part of the patient's admission orders. Which of the following is the most likely cause for the error that occurred in this scenario?
hint: Cardiac telemetry can interfere with the image quality of chest CT scans by causing a beam hardening artifact.
learning_objective: Recognize the common causes of inpatient cardiac telemetry-related errors.

answers.content: Failure at the patient-telemetry device interface
answers.explanation_why: When humans interact with medical equipment, three types of errors occur: human errors, device errors, and errors at the level of the device-human interface. Failure at the level of the device-human interface (e.g., disconnection of the patient from or improper connection of the patient to the telemetry device) is the most common cause of inpatient cardiac telemetry-related errors (approx. 50% of cases) and typically occurs after patients are shifted (e.g., for a test). Less common causes of inpatient cardiac telemetry-related errors are equipment malfunction (25%), communication breakdown (20%), and alarm fatigue (5%). Cardiac telemetry-related errors rarely cause patients to be harmed, but when they do, the consequences are dire with death as the most frequent outcome. Measures that can be taken to prevent such errors include checklists and standardization for inpatient transfers, regular telemetry equipment checks, forcing functions that prevent alarms from being turned down, and redirection of low-level alarms to telemetry technicians to prevent alarm fatigue in nurses.

Poor communication between healthcare providers about cardiac telemetry events (e.g., when nurses or telemetry technicians fail to notify physicians about alarms) can lead to adequate care being delayed or not initiated at all after an event has been detected. However, poor communication is not the most common cause of inpatient cardiac telemetry-related errors. A different cause is much more likely in this scenario, in which the cardiac event occurred soon after the patient returned to the ward.

answers.content: Desensitization to alarms from the telemetry device
answers.explanation_why: Desensitization of health care providers to alarms from the telemetry device (i.e., alarm fatigue) can lead to cardiac events going undetected but is an uncommon cause of inpatient cardiac telemetry-related errors.

Malfunctioning of the cardiac telemetry device (e.g., due to empty batteries in the case of a portable device) can lead to cardiac events going undetected but is not the most common cause of inpatient cardiac telemetry-related errors. A different cause is much more likely in this scenario, in which the cardiac event occurred soon after the patient returned to the ward.

question_text: A 52-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for treatment of a meningioma located in the posterior fossa. During surgery, the anesthesiologist notices a sudden fall in end-tidal carbon dioxide. Pulse is 115/min and blood pressure is 80/55 mm Hg. Oxygen saturation is 88%. Examination shows jugular venous distension, and a churning sound in the precordial region is heard throughout the cardiac cycle. On pulmonary examination, scattered crackles are heard bilaterally and there are occasional diffuse wheezes. In addition to high-flow oxygen and intravenous fluids, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 52-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for treatment of a meningioma located in the posterior fossa. During surgery, the anesthesiologist notices a sudden fall in end-tidal carbon dioxide. Pulse is 115/min and blood pressure is 80/55 mm Hg. Oxygen saturation is 88%. Examination shows jugular venous distension, and a churning sound in the precordial region is heard throughout the cardiac cycle. On pulmonary examination, scattered crackles are heard bilaterally and there are occasional diffuse wheezes. In addition to high-flow oxygen and intravenous fluids, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: A churning sound in the precordial region (also known as the mill-wheel murmur) is consistent with air in the heart chambers. This finding is characteristic of venous air embolism. Other common features of this condition include sudden hypotension, tachycardia, jugular vein distension, signs of respiratory distress, and, in patients who are being mechanically ventilated, a sudden fall in end-tidal carbon dioxide.
learning_objective: Recognize venous air embolism, and choose the most appropriate initial management step.

answers.content: Place the patient in the left lateral decubitus position
answers.explanation_why: Venous air embolism develops when air enters the venous circulation. This can occur during neurosurgical procedures, especially those that require the patient to be in a sitting position. In this position, the negative (subatmospheric) pressure of the cranial veins due to them being at a higher level than the heart can result in air being sucked into the cranial veins. Other causes of venous air embolism include vascular interventions (e.g., insertion or removal of central venous catheters), penetrating lung injuries, and barotrauma. Management procedures depend on the suspected site of embolism and include compression of the suspected entry site, correction of hypoxia and hypotension, and placing the patient in a head-down position (e.g., Trendelenburg position) or in the left lateral decubitus position (Durant maneuver), both of which help trap the air emboli in the right ventricular apex and therefore prevent further obstruction of the pulmonary outflow tract. If the patient remains unstable following these procedures, direct aspiration of air through a central venous catheter may be considered.

images.title: Air in the right ventricle
images.description: CT chest (with contrast; mediastinal window; coronal plane) of a patient with polytrauma from a motor vehicle crashA large amount of air is seen within the right ventricle (green overlay). The air was inadvertently injected during the transfusion of blood products.L: liver; LV: left ventricle; S: sternum; white arrow: contrast

answers.explanation_why: Blood products are indicated in hemorrhagic shock, which can manifest with tachycardia, hypotension, and a decrease in end-tidal carbon dioxide (due to decreased pulmonary perfusion). However, patients with hemorrhagic shock have flat rather than distended jugular veins due to the underlying decrease in central venous pressure. In addition, a mill-wheel murmur and signs of respiratory distress (hypoxia, crackles and wheezing on auscultation) are not expected in patients with hemorrhagic shock.

Unfractionated heparin should be administered in pulmonary thromboembolism, which can manifest with sudden onset tachycardia, hypotension, jugular vein distension, signs of respiratory distress (e.g., hypoxia), and a decrease in end-tidal carbon dioxide (as a result of a ventilation-perfusion mismatch). However, a mill-wheel murmur indicates the presence of air rather than a thrombus. Anticoagulation is not generally recommended in patients with venous air embolism.

Epinephrine and high-dose corticosteroids are indicated in anaphylactic shock, which can manifest with sudden onset tachycardia, hypotension, signs of respiratory distress (e.g., hypoxia, wheezing), and a decrease in end-tidal carbon dioxide. Many agents used in the operating room (e.g., neuromuscular blocking agents, antibiotics) can lead to anaphylaxis. However, jugular vein distension and a mill-wheel murmur are characteristic of venous air embolism, not anaphylactic shock. Although vasopressors can be used in hemodynamically unstable patients with venous air embolism, steroids are not generally recommended.

Coronary angiography is indicated for patients with suspected myocardial infarction (MI). Cardiogenic shock due to MI can lead to sudden onset tachycardia, hypotension, jugular vein distension, signs of respiratory distress (hypoxia, crackles on auscultation), and a decrease in end-tidal carbon dioxide. However, the presence of the mill-wheel murmur after a neurosurgical procedure of the posterior fossa is inconsistent with cardiogenic shock.

question_text: Two days after being admitted for an ischemic stroke of the left middle cerebral artery, a 74-year-old woman is evaluated for worsening confusion. She received intravenous alteplase therapy and was admitted to the intensive care unit. Twenty-four hours after being admitted, the patient started antiplatelet therapy; she was already able to speak in full sentences and had slightly improved muscle function. While being evaluated by the physical therapist this morning, the patient was confused. Her pulse is 72/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 120/64 mm Hg. She does not respond to verbal commands but withdraws appropriately to painful stimuli. Neurologic examination shows equal and reactive pupils. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: Two days after being admitted for an ischemic stroke of the left middle cerebral artery, a 74-year-old woman is evaluated for worsening confusion. She received intravenous alteplase therapy and was admitted to the intensive care unit. Twenty-four hours after being admitted, the patient started antiplatelet therapy; she was already able to speak in full sentences and had slightly improved muscle function. While being evaluated by the physical therapist this morning, the patient was confused. Her pulse is 72/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 120/64 mm Hg. She does not respond to verbal commands but withdraws appropriately to painful stimuli. Neurologic examination shows equal and reactive pupils. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This condition occurs as a result of reperfusion injury, which leads to endothelial damage and disruption of the blood-brain barrier.
learning_objective: Recognize hemorrhagic transformation as a complication of ischemic stroke treatment.

answers.explanation_why: Hemorrhagic transformation (HT) is a common complication of ischemic stroke and typically manifests with neurologic deterioration (e.g., new confusion, worsening neurological deficits) within 24–48 hours of the inciting ischemic event. The risk of hemorrhagic transformation is significantly increased in patients who have received thrombolytic medications (e.g., alteplase), antiplatelet therapy (e.g., aspirin, clopidogrel), and/or thrombosis prophylaxis (e.g., heparin, enoxaparin). Other risk factors for HT include hyperglycemia, hypertension, advanced age, delayed initiation of reperfusion therapy, and large infarct size. Measures that can reduce the rate of HT include neuroprotective measures (e.g., tight blood pressure and glycemic control, targeted temperature management) and careful preselection of patients eligible for thrombolytic therapy.

Cerebral vasospasm is a complication of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), which typically occurs 4–14 days after the inciting event and would cause neurologic deterioration. Cerebral vasospasm is not, however, a complication of ischemic stroke.

Recurrent ischemic stroke can manifest with neurologic deterioration after a period of stabilization or improvement after ischemic injury. However, this patient has received thrombolytic therapy (alteplase) and has already been started on antiplatelet therapy, both of which significantly reduce the likelihood of recurrent ischemic stroke. A different complication of ischemic stroke is more likely in this patient.

Uncal herniation can manifest with neurologic deterioration but would also cause pupillary changes (e.g., ipsilateral mydriasis) and signs of cardiorespiratory compromise (e.g., bradycardia, apnea), none of which is seen here.

question_text: A 44-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a motor vehicle collision in which he was the unrestrained driver. On arrival, he is unresponsive. A CT scan of the head without contrast shows a massive intracranial hemorrhage. The patient is admitted to the intensive care unit. He is currently intubated and mechanically ventilated and not receiving any paralytic or sedative medications. Temperature is 34.9°C (94.8°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 105/62 mm Hg after intravenous administration of norepinephrine. Neurological examination on admission shows dilated, nonreactive pupils and absent corneal, gag, and cough reflexes. There is no eye movement upon irrigation of the external auditory canal with cold water. A subsequent independent evaluation by another physician is concordant with these findings. Serum concentrations of electrolytes, glucose, urea nitrogen, and creatinine are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most appropriate action at this time?
content_preview: A 44-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a motor vehicle collision in which he was the unrestrained driver. On arrival, he is unresponsive. A CT scan of the head without contrast shows a massive intracranial hemorrhage. The patient is admitted to the intensive care unit. He is currently intubated and mechanically ventilated and not receiving any paralytic or sedative medications. Temperature is 34.9°C (94.8°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 105/62 mm Hg after intravenous administration of norepinephrine. Neurological examination on admission shows dilated, nonreactive pupils and absent corneal, gag, and cough reflexes. There is no eye movement upon irrigation of the external auditory canal with cold water. A subsequent independent evaluation by another physician is concordant with these findings. Serum concentrations of electrolytes, glucose, urea nitrogen, and creatinine are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most appropriate action at this time?
hint: Coma and signs of brainstem areflexia (e.g., dilated, nonreactive pupils and absence of corneal, gag, and cough reflexes) along with radiological evidence of acute, severe damage to the CNS (e.g., massive intracranial hemorrhage) suggest brain death.
learning_objective: Choose the initial step in managing a potential brain death diagnosis.

answers.explanation_why: Apnea testing is an essential part of diagnosing brain death and is typically carried out after all other criteria (e.g., coma, brainstem areflexia) have been met. However, because certain confounding factors can lead to misdiagnosis of brain death, there are prerequisites for apnea testing.

Adequate cerebral perfusion, i.e. systolic blood pressure (SBP) > 100 mm Hg is required for the diagnosis of brain death. If SBP falls below 100 mm Hg, vasopressors (e.g., norepinephrine) should be administered. Discontinuing norepinephrine in this patient may lower SBP and impede clinical judgment.

In order to diagnose brain death, there must be evidence of a specific cause (e.g., massive intracranial hemorrhage), and neurological examination must confirm coma and brainstem areflexia. Although this patient meets these criteria, diagnosis of brain death also requires the absence of confounding factors, and the neurological examination should include apnea testing.

answers.content: Perform a somatosensory evoked potentials test
answers.explanation_why: Somatosensory evoked potentials (SSEP) are ancillary tests for brain death that are only indicated if clinical examination and/or apnea testing are inconclusive or if the patient is younger than one year of age. Ancillary testing is not indicated at this point.

Confounding factors may interfere with brain death assessment and should be corrected before diagnosis. Core body temperature must be > 36.0°C (> 96.8°F) for a minimum of 24 hours because hypothermia may impede neurological assessment and delay the increase in pCO_2 in apnea testing. Normothermia can be achieved by covering the patient with warming blankets and/or administering warm intravenous fluids. Other causes of impaired brain function, such as poisoning, drug intoxication, electrolyte imbalances, and hypotension as well as conditions that can mimic brain death (e.g., locked-in syndrome) should be ruled out and corrected if possible. Systolic blood pressure must be > 100 mm Hg, which may require the administration of vasopressors (e.g., norepinephrine). If these prerequisites are met and patients still present with coma and brainstem areflexia, apnea testing can be performed for a definitive diagnosis of brain death.

question_text:
Patient Information
Age: 57 years
Gender: M, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: emergency department 
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “I think my husband is having a stroke.”
History of Present Illness:

patient brought by his wife, who found him lying on the ground

drooping mouth and difficulty moving the right arm and speaking in grammatically correct, fluent sentences for the past hour
language understanding is unaffected and can communicate with gestures 
pain in the right leg while walking

Past Medical History:

4-year history of Crohn disease; started therapy with infliximab 11 months ago
hospitalized for acute flare with fever, abdominal pain, and malaise 2 weeks ago; treated with oral prednisolone
occasional migraines

Medications:

infliximab
acetaminophen as needed
sumatriptan as needed

Vaccinations:
up-to-date
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family History:

father: diagnosed with Crohn disease at age 21 years

mother: deceased at age 64 years from myocardial infarction

Psychosocial History:

has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years

does not drink alcoholic beverages, or use nonprescribed medications or other substances

Physical Examination

Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O_2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI

36.9°C
(98.4°F)
90/min
16/min
145/80 mm Hg
98% on RA
185 cm
(6 ft 1 in)
80 kg
(176 lb)
23 kg/m^2

Appearance: alert and oriented; visibly anxious and frustrated
HEENT: PERRLA; gaze dominance to the left; drooping mouth on the right; eyebrows can be lifted and eyelids can be closed completely bilaterally
Neck: no jugular venous distention; no carotid bruit
Pulmonary: clear to auscultation
Cardiac: normal S_1 and S_2 with no murmurs, rubs, or gallops
Abdominal: nondistended; normoactive bowel sounds; soft, nontender
Extremities: swelling, red-purple discoloration, and pain in the right lower extremity on palpation

Neurologic: right upper extremity muscle strength 2/5; right lower extremity muscle strength 3/5; left upper and lower extremity muscle strength 5/5; decreased sensation to light touch and pinprick on the right side (face, arm, and leg)

Diagnostic Studies

Blood

 Hemoglobin
13.6 mg/dL

 WBC
4,500/mm^3

 Platelet count
210,000/mm^3

Serum

 Glucose
110 mg/dL

Diffusion-weighted MRI: hyperintense lesions in the left frontal lobe and temporoparietal junction

Which of the following diagnostic studies is the most appropriate next step to determine the cause of this patient's current symptoms?

right lower extremity muscle strength 3/5; left upper and lower extremity muscle strength 5/5; decreased sensation to light touch and pinprick on the right side (face, arm, and leg) Diagnostic Studies Blood Hemoglobin 13.6 mg/dL WBC 4,500/mm3 Platelet count 210,000/mm3 Serum Glucose 110 mg/dL Diffusion-weighted MRI: hyperintense lesions in the left frontal lobe and temporoparietal junction Which of the following diagnostic studies is the most appropriate next step to determine the cause of this patient's current symptoms?
hint: This patient has risk factors (prolonged immobility due to recent hospitalization, Crohn disease, smoking) and features (swelling, red-purple discoloration of the right leg) of deep venous thrombosis (DVT) and ischemic stroke, suggesting a paradoxical embolism.
learning_objective: Recognize paradoxical embolism, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why: Thrombophilia screening can be considered in patients with unprovoked DVT or recurrent unexplained venous thromboembolism. A single DVT in a patient with multiple risk factors (e.g., prolonged immobility due to recent hospitalization, Crohn disease, smoking) does not warrant thrombophilia screening.

Transcranial Doppler can assess intracranial collateral blood flow and provide real-time bedside monitoring of acute intracranial occlusions. However, ischemic stroke has already been confirmed by diffusion-weighted MRI. Identifying the cause of ischemic stroke is the most appropriate next diagnostic step.

Transthoracic echocardiography with agitated saline is the most appropriate next diagnostic step to evaluate for patent foramen ovale (PFO) showing a right-to-left shunt that increases with the Valsalva maneuver and coughing. PFO occurs in ∼ 25% of individuals and is typically asymptomatic until complications due to right-to-left shunting arise. Transient increases in right atrial pressures allow emboli originating from the venous system (e.g., DVT) to pass directly from the right atrium into the left atrium, and then into the systemic and cerebral arterial circulation. Management of PFO after an embolic stroke includes surgical or percutaneous closure of the defect, antiplatelet agents or anticoagulation, and evaluation for other potential causes of stroke (e.g., arrhythmia, hypercoagulability, endocarditis).

Paradoxical embolism can also be caused by a small atrial septal defect (ASD), which can be asymptomatic but typically manifests with a wide, fixed splitting of the second heart sound on auscultation. Echocardiography is also the first-line modality in the diagnosis of ASD.

images.title: Pathophysiology of paradoxical embolism
images.description: In the presence of a patent foramen ovale, transient increases in right atrial pressure (e.g., when coughing) can allow emboli from the venous system to pass from the right atrium to the left atrium. From there, they can enter systemic arterial circulation and cause arterial embolism (e.g., stroke).

answers.explanation_why: Carotid duplex is indicated for suspected carotid stenosis, which can lead to thrombotic occlusion of the carotid artery or embolic occlusion of the cerebral arteries, resulting in ischemic stroke. However, the absence of a carotid bruit and the presence of DVT indicate paradoxical embolism.

Cardiac MRI is indicated for various cardiac conditions to assess cardiac structure and function. While cardiac MRI can be considered for an embolic stroke of undetermined source to detect intracardiac thrombi and visualize PFO, a more widely available and better tolerated test is more appropriate.

question_text: An 81-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his daughter because of a persistent nosebleed for the past 2 hours. Medical history is significant for hypertension and major depressive disorder. He has not been evaluated by a physician in 1 year. Current medications are lisinopril and sertraline. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 195/115 mm Hg. On mental status examination, he is oriented to person but not to place or time. Physical examination shows active epistaxis. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations show no abnormalities. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, glucose, and creatinine are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the strongest indication for hospital admission in this patient?
content_preview: An 81-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his daughter because of a persistent nosebleed for the past 2 hours. Medical history is significant for hypertension and major depressive disorder. He has not been evaluated by a physician in 1 year. Current medications are lisinopril and sertraline. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 195/115 mm Hg. On mental status examination, he is oriented to person but not to place or time. Physical examination shows active epistaxis. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations show no abnormalities. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, glucose, and creatinine are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the strongest indication for hospital admission in this patient?
hint: This patient's blood pressure of 195/115 mm Hg indicates a hypertensive crisis. One of the indications below determines whether the patient is experiencing a hypertensive emergency.
learning_objective: Recognize hypertensive emergency, and choose the strongest indication for hospital admission.

answers.explanation_why: Hypertensive crisis is defined as systolic blood pressure ≥ 180 mm Hg and/or diastolic blood pressure ≥ 120 mm Hg. Elevated systolic blood pressure alone is not an indication for admission.
Hypertensive crisis is defined as systolic blood pressure ≥ 180 mm Hg and/or diastolic blood pressure ≥ 120 mm Hg. Elevated diastolic blood pressure alone is not an indication for admission.
Although advanced age increases the risk of hospitalization, age alone is not an indication for hospital admission in patients with hypertensive crises.

Although epistaxis is commonly associated with elevated blood pressure, it is a nonspecific symptom. A hypertensive crisis manifesting with an isolated nonspecific symptom is classified as hypertensive urgency and does not require hospital admission.

Patients with hypertensive crises should be immediately evaluated for acute signs and symptoms of end-organ damage to differentiate hypertensive urgency from hypertensive emergency and to determine if rapid reduction in blood pressure is required. This patient's confusion (i.e., altered mental status manifesting with disorientation) is most likely due to hypertensive encephalopathy or stroke, indicating acute end-organ damage in the central nervous system. Patients with hypertensive emergencies should be immediately admitted for intravenous antihypertensive therapy and critical care.

Other clinical features of hypertensive emergency include cardiac symptoms (e.g., dyspnea, chest pain), acute kidney injury, acute hypertensive retinopathy, and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia.

question_text:
Patient Information
Age: 57 years
Gender: F, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: emergency department 
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “It feels like I'm running out of air.” 
History of Present Illness:

dyspnea, cough, and pleuritic chest pain for 20 minutes

pain is rated 9/10
was watching TV when symptoms suddenly started
underwent surgery for total right knee replacement 3 weeks ago

Past Medical History:
osteoarthritis
Medications:
ibuprofen for knee pain
Vaccinations:
up-to-date
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Psychosocial history:

lives with husband
has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years

does not drink alcohol

Physical Examination 

Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI

38.2°C
(100.8°F)

112/min
24/min
88/55 mm Hg
92% on 4LNC

165 cm
(5 ft 5 in)
78 kg
(170 lb)
28.7 kg/m^2

Appearance: in acute distress, unable to lay back; feels lightheaded 

Neck: jugular venous pressure of 8 cm H_2O above the sternal angle; trachea is midline

Pulmonary: decreased breath sounds bilaterally; productive cough with blood-tinged sputum
Cardiac: tachycardia; split S2
Abdominal: obese; nontender to palpation; normoactive bowel sounds; no hepatosplenomegaly 
Extremities: mildly tender surgical scar on the right knee, no edema; tenderness and erythema of the right calf; radial and femoral pulses intact bilaterally
Neurologic: alert, fully oriented

Diagnostic Studies

ECG: sinus tachycardia; QRS duration 140 ms, rSR' waves in leads V1-V2, ST-segment depression and T-wave inversion in leads V1-V2

bedside echocardiography: mid-segment dilatation of the right ventricle, tricuspid regurgitation, increased pulmonary artery systolic pressure

CT scan of the chest: shown

Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?

hint: Orthopedic surgeries, such as a total knee replacement, often cause prolonged immobilization. This is a significant risk factor for venous stasis.
learning_objective: Recognize massive pulmonary embolism with hemodynamic instability, and choose the most appropriate treatment.

answers.explanation_why: This patient's CT scan shows evidence of a large pulmonary embolism (PE). In cases of massive PE with hemodynamic instability (e.g., SBP < 90 mm Hg), thrombolysis with recombinant tissue plasminogen activators (tPA) such as alteplase is indicated. Because of the associated significant risk of bleeding, there are several relative and absolute contraindications to thrombolytic therapy. Surgery within the past 10 days is a relative contraindication, but this patient underwent surgery 3 weeks ago. Therefore, alteplase would be the most appropriate treatment. Anticoagulation with heparin, rivaroxaban, warfarin, or apixaban is also appropriate treatment for patients with PE. However, these agents are typically used in patients who remain hemodynamically stable.

Bumetanide is a diuretic used in the treatment of pulmonary edema. Pulmonary edema can manifest with dyspnea, cough, tachypnea, and jugular venous distension. However, her CT scan shows a vascular filling defect that is consistent with a pulmonary embolism rather than the findings typically seen in pulmonary edema (i.e., ground-glass opacities and peribronchovascular interstitial thickening). In addition, administering a diuretic could be detrimental to a patient with hypotension.

Pericardiocentesis is a procedure used to treat patients with pericardial effusion and cardiac tamponade. Cardiac tamponade can manifest with dyspnea, chest pain, hypotension, and jugular venous distension. However, her CT scan shows a vascular filling defect consistent with PE, as opposed to a fluid-filled pericardial sac, which would be typical in a patient with tamponade. Furthermore, pericardiocentesis would pose a risk of myocardial or endocardial injury in a patient who does not have pericardial effusion.

Endovascular stent-grafting can be used in the treatment of type A (proximal) aortic dissection. Patients typically present with severe, tearing chest pain, hypertension, and asymmetric pulses. Hypotension, severe dyspnea, and cough are less common manifestations of type A aortic dissection. The patient's CT scan also shows a vascular filling defect consistent with a pulmonary embolism rather than a tear in the aortic intima, which would be typical in a case of dissection.

images.title: Aortic dissection (Stanford A)
images.description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT angiography (chest; ECG-gated; venous and arterial phases; axial plane) of a patient with a history of recent weakness, vertigo, and facial swellingThe ascending aorta is dilated and a Stanford type A (DeBakey type II) aortic dissection is seen. The aortic arch and descending aorta are not affected. The right and left coronary, the innominate, the left common carotid, and the subclavian arteries originate from the true lumen (green overlay; false lumen is red overlay). Facial swelling is the result of venous congestion from compression of the superior vena cava (blue overlay) by the dilated ascending aorta. Bilateral small pleural effusions are seen.Additional findings include sternotomy wires, a prosthetic aortic valve, atherosclerotic calcifications, pancreatic calcifications, and a small hiatal hernia.LCA: left coronary artery; RCA: right coronary artery; yellow overlay: azygos vein

answers.explanation_why: Tube thoracostomy is used in the treatment of tension pneumothorax, which can manifest with dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, cough, jugular venous distension, and hypotension. However, her CT scan shows a vascular filling defect consistent with a pulmonary embolism rather than air in the pleural space with tracheal deviation, which is typical in cases of tension pneumothorax.

Piperacillin/tazobactam can be used in the treatment of pneumonia. Pneumonia can manifest with dyspnea and cough, and, in the setting of sepsis, even hypotension. However, jugular venous distension would not be expected in pneumonia. In addition, this patient's CT scan shows a vascular filling defect consistent with a pulmonary embolism rather than parenchymal infiltrates and/or consolidation, which would be typical in a case of pneumonia.

Coronary angioplasty is used in the treatment of myocardial infarction (MI). MI can manifest with chest pain, jugular venous distension, and hypotension. However, her CT scan shows a vascular filling defect consistent with a pulmonary embolism. In addition, a CT scan is typically not diagnostic in cases of myocardial infarction.

images.title: Saddle pulmonary embolism
images.description: CT chest (with contrast; axial plane)A large embolism burden is seen (green overlay), with extension across the bifurcation of the pulmonary trunk into the right and left pulmonary arteries.Straddling of the pulmonary trunk bifurcation by pulmonary embolism is sometimes referred to as saddle embolism.AA: ascending aorta; DA: descending aorta; E: esophagus; LMB: left main bronchus; LPA: left pulmonary artery; PT: pulmonary trunk; RMB: right main bronchus; RPA: right pulmonary artery; SVC: superior vena cava

question_text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after sustaining multiple injuries in a motor vehicle collision. On arrival, he is responsive only to painful stimuli. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 132/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 78/49 mm Hg. Physical examination shows cool, clammy skin and absent radial pulses. Lung examination shows clear breath sounds bilaterally. Intravenous fluid resuscitation is initiated, but the patient's blood pressure remains low. A focused assessment with sonography for trauma shows a large amount of free fluid in the abdomen. The decision is made to intubate the patient for airway protection. Shortly after endotracheal intubation and initiation of positive pressure ventilation, the patient's blood pressure drops to 62/38 mm Hg, and his pulse rises to 148/min. Airway pressures are consistent, and lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following best explains this patient's clinical deterioration after intubation?
content_preview: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after sustaining multiple injuries in a motor vehicle collision. On arrival, he is responsive only to painful stimuli. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 132/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 78/49 mm Hg. Physical examination shows cool, clammy skin and absent radial pulses. Lung examination shows clear breath sounds bilaterally. Intravenous fluid resuscitation is initiated, but the patient's blood pressure remains low. A focused assessment with sonography for trauma shows a large amount of free fluid in the abdomen. The decision is made to intubate the patient for airway protection. Shortly after endotracheal intubation and initiation of positive pressure ventilation, the patient's blood pressure drops to 62/38 mm Hg, and his pulse rises to 148/min. Airway pressures are consistent, and lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following best explains this patient's clinical deterioration after intubation?
hint: Hypovolemic shock is a high-risk indication for mechanical ventilation. Patients with hypovolemic shock have an increased risk of peri-intubation mortality from cardiac arrest due to the adverse effects of induction agents and the transition to positive pressure ventilation.
learning_objective: Recognize the danger of positive pressure ventilation in patients with hypovolemic shock.

answers.content: Decrease in cardiac output due to decreased venous return
answers.explanation_why:
This patient with severe hypotension, tachycardia, cool clammy skin, and absent radial pulses is in hypovolemic shock, likely due to intra-abdominal hemorrhage resulting from the motor vehicle collision. Hypovolemia causes low preload, so the heart relies on high venous return to maintain cardiac output. Positive pressure ventilation (PPV) increases intrathoracic pressure, which further impedes venous return to the right heart. In a patient who is already volume-depleted, this can cause a precipitous drop in cardiac output and blood pressure, manifesting with acute worsening of hypotension and tachycardia after intubation.

Adequate volume resuscitation before and during intubation, using the lowest possible mean airway pressure and positive end-expiratory pressure, and close hemodynamic monitoring are essential when performing intubation and PPV in patients with shock.

answers.content: Lung collapse due to loss of pressure gradient between alveoli and pleural cavity
answers.explanation_why: This describes pneumothorax, which can be caused by pulmonary barotrauma due to mechanical ventilation. Increased intrathoracic pressure in pneumothorax impairs venous return to the heart, resulting in decreased cardiac output and hypotension. However, a sudden increase in airway pressures would be expected, whereas this patient's airway pressures are consistent.

answers.content: Accumulation of protein-rich fluid in the alveolar space due to increased permeability
answers.explanation_why: This is the pathophysiology of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). ARDS can develop after trauma but typically manifests with significant hypoxemia, not with acute hypotension immediately after intubation. In addition, bilateral pulmonary infiltrates are a feature of ARDS, whereas this patient's lungs are clear to auscultation.

answers.content: Accumulation of protein-poor fluid in the alveolar space due to increased hydrostatic pressure
answers.explanation_why: This describes cardiogenic pulmonary edema, which results from elevated left-sided heart pressures (e.g., due to acute heart failure or MI). This patient's lungs are clear to auscultation.

answers.content: Myocardial ischemia due to reduced coronary blood flow
answers.explanation_why: Although hypotension can reduce coronary perfusion, leading to myocardial ischemia, the temporal relationship between symptom onset and positive pressure ventilation initiation in this patient with hypovolemia indicates a different primary mechanism for the hemodynamic collapse.

question_text: A 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance 20 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. He was found at the scene with altered mental status and significant bleeding from a deep laceration on his left thigh. His medical and social history are unknown. On arrival, he appears pale and diaphoretic. He is unable to answer questions appropriately. His temperature is 36.2°C (97.2°F), pulse is 142/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 78/42 mm Hg. Examination shows a large, actively bleeding wound over the left thigh with exposed muscle tissue.  Peripheral pulses are weak, and capillary refill is delayed. There are no other signs of external bleeding. Two large-bore intravenous lines are placed, and initial laboratory studies are drawn. In addition to intravenous fluids, which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for hemodynamic support in this patient?
content_preview: A 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance 20 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. He was found at the scene with altered mental status and significant bleeding from a deep laceration on his left thigh. His medical and social history are unknown. On arrival, he appears pale and diaphoretic. He is unable to answer questions appropriately. His temperature is 36.2°C (97.2°F), pulse is 142/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 78/42 mm Hg. Examination shows a large, actively bleeding wound over the left thigh with exposed muscle tissue. Peripheral pulses are weak, and capillary refill is delayed. There are no other signs of external bleeding. Two large-bore intravenous lines are placed, and initial laboratory studies are drawn. In addition to intravenous fluids, which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for hemodynamic support in this patient?
hint: This patient presents with altered mental status, tachycardia, hypotension, weak peripheral pulses, and delayed capillary refill in combination with a large, actively bleeding wound, which suggests hemorrhagic shock.
learning_objective: Recognize that inotropic agents are not appropriate in the initial management of hemorrhagic shock due to trauma.

answers.explanation_why: Vasopressors and inotropes are contraindicated as first-line therapy for hemorrhagic shock because they can worsen tissue perfusion and increase the risk of ischemic complications, and they do not address the primary problem of inadequate circulating volume. Hemorrhagic shock is characterized by profound hypovolemia leading to decreased preload and cardiac output. The most crucial intervention for hemorrhagic shock from acute trauma is immediate hemostatic control and rapid restoration of intravascular volume with transfusion of packed red blood cells and other blood components. Early transfusion improves outcomes and increases survival rates in trauma-related hemorrhagic shock.

Norepinephrine is a potent vasoconstrictor used as a first-line agent for treating septic or distributive shock because of its strong alpha-adrenergic effects, which increase systemic vascular resistance and blood pressure. However, in hemorrhagic shock, vasoconstrictors can further decrease tissue perfusion and do not correct the underlying hypovolemia. Without volume resuscitation, norepinephrine may worsen organ ischemia and is therefore inappropriate as initial management in trauma-induced hemorrhagic shock.

Dobutamine is a beta-1 adrenergic agonist that primarily increases cardiac contractility and heart rate, making it useful in cardiogenic shock with reduced contractility. However, in hypovolemic shock, the primary problem is inadequate circulating volume rather than pump failure. Increasing contractility without restoring volume will not improve perfusion and may precipitate arrhythmias or worsen hypotension.

Epinephrine has both alpha-adrenergic and beta-adrenergic effects, increasing heart rate, contractility, and systemic vascular resistance. This drug is indicated in anaphylactic shock and sometimes in cardiac arrest. In trauma-related hemorrhagic shock, epinephrine does not address the underlying hypovolemia. Although epinephrine can transiently elevate arterial pressure, the drug may exacerbate tissue ischemia by increasing systemic vascular resistance and myocardial oxygen consumption, without improving perfusion or oxygen delivery to vital organs.

Dopamine has dose-dependent effects, acting as a vasopressor at higher doses and an inotrope at moderate doses. While dopamine can be used to treat some forms of shock (e.g., cardiogenic or septic), this drug is not recommended in hemorrhagic shock because it does not address the primary problem of volume loss. Dopamine can also increase heart rate and myocardial oxygen demand, which may be harmful in patients with hypoperfusion from blood loss.

question_text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being found unresponsive at home. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation is initiated by paramedics, but he remains unresponsive on arrival. His family says he appeared healthy on the previous day. He has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. He has no history of substance use and is not married. Physical examination shows a comatose man who is intubated and mechanically ventilated. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 82/min, blood pressure is 122/76 mm Hg, and respirations are controlled by the ventilator. He has fixed, dilated pupils, absent corneal and gag reflexes, and no spontaneous movements. Apnea testing confirms the absence of spontaneous respirations. The attending physician discloses the diagnosis of brain death to the family and gives some time to process the information. In a follow-up conversation, the physician addresses the topic of organ donation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
content_preview: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being found unresponsive at home. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation is initiated by paramedics, but he remains unresponsive on arrival. His family says he appeared healthy on the previous day. He has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. He has no history of substance use and is not married. Physical examination shows a comatose man who is intubated and mechanically ventilated. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 82/min, blood pressure is 122/76 mm Hg, and respirations are controlled by the ventilator. He has fixed, dilated pupils, absent corneal and gag reflexes, and no spontaneous movements. Apnea testing confirms the absence of spontaneous respirations. The attending physician discloses the diagnosis of brain death to the family and gives some time to process the information. In a follow-up conversation, the physician addresses the topic of organ donation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
hint: There are standardized processes for donor candidates who did not explicitly decline to donate organs.
learning_objective: Recognize key principles and requirements for organ donation in clinical practice.

answers.content: Request approval from the hospital ethics committee before proceeding
answers.explanation_why: Although the ethics committee may be involved in complex or disputed cases, its approval is not necessary for standard organ procurement procedures once brain death has been declared.

answers.content: Wait for a mandatory 24-hour period after brain death is declared before proceeding
answers.explanation_why: There is no mandatory waiting period between brain death and the initiation of the organ procurement process. Once brain death is confirmed, the patient is legally dead, and organ procurement procedures may proceed following established protocols. Prolonging the interval without a specific clinical or legal reason may reduce organ viability and is not a standard procedural step in organ donation protocols.

answers.content: Notify the local organ procurement organization for evaluation
answers.explanation_why: Federal regulations and hospital policy require that all potential organ donors be reported to a local organ procurement organization (OPO) as soon as brain death is established or imminent, unless the deceased patient has specifically declined to become a donor (e.g., in an advance directive). The OPO is responsible for evaluating medical suitability and discussing organ donation with the family. Physicians and hospital staff should not initiate the process for donation themselves (e.g., by obtaining consent), as this may result in conflicts of interest and reduce consent rates. OPO staff are specially trained to provide support, address questions, and facilitate the process ethically and sensitively. Early notification preserves organ viability and ensures that the process respects medical, ethical, and legal standards.

answers.content: Proceed only if the patient had a documented donor card
answers.explanation_why: Documented donor status is helpful but not required to initiate the process of organ donation. While a documented donor card or registration in a donor registry is legally binding in many states, organ donation evaluation should proceed even if such documentation is not available. In many cases, family members or legally authorized representatives may make decisions about donation in the absence of documented donor status, provided that other requirements and protocols are followed.

answers.content: Obtain written consent for organ donation from the patient's mother
answers.explanation_why: Written consent for organ donation may sometimes be required from the next of kin, depending on state law and the patient’s documented wishes. However, the process for obtaining and validating consent is standardized and typically involves designated professionals who are trained in these sensitive discussions.

question_text: A 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a high-speed motorcycle collision. He was intubated for airway protection and is admitted to the neurointensive care unit. Past medical history is unremarkable. His driver's license identifies him as an organ donor, and his name appears on the state donor registry. On hospital day 2, two attending physicians independently complete a brain death examination; pupils are fixed and nonreactive, corneal and gag reflexes are absent, and apnea tests confirm absence of respiratory drive. He is not receiving sedatives or paralytics, and he does not have hypothermia. He remains on mechanical ventilation with stable hemodynamics. The hospital has notified the regional organ procurement organization (OPO) per policy. The patient’s father states that the family’s religious beliefs prohibit organ donation and asks the team to “stop this process.” Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a high-speed motorcycle collision. He was intubated for airway protection and is admitted to the neurointensive care unit. Past medical history is unremarkable. His driver's license identifies him as an organ donor, and his name appears on the state donor registry. On hospital day 2, two attending physicians independently complete a brain death examination; pupils are fixed and nonreactive, corneal and gag reflexes are absent, and apnea tests confirm absence of respiratory drive. He is not receiving sedatives or paralytics, and he does not have hypothermia. He remains on mechanical ventilation with stable hemodynamics. The hospital has notified the regional organ procurement organization (OPO) per policy. The patient’s father states that the family’s religious beliefs prohibit organ donation and asks the team to “stop this process.” Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: OPOs rely on state donor registries linked to driver's license information for timely verification of patient preferences.
learning_objective: Recall ethical principles of organ donation when family objects after patient consent.

answers.content: Obtain written consent from the patient's mother
answers.explanation_why: Next of kin consent for organ donation is only required if the patient's intent to donate organs is not documented or if the patient is a minor (because the consent of the legal guardian is required). This patient has given first-person authorization for organ donation, and further consent from family members is not legally necessary.

A court order may be necessary in the event of an unresolved legal dispute (e.g., ambiguity about the patient's identity, lack of documented donor registration). Family refusal is not a valid reason to halt organ procurement in patients who have provided first-person authorization for donation.

Canceling organ procurement is only appropriate if the patient's intent to donate organs is not documented, if the patient does not meet donation criteria, or if there are legal or medical contraindications to donation. In this scenario, the patient is a registered organ donor, and brain death has been confirmed. A patient's next of kin cannot override a first person authorization for organ donation.

An individual's documented decision to become an organ donor (e.g., indicating donor status on a driver’s license) is legally binding and recognized as first person authorization. Once an individual has been declared brain-dead, assuming there are no medical (e.g., malignancy) or legal contraindications (e.g., need for legal investigation) for donation, hospitals and OPOs must respect the patient's autonomy by proceeding with organ donation. The patient's next-of-kin cannot override a valid first person authorization for any reason (e.g., religious beliefs). Clinicians should offer compassionate support and give clear information to the family but are otherwise obligated to follow the patient’s documented wishes.

Standard protocol requires notifying an OPO as soon as a patient is near death with a severe neurological injury and again within 1 hour after brain death. After notification, the OPO is responsible for evaluating the donor candidate and procuring the organ.

An ethics committee provides guidance in cases of moral or legal uncertainty, such as ambiguous advance directives. This patient has given first-person authorization for organ donation, and convening the ethics committee is therefore unnecessary.

question_text: A 48-year-old woman calls her primary care physician via the clinic's real-time telehealth platform. She sounds anxious and speaks in short sentences. She reports that after eating shrimp at a restaurant, she experienced lip swelling, difficulty breathing, and dizziness. She has a documented shellfish allergy. The patient is currently at home with her partner and states that she took oral diphenhydramine just before calling. She does not have an epinephrine autoinjector. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?
content_preview: A 48-year-old woman calls her primary care physician via the clinic's real-time telehealth platform. She sounds anxious and speaks in short sentences. She reports that after eating shrimp at a restaurant, she experienced lip swelling, difficulty breathing, and dizziness. She has a documented shellfish allergy. The patient is currently at home with her partner and states that she took oral diphenhydramine just before calling. She does not have an epinephrine autoinjector. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?
hint: Acute lip swelling, shortness of breath, and dizziness after shrimp ingestion in a patient with a known shellfish allergy are consistent with anaphylaxis, which is a life-threatening medical emergency.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate action for a patient presenting with a medical emergency via online or telephone communication.

answers.content: Reassure the patient and arrange a clinic visit the same day
answers.explanation_why: Same-day clinic evaluation is appropriate for individuals experiencing a stable allergic reaction limited to mild skin involvement. However, severe systemic symptoms such as respiratory distress and cardiovascular instability necessitate urgent intervention that cannot be safely delayed. Outpatient evaluation in this scenario risks rapid deterioration before arrival at the clinic.

answers.content: Ask the patient's partner to drive her to the hospital if her symptoms do not improve within 30 minutes
answers.explanation_why: Advising private transport with a planned delay is unsafe in a patient with dyspnea after an allergen exposure. Anaphylaxis can progress to airway obstruction or cardiovascular compromise within minutes.

answers.content: Instruct the patient to call emergency medical services immediately for transport to the hospital
answers.explanation_why:
In telemedicine encounters, physicians must immediately direct the patient or caregiver to activate emergency medical services if there is any suspicion of a medical emergency. Epinephrine is the first-line treatment for anaphylaxis and should be given at the first sign of respiratory compromise or hypotension. Delayed administration of epinephrine is associated with increased rates of hospitalization, biphasic reactions, and death. Further remote evaluation or reassurance must never delay definitive in-person care in an emergency.

Patients with known anaphylactic reactions should be prescribed an epinephrine autoinjector for future allergen exposures.

answers.content: Prescribe an epinephrine autoinjector and instruct the patient to obtain it from the nearest pharmacy
answers.explanation_why: Epinephrine is the first-line treatment for anaphylaxis and should be given at the first sign of respiratory compromise or hypotension. Prescribing an epinephrine autoinjector is a critical long-term safety measure for individuals at risk of anaphylaxis. However, writing a prescription is inappropriate during an acute reaction because it delays urgent intervention.

answers.content: Perform a video examination before making further recommendations
answers.explanation_why: A video examination may help clarify the severity of less urgent concerns but must never delay the activation of emergency services in life-threatening situations.
